PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Is the Minister for Defence aware that the parliamentary left members of his Party have this morning dissociated themselves from the 1991 Australian International Defence Equipment Exhibition, the one known as AIDEX, and have indicated that they will be seeking the cancellation of future arms trade fairs in Australia? Can the Minister state what the Government's policy is with regard to both the 1991 and future AIDEX exhibitions in Australia and what would be the consequences for Australian defence and the defence industry in Australia if the parliamentary left's views were to prevail?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The characterisation that there is only one group in politics that is not keen on AIDEX is not correct. I know Senator Spindler is also interested in this particular issue. The Government's attitude is that it is an exhibition run by a private company. It is not Government sponsored per se, although we do have one or two small exhibitions from DSTO and another element at AIDEX 91.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have been minded to say to Senator Durack on many occasions, I do not believe that the exhibition of arms or material on arms is the relevant question for this Government. I regard the relevant question as the proper and stringent export controls by which government policy can be applied very selectively to make sure any arms exports go to areas of stability, traditional allies and areas that have a good human rights record. With that in mind, I therefore draw that distinction.

I can understand that people who have spent many years in the peace movement would oppose, per se, an arms exhibition. I do not share that view. I share the sentiments of their goodwill about trying to bring about worldwide disarmament. I have no quarrel with that. But I do believe that there is not much difference between having an exhibition and having the same type of materiel portrayed in magazines, by personal representation or by lobbying.

I remind those that do oppose it that the critical aspect is whether one has proper and stringent export controls. That is the way this Government has sought to treat this particular matter and will continue to do so in future.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I ask a supplementary question. The call by his colleagues in the parliamentary left and, indeed, others is also presumably to the Government to prevent AIDEX exhibitions of this kind being held again in Australia after the one this year; in other words, it would be the last. Can I take it from the Minister's reply that the Government would not accede to that request?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I do not have that request immediately before me; no doubt it might be coming. I never rule out any request if it is backed up by proper argument. From an Australian defence point of view, it would not be the end of the world whether or not we have an AIDEX exhibition. I do not think it would massively impact upon the activities of the Australian defence forces.

ANSWER.PARA: On the other hand, there is no way I am going to just drop or eliminate the activities of private companies simply on the basis that people do not like them. There has to be a substantial reason, and a substantial Government reason, for intervention to that extent. No such reason has been put before me at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In view of the Nobel Peace Prize for 1991 being awarded to Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, can the Minister advise, firstly, whether he believes that the Nobel Peace Prize for Daw Aung San Suu Kyi will improve the opportunities for Burma to achieve democracy? Secondly, is the Australian Government making efforts in the United Nations and ASEAN to put pressure on the military regime in Burma to hand over power to the democratically elected National League for Democracy? Thirdly, will the Australian Government demand that the military regime immediately release Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and all political prisoners? Fourthly, in recognition of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi being awarded the Nobel Peace Prize and her unswerving efforts to achieve democracy in Burma, will the Australian Government extend an official invitation to her to visit Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am sure that all Australians would share my delight at the news of the 1991 Nobel Peace Prize being awarded to Daw Aung San Suu Kyi. We, as a government--and I am sure that I do so on behalf of all the Australian people--extend to her and to the people of Burma our congratulations on this very great honour.

ANSWER.PARA: The conferring of the award does demonstrate the enormous respect that Aung San Suu Kyi has earned from the international community for her very great moral courage and determination to bring about political reform in Burma. It should bring home in very clear terms to the SLORC, the governing military regime, the strong international concern about the situation in Burma and should also lend some hope to the Burmese people. Coupled with the very clear results of the elections that were held in May last year and the continuing international pressure, the awarding of the Nobel Peace Prize should improve opportunities for Burma to achieve democracy.

Certainly, as to the more specific second part of the question about Australian Government efforts, we are participating actively in international efforts to persuade the military regime to implement democratic reform and to observe human rights. At the current UN General Assembly we intend to co-sponsor a resolution on Burma and we are working to obtain the widest possible support for that. We are encouraged by the recent statement of the Thai Foreign Minister, Arsa Sarasin, that ASEAN hopes to encourage Burma to make a peaceful transition towards closer integration with other countries in the region. We have been in all our contacts--in my contacts, certainly, with ASEAN Ministers in recent months--reinforcing that view.

Again, we shall continue to take a prominent stand on Burma at the UN Commission on Human Rights, in view of the continued detention of a number of political prisoners in that country. In this respect, I should say that there was a report today that Professor Yokota, the special representative appointed by the UN Commission, will make his initial visit to Burma before the end of this year. We understand that it is likely that he will request a meeting with Aung San Suu Kyi. Whether he gets it is another question, of course. He will submit a report of his visit to the next session of the Commission early next year and we will be watching those developments closely.

We are also implementing a policy of close coordination with other countries--in Europe, North America and elsewhere--that share our deep concerns about Burma. In regular consultations, we have raised the question of economic sanctions. We realise that such sanctions cannot be effective if they are not supported by the main regional trading partners. That has rather inhibited that effort to date. Similarly, we are advocating an international arms embargo against Burma and the Minister for Defence--it is his responsibility--and I have made clear that we will not be exporting defence and defence related goods to that country.

As to the third part of the question, about demanding immediate release, it is certainly the case that the continued detention of Aung San Suu Kyi and others discredits the military regime and infringes internationally accepted standards of human rights, certainly in her case. We have consistently called for her release. We have condemned her detention and exclusion from public life. I do so again today. We will continue to demand in vigorous terms her immediate and unconditional release.

As to the last part of the question, about an invitation to visit Australia, of course it is the case that Aung San Suu Kyi would be a welcome guest in Australia at any time. Given that she is under house detention at the moment, that is not a very practical prospect for the time being. We certainly will do our best to communicate--if it has not been made clear already by contacts that Senator Schacht and others have had with her--that she would be a very welcome guest.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. As we are now being required to debate the Appropriation Bills based on a Budget which has subsequently been fundamentally changed in relation to Medicare, how is the Government planning to pay for these changes? What further legislation is going to be necessary? When will we see the legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The question about the progress of the legislation is more appropriately addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. In so far as the Budget implications of the Medicare changes are concerned, I will be able to give Senator Walters a more detailed answer in due course, but let me just say that the overall outlays, the new policy balance, in the 1991-92 Budget change from a reduction of $50m to plus $19m--that is, at Budget time this year the Government had offset all new policy agreed since the 1991 Budget as well as saving a further $50m.

ANSWER.PARA: The size of the change and any risk to the overall Budget strategy need to be placed in the proper context; that is, changes at the margin to a Budget with outlays of some $100 billion are not an unusual occurrence. Such a small change would not be likely to alter the Budget strategy. Moreover, it pales into insignificance when viewed against, for example, the $750m change forced on the 1991 Budget by the Opposition, relating to the gas pipeline from Sydney, and the $50m for not supporting changes to family allowance and family allowance supplement assets test criteria.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. As the Minister would know, not all that legislation has been through the chamber, so one cannot surmise anything in that area. Will the Minister please table those figures so that I can see them? It is very hard to assess what he is saying when he is just rattling off a whole lot of figures. I am sure my colleagues would also like to see them.
—-What have we got a Hansard for?
—-They will be in Hansard, but I need the figures now.
—-They will be in Hansard.

—-I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications to a discussion paper on public broadcasting sponsorship provisions prepared by the broadcasting policy division of the Department of Transport and Communications in May 1991. Were comments invited from interested parties on this paper and, if so, how was the invitation extended? Have submissions been received from the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, the Federation of Australian Broadcasters, the Public Broadcasting Association and any individual public broadcasters? Is a further paper to be issued by the Department following comment on the May 1991 paper and, if so, when may it be expected that such a further paper will be released?
—-I am aware that this was a matter which Senator Colston pursued rather aggressively at the Estimates committees.
—-Vigorously.

—-Vigorously and effectively. I am pleased to be able to provide Senator Colston with the following information. The Department wrote to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters, the Public Broadcasting Association of Australia and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy on 26 June this year seeking comments on the paper. Submissions were received from all of these bodies and also from two public broadcasters, 3ZZZ and 2WEB. The Government will consider the issues on the basis of the paper and the responses which were made to it. It will make a decision at that time on what will be the next steps to take.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and concerns the impending decision of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Kelly--I believe this Thursday--to renew Pasminco Metals-EZ's licence to dump thousands of tonnes of jarosite containing heavy metals, arsenic, zinc, copper, iron, mercury and cadmium and EZ's seeking of a five-year dumping licence instead of the usual 12 months. Firstly, can the Minister confirm that Australia voted for a 1990 resolution of the London Dumping Convention which agreed to stop all sea dumping of industrial waste by the end of 1995 and also that in this year's South Pacific Forum communique Australia commended this decision? Secondly, I ask the Minister whether he agrees that a recent letter from the Environment Minister, Mrs Kelly, to Greenpeace totally discredits Australia's commitment by stating:

QUESTION.PARA: I do not at this stage propose to stipulate to Pasminco Metals-EZ that it must cease ocean dumping by a specified date.

Finally, will the Minister therefore ask the Prime Minister to direct Mrs Kelly to fully honour Australia's international obligations by stipulating a date on or before 31 December 1995 by which sea dumping of jarosite must cease; if not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-This question appropriately should be directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, but Senator Coulter has asked it of me because of that nifty little part in it about directing the Minister for the Environment to do some particular thing. First of all, let me say that Australia did support the consensus agreement at the thirteenth consultative meeting of contracting parties to the London Dumping Convention in 1990. That resolution provides for the phasing out of sea dumping of industrial wastes by the end of 1995. The Government supported this year's South Pacific Forum's communique commending the London Dumping Convention resolution. So the answer to the first part of Senator Coulter's question is yes.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the second part of the question, as to whether it is agreed that a recent letter from the Environment Minister, Mrs Kelly, to Greenpeace totally discredits Australia's commitment at the London Convention, is no. Australia supports the principle underlying the resolution that the production of waste should be minimised and disposed of in an environmentally sound manner. In formulating that resolution, the parties to the London Convention recognised that there were very real difficulties in implementation. Accordingly, the Convention states that `the cessation of dumping of industrial wastes should not result in unacceptable environmental effects elsewhere'. I understand from personal knowledge that there is some debate about that issue taking place in Tasmania at the present time. I think there is a division of opinion amongst environmentalists about it.

I make the further point that there is to be an evaluation in 1992 of the consequences of this decision to determine any technical and social difficulties in the adoption of alternative methods of waste management. That resolution has already been copied to EZ, and the company has been put on notice with respect to the 1995 deadline. Clearly, however, there will be a range of issues which the company will need to address to meet this or any earlier deadline. It is not merely an issue of transferring the problem from the sea to the land. The Government and the company are seeking a long term solution that minimises overall environmental impacts.
The answer to the third part of the question, as to whether the Prime Minister will direct Mrs Kelly on this matter, is no, for the reasons which I have outlined above.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister: why, in view of Australia's signing the London Dumping Convention, will the Prime Minister not direct Mrs Kelly to at least observe a date within that December 1995 time frame? Secondly, is the Minister aware that Pasminco owns a 50 per cent share in the Budel zinc smelter in the Netherlands? The Dutch Government is also a signatory to the London Dumping Convention. The Dutch Government has banned sea dumping, as a result of which that company is temporarily placing the waste on land. It is putting its material on land and it has a wide ranging research program on safe disposal. Is the Minister aware of those facts?

—-The answer to the last part of the question was no, because the London Convention does not require that, as I have already indicated in my answer to Senator Coulter. The honourable senator then asked, by way of a supplementary question, whether I am aware of the adoption of new practices by a company in the Netherlands in which EZ has a shareholding. The answer to that part of the question is no, I was not aware of that. But, in any event, I regard it as entirely irrelevant. Of course, it will depend upon the circumstances in which alternative measures of disposing of waste are available. Certainly, in Tasmania, there has been a very respectable body of scientific opinion to the effect that the disposal of waste on land is not a simple or satisfactory solution to the issue which arises in respect of EZ.

—-My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. The Minister will be aware of the fear in this country of damage to coastal areas that can be caused by oil pollution at sea. Can the Minister give an update on his previous advice that the Federal Government is instituting a review of the national plan to combat sea-sourced oil pollution?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Following the Kirki incident, honourable senators will recall that I advised the Senate that, about a week prior to the Kirki incident occurring, I had written to all of my State colleagues seeking their support for a complete review of the national plan to combat oil pollution at sea, known as Natplan. I am pleased to advise the Senate that the recent meeting of the Transport Advisory Council in Darwin, which comprises Federal and State Ministers for Transport, endorsed the Federal Government's recommendation that this plan should be completely reviewed. Natplan represents a cooperative effort between the Federal and State governments which is coordinated with similar measures by the oil industry itself. It has operated successfully since its establishment in 1973 and it was instrumental in ensuring a rapid and successful resolution to the Kirki incident.

ANSWER.PARA: From 1 January this year, the Australian Maritime Safety Authority assumed responsibility for Natplan's administration and it is appropriate that the chief executive officer of AMSA, Mr Paul McGrath, will chair the review. The review will also involve senior officers from both Federal and State departments and include representatives from the oil and shipping industries. The review, which it is anticipated will take about six months, will examine levels of risk, equipment and training needs, management issues and the respective responsibilities of government and industry bodies which are involved in an oil spill response situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. I take up the invitation of Senator Button and ask the Minister: how is the Government planning to implement the Medicare changes it has just made? Is it intending to amend the appropriations legislation which has been already debated in part by the Senate?

—-As I understand it, the Health Insurance Amendment Bill is currently in the House of Representatives and there will be required to be a Government amendment to that Bill to take account of the changes announced by the Deputy Prime Minister, the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, in relation to the Medicare co-payment. As Senator Walters and other honourable senators who serve on the Standing Committee on Community Affairs under the chairmanship of Senator Zakharov would know, that Committee is scheduled to hold hearings about that Bill on Friday, 8 November; at least I was notified to that effect by the Secretary of that Committee yesterday.

—-Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I understand what the Minister said in relation to co-payment. The question is really about how the Government will finance the shortfall as a result of its change to Medicare. I ask again, therefore, whether that will require amendment to the set of Appropriation Bills currently before the Senate.

—-I will have to seek advice on that, not only from the portfolio Minister but also from the Minister for Finance in relation to the necessity, if there is one, to deal with this matter by change to the Appropriation Bills during this session as opposed to the usual procedure of Additional Estimates. I will seek further information in relation to that.

—-Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of claims that Australia's image as a reliable and cost efficient trading nation is hampered by inaccurate and stereotyped views overseas about Australian workers and work practices? Can the Minister advise the Senate whether the Government has taken steps to counteract these views among our major trading partners and to promote the significant reforms in work practices and industrial relations generally that have been made in Australia in recent years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the first part of that question is: much less so now than was previously the case. Previously, Australia did have a stereotypical image overseas of being dispute prone. But increasingly, as our trading partners have come to realise the changes that this Government has been able to effect in the industrial relations landscape of this country, there has been a recognition that the changes have, in part, succeeded and that our reliability, quality and timeliness are much greater.

ANSWER.PARA: However, there are still, in a recidivist way, some problems with the old stereotype and, most typically, they relate to non-English speaking trading partners--specifically, Japan. That is not to say that all Japanese businessmen have that view; they certainly do not. As a consequence of explaining developments in the Australian industrial relations system so that our key trading partner was aware of them, my Department has published a booklet which contains a photograph of a vessel from the North West Shelf which supplies LNG to greater Tokyo. As a mark of confidence in Australia's reliability, that vessel needs to appear on the horizon of Tokyo Bay like clockwork all the time or the lights go down in greater Tokyo. The Japanese have no doubt placed their faith in the reliability of this Australian export. The booklet has been produced as a means of explaining the vast changes that have occurred.

I am pleased to say that many eminent Australians--among them Alan Jackson of BTR Nylex; Phillip Brass of Pacific Dunlop; Peter Robson of Anderson Rae; Bill Kelty of the ACTU; Peter Newman of the Shipping Industry Reform Authority; Brian Noakes of the Confederation of Australian Industry; John Prescott of BHP; and Martin Ferguson of the ACTU--have all written in this booklet, in their own words, about the vast improvement in Australia's industrial relations performance. The booklet also contains tables most commonly sourced from the OECD which illustrate the changes that have occurred.

The booklet is a resource manual for Japanese industry, government and union leaders. It gives a snapshot of the progress that has been made, the reduction in industrial disputes, and the vast changes in workplace reform and award restructuring. It is in great demand and available through both the Australian Embassy in Japan, which collaborated with us in the preparation of the document, and Australian trading houses which deal with Japan. It is in so much demand that when I lead a tripartite mission, which includes Brian Noakes of the Confederation of Australian Industry and Martin Ferguson of the ACTU, to Japan in January under the terms of the Nara treaty, we will have the publication updated so that all of us representing Australia abroad can pull as a team and present an accurate view of the vast changes in industrial relations in this country.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to today's reports that last night the Minister met with his Victorian counterpart and fellow Keating supporter, Mr David White, the Victorian Minister for Manufacturing and Industrial Development. Was the meeting with prime ministerial persona non grata Mr White with the knowledge and approval of the conveniently absent Prime Minister? I met with Minister White last night--I meet with industry Ministers from each of the States if they request me to do so--and we had a very useful discussion.

If the Minister cannot answer either of those questions, we will understand why.

—-There was no reference at all in our discussion to what Senator Alston is pleased to call `Mrs Kirner's constant cry'. In relation to the first part of the question, as to whether the Prime Minister knew that I was meeting with David White, I regard that as totally irrelevant; but the answer is, I think not.
—-I bet Mr Keating knew.
—-No, he did not.

—-Has the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade seen reports of an alleged massacre of Iraqi soldiers in Suleimaniya? What is the Government's response to these reports and the present situation of the Kurds in general?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am aware, as I imagine other senators will be, of press reports which indicate that more than 60 unarmed Iraqi soldiers, taken prisoner by Kurds in Suleimaniya last week, were brutally massacred by their captors. On the information available to us at this stage, which is still quite limited, it appears that the reports are correct, but we are seeking further clarification.

ANSWER.PARA: The murders are an appalling reminder of the tragic circumstances now prevailing in northern Iraq. They have apparently taken place in the context of renewed and widespread fighting between Kurds and the Iraqi Army in several areas of northern Iraq, and against the backdrop of further Turkish hot-pursuits of Kurdish rebels into northern Iraq.

A representative of the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan, one of the main Kurdish parties, is presently visiting Australia to talk to Government representatives and others about the situation of Kurds in Iraq. Mr Hussein Sinjari has been seen by Mr Howe and by Mr Hand, and by officers of my Department and AIDAB. When asked about the massacre, I understand that he expressed his revulsion and extreme regret at what had happened. He believed that Iraqi security was behind the killings; that was his explanation. He further understands that Kurdish groups have begun an inquiry into the massacre.
In this context I should note that the leader of the other major Kurdish faction, the Kurdish Democratic Party, Mr Massoud Barzani, has also expressed his abhorrence at the killings.

So far as the response of the Australian Government is concerned we, of course, condemn in the strongest possible terms any such massacre which may have occurred, and call on all parties to the Kurdish conflict to exercise maximum restraint. Acts of violence of this kind can only serve to set back the already very difficult process of reconciliation and rebuilding that is so badly needed in northern Iraq.

We have made some substantial aid donations to the Kurdish relief effort, including a total of $3.1m in emergency relief, and sending a team of 75 ADF personnel to northern Iraq for a month at a cost of $4.4m.

United Nations personnel continue to be active in assisting the Iraqi Kurds and monitoring their situation. Ultimately, however, responsibility for the welfare of Kurds and other civilians in Iraq does depend on the Iraqi leadership. We hope that the Iraqi authorities will work with all parties in Iraq to address the needs of the different ethnic and religious groups, and guarantee them the basic human rights for which they have so long waited.

—-The answer is just no.

Question Time after Question Time, Senator Bishop raises assertions in order to get public attention. I will tell Senator Bishop what the public think of her--they think she is a joke.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Of course, when Senator Bolkus is lacking in information, he usually descends to that sort of response. I simply reiterate: I would like a report on the facts. Was Mr Della Bosca here? Did he in fact brief Labor Party politicians? Will he report back on those findings, including details of who received the maps prior to the Commissioners publishing them in a public manner--a list of those people who had access to them?
—-During the break in sittings a number of people in Adelaide asked me about Question Time and Senator Bishop. I did have to say to them that I did not think she was all that bright.
—-Mr President, I raise a point of order. This is not an answer to the question. You have a responsibility to keep him in order.
—-Order! Senator Bolkus, answer the question.

—-I did say to them that I did not think she was all that bright. Thirty seconds ago, in response to Senator Bishop's first question, I made a number of commitments. Had she listened to my answer, she would not have risen to ask the second question; it is superfluous. I have already answered her first question and, in doing so, answered the supplementary question. Senator Bishop would do her constituents a great service if she actually lifted her game.

—-My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Apparently reliable reports in today's media suggest that finance Ministers at the meeting of the International Monetary Fund in Bangkok have endorsed reductions in spending on farm subsidies. Given these reports and indications of a change in German attitudes, what are the prospects for achieving a successful outcome in the Uruguay Round of trade negotiations by the end of this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It does appear from reports of the IMF meeting in Bangkok that there has been a recognition of the importance for the international economy of bringing the Uruguay Round to a speedy conclusion. That is certainly the view that the Treasurer, John Kerin, has been putting to the IMF and World Bank at that meeting. I do understand that the meeting has taken the positive step, as Senator Loosley said, of endorsing a cut in trade subsidies.

ANSWER.PARA: The Uruguay Round now appears set to enter its final phase, reflecting the commitment of the G7 leaders made at their London summit to bring the Round to a successful conclusion. It also reflects the pressure by many countries around the world, not least Australia and members of the Cairns Group, for participants to face up to the politically hard decisions that are necessary to conclude the Round. It certainly does seem that the finance Ministers have reinforced this position.

As to the general state of play on the Round, the Director-General of the GATT, Mr Arthur Dunkel, does plan to table a draft final agreement around mid-November which will contain a package of results across the full Uruguay Round agenda. He has asked the negotiating groups to finalise their contributions by 1 November. The package will reflect agreements reached by the end of 1990, progressed during this year, and proposed solutions to unresolved problems. All participants, once that package is on the table, will then have to decide whether they will make the difficult political decisions needed to unblock the Round, especially in the areas of agriculture, services and market access.

It is obviously the case that failure to make an early response to the November proposals as they emerge would be a signal of the inability of participants to finalise the Round before the start of US electoral activity in March next year. That in turn would unquestionably raise a very real question about the future of the Round and therefore, indeed, of the whole multilateral trading system. Certainly, we will have to look at the commitment of the G7 summit to invoke that to resolve key differences among the major developed countries if that sort of scenario starts to unfold. More optimistically, if the necessary decisions are made in November and December, a good result in the early months of 1992 is possible. So the whole thing is really very finely balanced at the moment.

Agriculture does remain the key to any successful outcome from the Round. The crucial question remains the extent to which the European Community is prepared to make commitments to reduce domestic support, border protection and export subsidies for its farm products. We have been waiting on significant movement from the European Community for the past five years. It is pleasing--and this was also referred to in Senator Loosley's question--that we saw last week a signal of greater willingness on the part of Germany to move forward on agriculture. That signal is consistent with the message that the bipartisan delegation which Dr Blewett recently led to Europe received from the Germans. However, obviously, if satisfactory progress on agriculture is to be achieved, it is crucial that all member states recognise the urgency of the situation and the importance of a good result to the world trading system as a whole.

As the negotiations enter this really quite critical final phase, we as an Australian government are taking every opportunity to exert pressure on the major participants to deliver on the various public commitments which they have made repeatedly throughout the Round in general terms to work for an enhanced multilateral trading system. I have already mentioned the bipartisan delegation led by Dr Blewett. The point that we will continue to make over coming weeks is that the time really has come for the participants to match rhetoric, which has been in ample supply over recent years, with real commitments.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. Can the Minister advise this Senate and the Australian people whether economic recovery is taking place in Australia and, if so, in what specific areas? If it is not currently taking place, when does he expect it will do so and, again, in what specific areas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-As was forecast in the Budget figuring, and as was mentioned by Senator Parer and others who participated in the Budget debate, we are looking to an improvement in activity in the economy in the second half of this financial year and a consequent improvement in employment and other matters which contribute to a better growth picture in the Australian economy as a whole. I have answered that part of this question on numerous occasions. I give the same answer and I will continue to do so. I do not know whether, off the cuff, I can give any specific identification of some particular areas of the economy in which recovery can be said to have taken place.
—-Why not? You are the industry Minister.
—-What has that to do with it?
—-I would hope you would have some damned good indications.

—-That does not mean that one should make a fool of oneself by speculating about various things. There is a forecast and I think there is an impending improvement in the housing sector. A number of industries have identified to me an improved performance in terms of demand, and reduction of stocks. Of course, amongst a variety of industries there is an increasingly improved export performance every year, capped by the current level of performance which was reflected in the current account figures published a couple of weeks ago.

ANSWER.PARA: As the honourable senator knows, at the same time inflation anticipations have been considerably dampened, interest rates have been reduced, and there are signs of enhanced competitiveness in a number of sectors of the Australian economy. The most important issue for this Government and the Parliament--people are concerned about it--is the shape in which this economy comes out of the recession. It is important that it come out in a steady way, with a predicted steady pattern of growth which takes advantage of the structural changes that have been made in the economy and the improvements in--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Such as?
—-There have been huge structural changes.
—-What structural changes?
—-Order! The question has already been asked.

—-For example, there has been a very significant shift in the export activities of this country. Last month we had an improved current account figure, in spite of the fact that one of the greatest contributors to our exports in years gone by, the wool industry, can only be described as being in extreme difficulty at the moment. Other sectors of industry have contributed to that improved performance in exports. These represent significant structural changes.
—-There is no domestic demand.

—-That is a partial factor, but it is certainly not a factor which impinges on a whole range of Australian industries. We have never had high levels of domestic demand for agricultural or mining industry products compared with the export demand which exists and has existed for a long time. If one looks at the changed pattern of top export performers from Australia--seeing that Senator Crichton-Browne is interested--one sees a very different pattern from that of five or six years ago.
—-Robe River is improving.

—-So is IBM, Glaxo Australia Pty Ltd, BHP--a whole range of companies. None of those changes are underpinned by mindless ideological commitment such as comes out of the honourable senator's rusty old think tank in Melbourne. Once again, I recommend that he talk to his father about these issues; his father understands them better than does the honourable senator.

—-Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. I noticed that he said that he expected improvement in the second half of this financial year. How does he reconcile this view about a second half improvement with a categorical statement by the Minister for Finance earlier in Question Time in the House of Representatives that economic recovery was already taking place. Again, I ask the Minister--
—-Are you telling the truth? Mr Reith didn't the other day when he quoted Senator Button.
—-I am quoting exactly what Mr Willis said. In view of Mr Willis's categorical statement today that economic recovery is already taking place, I again ask: in which specific areas?

—-I did not have the advantage of listening to Mr Willis, so I do not know whether his answer was categorical. But, assuming that he did say that economic recovery is already taking place, I agree with him--and I said that in the course of my answer to Senator Parer.
—-You said in the second half.

—-No; I said two things: I said that there were signs of economic recovery taking place in the housing industry, for example, and I said that a number of specific industries had informed me that their situation had improved considerably. For example, the chief executives of some companies in Queensland have informed me personally of that fact. As I said, there has been a continued and significant improvement in exports. These are all improvements which have taken place. No doubt Mr Willis had those in mind. My point is that we suspect the recovery in the second half of the year to be less patchy--less by sectors, by industries--than it is at present.

—-I refer the Minister for Defence to his reply to my question of 9 October on the AIDEX arms bazaar, in which he claimed that the recently revised arms export guidelines are `one of the most comprehensive and best sets of guidelines in the world'. I note that the revision of the guidelines was a response to a number of controversial approvals granted over the last two years, and I ask the Minister whether these proposals would have been approved had the new guidelines been in place at the time, namely, for the export of: firstly, Mirage fighters to Pakistan; secondly, trainer aircraft engine parts to Iraq and to Burma; thirdly, trainer aircraft or aircraft parts to Somalia; and, fourthly, military helicopters to Papua New Guinea for use on Bougainville. I also ask whether the new guidelines would have allowed the international arms smuggler Mohammed Kahan to get away scot-free after a huge arms cache he was about to send to Fiji was discovered in Sydney and whether proceedings will now be commenced against him to deter any intending arms dealers from following his example.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Let me make it quite clear that I do not accept Senator Spindler's gonzo definition of AIDEX as being an arms bazaar. While we are on that question, Senator Spindler at his news conference this morning, by acts of commission, almost implied that AIDEX was a totally Government run exhibition and not a private company. So next time Senator Spindler is on radio--using this as his latest tool to get publicity--I ask him to please make that quite clear and not mislead the public.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said in answer to Senator Durack earlier today, if it is moral to import arms, it is moral to export arms. Information on such weaponry may be received from a whole number of sources, that is, by way of magazine articles, advertising, personal contact or exhibition. The critical thing for government policy is not whether people view weapons; it is where they are exported to. That is a matter that we have had revised twice in my time as Minister for Defence because our aspiration is to make the guidelines as good as possible. I am quite happy to defend the past track record. Those guidelines are most stringent.

Senator Spindler would note from his question that now government to government sales have also been brought within the guidelines, which was a very positive step. He goes on in his question and asks me then to apply those new criteria to past exports. I am not going to answer such a hypothetical question because all due process would have been gone through--consultation with Foreign Affairs, consideration by the committee, and advice to me both from that committee and my Department. So I have no intention of breaking Standing Orders by answering such a hypothetical question.

Senator Spindler then goes on to ask me about a smuggler. Frankly, we do not grant export licences to smugglers. If Senator Spindler is interested in that subject, he should direct his question to the Minister responsible for Customs, who will no doubt deal with it appropriately. I do not want to be too harsh on Senator Spindler because he has just been allocated the defence portfolio for the Democrats. He has managed to ask me one more question than the shadow Minister has in the whole spring session, so I do not want to discourage him.

But I do make this plea to him: being a shadow spokesman either for a main party or for a minority party does involve being negative and constantly carping. I understand that; it is part of the role. But Senator Spindler should also try to play a positive role. He should try once in his tenure as the Democrats' spokesman for defence to comment positively on some defence aspects, and not be seen as anti-defence, carping, anti-American, anti-everything.

Senator Spindler did that right throughout the Gulf war. He did not have an intellectually sustainable position. He was highly embarrassed and I really felt for him in the position in which he was put. But he has been making a big thing about this. This is the first big issue he has run out as shadow Minister for defence for the Democrats and is talking about arms bazaars and the rest of it. All I say is that Senator Spindler should put the full story and not his own perverted view of that story.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am happy to oblige the Minister and to congratulate him on the government to government inclusion in the new guidelines. Here is a positive comment for him. Could I also ask whether Mohammed Kahan has been sent an invitation to the AIDEX bazaar?

—-Quite frankly, when a private company runs an exhibition in this country, it may surprise Senator Spindler to know that I do not actually pick up the telephone and say, `I want to know everyone in the world who has been invited to it'. Perhaps Senator Spindler could direct that question to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and, if he is in a good mood, he may do a visa search and tell Senator Spindler whether that person is coming; I do not know.

—-My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport. I ask about the impending establishment of a National Road Transport Commission which will administer changes to heavy vehicle registration charges. At the Special Premiers Conference in July, heads of government, with the exception of the Northern Territory, signed an agreement to establish the NRTC. This agreement required the NRTC to derive a road user charge based on full cost recovery of all fully distributed road costs from commercial vehicles. Part of the agreement, flowing from the Industry Commission report, was that the NRTC must apply for a template to break this total cost between different classes of road users, based on the weight of the vehicle and the distance travelled per year. In light of this agreement to a full cost recovery formula, can the Minister give an unequivocal guarantee that only phase one of the working group's charges will be adopted or will the second phase, to begin in July 1995, have to be introduced to achieve the full cost recovery aim?
—-The NRTC will recommend charges by March 1992 to apply no later than 1 January 1993. Full cost recovery will be phased in by 1 July 1995, and by 1 July 2000 for road trains.

—-My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. I have received a letter from a concerned medical practitioner in South Australia saying that 20 per cent of patients of a bulkbilling community health centre in Adelaide are not enrolled in Medicare and that 5 per cent of the centre's clients are Aboriginals, most of whom are not enrolled. Can the Minister confirm whether this is the case? What is the process for enrolling in Medicare and what are the consequences for patients who are not enrolled?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Senator Crowley will know that Medicare benefits are only payable for eligible persons, Australian residents, and that it is an easy matter to be enrolled. People can establish their eligibility for Medicare by completing an enrolment form and obtaining a Medicare card. I understand that it is not necessary for people enrolling in Medicare to attend at a Medicare office to complete the enrolment; they simply have to provide documentary evidence of identity and residency status and they can be enrolled.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the particular matter that Senator Crowley has raised, given the number of people enrolled in Medicare, it seems inconceivable that 20 per cent of any doctor's practice would be made up of people who do not have a Medicare number. Perhaps the figure represents the fact that 20 per cent of the centre's clients do not attend the centre with their Medicare card. In this situation a doctor can still direct bill, giving the personal particulars of the patient. Except for a very small percentage of cases, this is sufficient for the Health Insurance Commission to identify the patient and to pay the claim.

I do not know the exact significance of the claim that 5 per cent of the centre's clients are Aboriginals. It may mean to imply that the Aboriginal community constitutes a major component of the bad debts of the practice. As I say, given the ease of being enrolled in Medicare, I do not quite see why the difficulty has arisen. Nevertheless, if there are particular difficulties that the administrators of the centre have identified, they should take up the matter with the Health Insurance Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to the decision by the Federal Cabinet to agree to the introduction of pay television services which has left many unanswered questions. Why did the Cabinet have to decide right now? What was the hurry? Is it true that the main motivation for opting for the outdated satellite technology is to get the Aussat disaster off the Government's books? Is it true that the Minister is planning to legislate for a protected pay television monopoly which would bar Telecom Australia, with its more advanced fibre optics technology, from competing for pay television services? Finally, which one of the ALP's rich mates is likely to control this new Government created monopoly?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I will ignore the piece of political nonsense attached to the end of the question.
—-Give him a serve.

—-No--why disturb the quiet of the Senate. The decision on pay television is important for Australia's communications industry and the public. Despite the cries from those opposite, I suspect that it will be widely welcomed by the electorate at large. The decision will add diversity of choice for in-home entertainment and will make information and education services available to the public. It will be a catalyst in

ANSWER.PARA: the upgrading of the nation's communications infrastructure. It will provide a chance for a new high-tech industry in Australia which will provide jobs in programming, retailing and servicing of pay television. And it will create manufacturing opportunities for Australian industry with export potential. I think it is a very popular decision because it gives people more choice. The Government has set out a number of conditions for the operation of pay TV. It will be delivered via at least four channels on Aussat's satellites. An additional two Aussat channels will be made available for the further development of pay TV systems. Strict siphoning rules will ensure that important programs, including national and international sporting events, will continue to be available to free-to-air television. Foreign ownership limits will be applied to ensure that there is majority Australian ownership. At this stage, it is sensible to work these out during the sale process for the right to provide a pay TV service, as the Government did for the sale of Aussat.

Further consideration will also be given to cross-media participation, given the strong public concern about concentration of media ownership. Australian content for pay TV will be addressed by the broadcasting regulatory authority established under the proposed broadcasting services Bill and a recommendation made to government.

The licence for the multi-channel national service will also require the owner to develop a local industry package to maximise Australian industry involvement. Pay TV is also a factor in the sale of Aussat. The satellite is one of the principal options, as I have pointed out--

TALK.START.PARA: —-As Senator Kernot would know, I have pointed this out to the Senate on at least two previous occasions. It is a factor because the satellite is one of the principal options for delivering pay television services to homes. Bidders for Aussat can now factor pay TV into their bids.

—-Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In light of that answer, would the Minister agree that the Government's approach to pay TV is yet another example of--to quote yesterday's Newcastle Morning Herald--`the shambles of patronage and political favouritism that pass for media ownership regulation in Australia under this Government'?

—-That is a piece of utter nonsense. Might I just say on a personal level that that is a factor which is not a consideration and never has been a consideration so far as the Minister responsible for implementing this decision is concerned. It is probably one of the principal reasons for the aggro on the other side. I reiterate: I think this is a sensible decision which will be widely welcomed by the electorate at large.
—-Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Yesterday in my absence, Senator Boswell addressed a question concerning anti-dumping to the Minister representing me. In relation to the specific parts of the question which relate to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the answers are as follows: the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has not received any request from the Australian Customs Service or the Anti-Dumping Authority to facilitate an inspection of PRC canning arrangements in relation to this anti-dumping inquiry. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade does not generally become involved in normal value inquiries overseas as such inquiries are--
—-We can't hear a word you say when you mumble away there.
—-Senator Archer would not understand it if he did hear every word. It is all on the record and he can read it later on.

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade does not generally become involved in normal value inquiries overseas as such inquiries are usually handled by officers of the Australian Customs Service. However, the Department assists and facilitates such investigations where it can and when requested. The Department constantly monitors developments in Chinese industry; however, detailed sectoral surveys required to ascertain whether or not dumping has occurred are not undertaken by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

Under the customs legislation, the Anti-Dumping Authority is unable to base a normal value on information from a centrally planned economy. Therefore, neither Customs nor the Anti-Dumping Authority will be obtaining information from China in relation to the current inquiry into canned peaches.

The North-East Asia Analytical Unit in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is currently looking at the issue of Chinese grain production with a view to increasing sales of Australian grain in the Chinese market. This review includes determining the cost of grain production and subsidies paid to Chinese producers. That review is expected to be completed by March 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Yesterday in Question Time, Senator Knowles asked me a question as to whether there were regulatory or legislative prohibitions or barriers to operating international flights into Broome. In fact, I noted during my reply that the Leader of the Opposition continually interjected to the effect of `Yes, that is correct' and `There were'. I did say yesterday, without any specific knowledge, that I would have been surprised had that been the case and that the major barriers that were present in terms of mounting international operations were usually barriers of a commercial nature. On investigation, I have discovered that is, in fact, precisely the situation that applies to Broome Airport.
—-It is not the situation.

—-It is, in fact, the situation; I assert again. If the Leader of the Opposition once again has advice to the contrary, I would appreciate it--for the sake of the citizens of Broome--if he could advise me. The facts are that late last year a group of tourism interests from the city of Broome approached the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley, with a proposition asking whether he would support the provision of international services to the airport at Broome on a charter basis; in other words, to test the market. Mr Beazley agreed to that proposition.

ANSWER.PARA: Broome is, in fact, designated as an international airport for international airline charter operations. However, under current arrangements, customs, health and immigration clearances can only be provided on a restricted basis sufficient for those charter operations. I am sure that all members of the Opposition would agree that the very significant infrastructure that has to be laid on to clear international flights cannot simply be provided in advance of knowing whether there are going to be any customers or not. Minister Beazley did, in fact, agree for that airport to be designated as an international airport, and it is so designated for charter flights.

The Government is aware of a long term tourism and trade potential of the Kimberley region. It has already held discussions with Western Australian interests about the possibility of operating programs of charter services between Broome and Singapore. The Australian Customs Service and the Western Australian tourism and transport authorities have also been involved in these discussions. Charter services, if they can be mounted on a commercial basis, will provide a useful indicator of the potential for international services to the region. The Federal Government is prepared to do everything possible to ensure that the market is tested in that way.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Yesterday Senator Newman addressed a question to me regarding Telecom Australia's 0055 service, with a number of very detailed sections about the number of complaints that have been received and the number of services that have been transferred to the new opt-in number. I have been provided with the following response to Senator Newman's question.

ANSWER.PARA: Under the new arrangements operating since 1 October, standards for the content of recorded messages are defined in codes of practice. These standards are established by an independent telephone information services standard committee, and an arbitrator will determine whether the codes have been contravened and advise on the course of action to be taken. Such action could include either modification of the message, transferral to the opt-in 0051 closed user access service, or removal.

I am advised by Telecom that, as the new arrangements are still in the process of being implemented fully, it is still unclear how many of the services currently on 0055 will need to be transferred to the new 0051 service. However, the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley, has recently written to the chairman of Telecom expressing his concern that community views on these issues be addressed adequately and seeking an assurance that implementation of the arbitrator's rulings will be given a high priority. The Minister is currently awaiting advice from Telecom concerning implementation of these procedures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I seek leave to make a statement in relation to a matter which was raised in the adjournment debate last night.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —-During the adjournment debate in the Senate last night I counselled Senator Bishop, as she was developing an argument in relation to a question asked on 5 September by Senator Crowley of the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, that:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not proper to impute an improper motive of misleading the Senate, Senator Bishop. You might be able to say it slightly differently.
Upon Senator Bishop's suggestion to me that she was:
. . . proceeding now to show how he did mislead the Senate. . .

the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) took a point of order to the effect that Senator Bishop should be asked to withdraw her remark in accordance with my initial ruling. I then ruled as follows:

It is not proper to accuse a Minister of misleading the Senate. Senator Bishop, you may wish to say that he may have misled the Senate or inadvertently misled the Senate, but I will not permit you to say that a Minister misled the Senate.

After some cross-chamber discussion, I suggested that Senator Bishop continue her speech. Later in the debate the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) asked me to undertake some research into the matter, advise of the results and inform the Senate of whether I would wish to stand by the precedent.
In making this statement I point out, as Odgers has done in the sixth edition of Australian Senate Practice, that:
. . . it is important that any example of unparliamentary language be considered in its context.
That appears on page 217. Odgers went on to state that:
. . . some expressions may be inelegant but not necessarily objectionable.

The converse, however, also holds, namely, that in its context an expression normally not unparliamentary could be objectionable. While I accept Senator Hill's point that the word `misled' is not in itself unparliamentary, I draw attention to the context in which Senator Bishop used the word. She had indicated that the Minister had:
. . . quite deliberately set up a question from Senator Crowley with the direct objective of maligning Robe River Mining.

She then went on to say that she had taken a point of order, at the time Senator Cook rose to answer the question, as to whether the Minister was speaking as a Minister of the Crown or as a paid-up union employee. In that context, I considered that Senator Bishop's use of the word `misled' implied deliberate misleading.
I draw attention to the ruling of President Givens, quoted at page 218 of Australian Senate Practice, that it is:
. . . unparliamentary to insinuate or say that a Senator has made an untrue statement knowing it to be untrue.
I consider last night's incident to be analogous and stand by the ruling I made. I emphasise, however, that in normal circumstances I accept that the word `misled' is not in itself unparliamentary.

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--I present to the Senate the following petitioning letters, from 541 citizens, which are not in conformity with Standing Orders as they are not in the correct form:

SPEECH.PARA: The Hon. R. Hawke, M.P.,
Prime Minister,
Parliament House,
CANBERRA, A.C.T., 2600.
Dear Mr Hawke,

Croatian Australians and their many supporters are most disturbed to hear that your government has forwarded $100,000 to the Yugoslavian Red Cross despite our warnings that no money via the Yugoslavian Red Cross is reaching the victims of the war in Croatia.

You will recall that Croatian representatives informed you of this situation at a meeting at Kirribilli House on July 31. Since then hundreds of Croats have died or been injured at the hands of Serbian terrorists backed by the Yugoslav army. As you are well aware the Yugoslav Government has now admitted that the army is out of control and acting illegally.

Last week representatives of Australian Croatians spoke to several doctors working around the clock in hospitals in Zagreb. These doctors confirmed that no money had been forthcoming from the Red Cross in Belgrade to assist in the crisis. As the conflict is in Croatia and the wounded and refugees are there, not in Belgrade, we are at a loss to understand why the Australian Government donation was not sent directly via the Australian Red Cross to where it is needed in Croatia.
We strongly deplore the ill-considered action in sending funds to Belgrade despite our clear warnings.

We noted that you have also ignored our request to recall the Australian Ambassador to Yugoslavia so he can give an up to date briefing to the Government on the current situation in Croatia. We cannot accept that it is too expensive for him to fly to Australia for a week. We note you flew the former Ambassador to Ireland, Mr Brian Burke, back to Australia earlier this year to attend a court case that was not even a Federal matter!

We have also noted that you did not deem it fit to send an Australian observer to European Community peace talks although countries such as Sweden and Canada, which also have large communities of citizens of Croatian descent, did so.
