DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-On behalf of Senator Tate, I present the Government's response to the report of the Joint Statutory Committee on the National Crime Authority on Operation Ark. I seek leave to have the document incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows--

The report was tabled in the House on 18 October 1990, by the Committee Chairman, the Honourable Member for Herbert, and in the Senate on 17 October 1990 by the Deputy Chairman of the Committee, Senator Vanstone. As the Committee puts it, the tabling of this Report is pursuant to the Committee's obligation to maintain a system of accountability under Section 55(1)(b) of the National Crime Authority Act 1984. The report was accompanied by a Qualifying Statement by the Members for Gippsland and Moore, and Senators Crichton-Browne and Vanstone.

The report deals with an investigation in South Australia by the National Crime Authority (NCA). The Report makes no findings and no recommendations. While the Qualifying Statement also does not advance recommendations, it suggests that aspects of Operation Ark are relevant to the Committee's current Evaluation Inquiry and should be discussed further in that context. I also note that, in a tabling statement agreed by the Committee and tabled in both Houses on 21 February 1991, the Committee indicated that "it would neither be constructive for it to reconsider the Operation Ark case, nor to attempt further adjudication on the conflicting claims about the status of the NCA Operation Ark report at 30 June 1989". The Committee went on to indicate that it would address issues arising from changes in membership of the NCA in the context of its Evaluation Inquiry. These are matters for the Committee to decide, and do not call for a response from the Government.

The Government accepts the Joint Parliamentary Committee's Majority Report. There is concern, however, about aspects of the Qualifying Statement signed by four members of the Committee, Senator N Crichton-Browne, Mr P Filing MP, Mr P McGauran MP and Senator A Vanstone.

The Government wishes to make clear that it supports the right of members of committees to add protesting or dissenting views to committee reports. Indeed, standing order 343 of the House permits this. The Government cannot, however, approve of a procedure under which a dissenting report, without the authority of the Committee, discloses in camera evidence--as occurred in the present case.

I understand that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure has expressed the view that procedures should be put in place to avoid the disclosure of in camera evidence in dissenting reports unless authorised by the relevant committee. This view is supported by the Government.

In its report of 2 May 1989, the Senate Standing Committee on Procedure suggested certain guidelines be followed by Senators who wished to refer in a dissenting report to evidence taken in camera. It recommended inter alia:
- the Senator should advise the Committee of the evidence concerned and all reasonable efforts should be made by the Committee to reach agreement on the disclosure of the evidence for this purpose;
- witnesses involved should, if practicable, be informed of the proposed disclosure and given reasonable opportunity to object; and
- consideration should be given to disclosing the evidence in such a way as to conceal the identity of persons who gave or are referred to in evidence.
The Government observes that these recommendations were not followed in the present case.

Moreover, the debate on 13 February 1991 concerning the report by the Senate Standing Committee on Procedure also emphasised the need to limit disclosure of purely operational material to the wider public--particularly with the aim of protecting witnesses.

The Government believes it is important to maintain the confidentiality of persons who assist the Authority by way of information. The Authority's position is based on a long-standing practice it has adopted with my approval out of concern for the safety of witnesses and informants. This principle must necessarily extend to those who appear and give evidence before the Committee. If the confidentiality of those co-operating with the Committee is not upheld and respected, then there is a danger that the willingness of those who might otherwise provide information would be diminished. The Government is concerned to ensure that the reputation and the standing of committees is not diminished by unauthorised minority disclosure of information received on a confidential basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I wish to speak briefly to the Government's response to the report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority on Operation Ark. I wish to speak briefly because the response is so weak that it does not deserve much time, but there are a couple of points that require comment. The Government says that it agrees with the majority report, and then proceeds in its response to make some critical remarks clearly directed at those senators and members who chose to put in a qualifying statement.

SPEECH.PARA: It is perfectly fair for people to have views about the conduct of one or other member or senator and the manner in which that person has chosen to go about his or her business. But should people choose to make remarks, one could at least expect that they do so without misrepresenting the situation and that they tell the whole story, not just a part of it. I do not say `tell the whole story' to indicate that that is what I now wish to do. But I do want to draw attention to those areas where I believe the Government in its response has not been as frank as it should have been, has told perhaps the truth but not the whole truth and, in doing so, has given a picture other than the true picture to those who might read it.
The Government says on page 2 of its response:
The Government can not, however, approve of a procedure under which a dissenting report, without the authority of the Committee, discloses in camera evidence--as occurred in the present case.

What the Government does not say following that is that at the time that happened, the process undertaken by myself, Senator Crichton-Browne, Mr Filing and Mr McGauran was not in any way conflicting with Senate Standing Orders or guidelines. It implies that what was done then, and could not be done now, should not have been done because in some way it was in contravention of the Senate Standing Orders. I therefore think it would have been appropriate for the Government to perhaps outline a little more clearly the discussions that have been had over the use of in camera evidence in reports to this chamber.

It would have been even more colourful if the Government had chosen to make some remarks about whether chairmen of committees can disclose in camera evidence at their will or can actually say at a public hearing, `The committee has decided that this evidence has been released. Is that all right with you, Joe Bloggs?'. Joe Bloggs, who is sitting there, has given some in camera evidence to the committee in the past. He is now at a public hearing and the chairman is referring to in camera evidence he has given at previous private hearings. The chairman may say, `The committee has decided that this should be released, is that all right with you?' when the committee has not consulted the witness. That in camera evidence is then released with quite disastrous consequences.

As I understand it, the reason why the Government would not turn its mind to that type of activity was that the only time this had happened was under a Labor chairman and not that long ago. It is certainly within the memory of this Government and it is clearly embedded in the memory of any member of this Committee.

It seems that the Government is prepared to say with respect to Opposition members, `Tut, tut, you should not go about your business this way', but when one of its members, who is a chairman of the Committee, has chosen by either sheer ignorance and incompetence or design--I am not sure which--to release a whole swag of in camera evidence which had quite serious consequences which are not worth going into now, the Government chooses to remain silent. It is quite amazing. In that respect, this is a quite misleading response to that report.

The Government refers on page 2 of its response to a report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure in May 1989. It does this to try to give the impression that, at the time of this report being released and the qualifying statement being put with it, the report applied and was endorsed by the Senate. Of course it was not. As I understand it, when that report came forward, it was sent back. Why? Because former Senator Peter Baume, who is no longer in this place, asked how a committee would resolve the situation where a member or a number of minority members wanted to release some in camera evidence or wanted to put something in a majority report or in a qualifying statement and the majority said no. At that stage, no method was devised of resolving such an impasse. Consequently, as I understand it, the matter was referred back to the Committee. But it certainly was not endorsed by this chamber at that time.

Things have moved on since then and now, if one wishes to disclose in camera evidence, there is a list of things that one needs to do. I do not deny that, although I have perhaps different views from some people on the procedures that we should move to adopt in the future. The fact is that things have moved on. One would now need to advise people that one was going to release some in camera evidence and give them an opportunity to say why that should not happen. But when we read this Government response, we do not get the slightest hint that that was not the case at the time that this report was tabled. On page 3 of the response, the Government says:

. . . the debate on 13 February 1991 concerning the report by the Senate Standing Committee on Procedure also emphasised the need to limit disclosure of purely operational material to the wider public. . .

I have not gone back and pursued the Hansard of that date. No doubt someone did raise a concern about the need to limit disclosure of purely operational material. But why is this piece of information in a Government response to a committee report? What was said in the Senate on 13 February 1991 does not impact on what was said in that report at all. The report says that a member of the Senate--perhaps a couple--got up and had this particular view.

I think I can give the answer as to why the Government has chosen to refer to a debate in February this year when it is responding to a report put out in October last year. By referring to the debate in February this year the Government wants to create the impression--I think it has deliberately gone about doing this--that some of the in camera evidence revealed in the qualifying statement was somehow material that should have been kept from the public for reasons other than agreed administrative practice in this place; that is, that it was operational material that could potentially have put someone at risk in some way. Nothing could be further from the truth.

On a number of occasions I, I think Senator Crichton-Browne and no doubt someone in the other place have challenged members of the Government, in relation to this exercise that we all had hoped could be put behind us, to point to one piece of information that is other than of an administrative nature; to point to one piece of information that does contain operational material. That has not been done because it cannot be done. The only information that was revealed in that qualifying statement is information that I still believe should have been revealed. The only embarrassment is that it was not revealed to this chamber earlier. The embarrassment is that the Committee took so long to report to this Parliament on a very disastrous time during the NCA's operation in Adelaide.

The Government says also on page 3 of its response, as a sort of parting remark, that it is concerned to ensure that the reputation and the standing of committees is not diminished by unauthorised minority disclosure of information received on a confidential basis. I would like to have seen the Government add to that that it was concerned to ensure that the reputation and the standing of committees is not diminished by Government members on those committees behaving merely as the lackeys of the Executive.

We need to understand that in this place, for quite proper reasons, the Government has the majority on committees. Is the Government, therefore, to be allowed to say yea or nay to what this Parliament can be told? Individual members of committees need to be prepared to say to their own executives, `Well, tough. I think you have made a mistake and the Parliament has to know about that mistake'. If committees continue to operate as this Committee has, what will happen when a committee comes across something that the Executive has done or is responsible for having allowed to happen--some sort of scandal that this Parliament should know about? Nothing will happen. Parliament will not be told because the majority of the committee members are the lackeys of the Executive, unwilling to tackle any task that might embarrass the Executive by revealing some sort of incompetence on its part.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It used not to be like that.

—-Senator Walters interjects that it used not to be like that and--if we want to put it that way--in plenty of jurisdictions it is not like that. We all watched, with some fascination, as Ollie North gave his evidence to a United States committee on the Iran-Contra affair. Quite rightly, United States parliamentary committees got stuck into the Hart scandal. One can think of other examples in the United Kingdom and no doubt in other parliaments where parliamentary committees have not forgotten their responsibility, which is, in part, to oversee and keep a check on the Executive.

SPEECH.PARA: If members of a governing party--that is, the party from which the Executive is formed--form a majority on a committee, and those people do not see themselves as parliamentarians but rather as Executive aspirants, willing to do the bidding of their leader or relevant Minister so as to protect their own path to the Executive, one has to query very substantially whether parliamentary committees are doing their job.

I see that we have a number of schoolchildren here. No doubt they are told that this place, in part, keeps a check on the Executive. Have they considered whether they would have the courage to dob on their own--their leader would be the Prime Minister and their colleagues would form the Ministry--were they members of a party in government? That is what it amounts to.

I have not had the experience of being in government. I do not want it to be said that I look forward to the opportunity of dobbing on my own; that would be the wrong way of putting it. I face that prospect with some apprehension. But I like to think that I would have the courage to do it. I do not want to be so rude as to say that the other members of this Committee do not.

The National Crime Authority had, by one story, presented a report relating to police corruption in South Australia. We had a change of membership, with the new membership saying, `That wasn't a report'. It offered a variety of reasons why technically it had not been concluded. I do not mean to say that I accept those reasons at all. Therefore, that report was not put forward. A doctored version--a very substantially watered-down version--was then presented to the Government. This matter came to light only by virtue of the fact that the media found that there were two Operation Ark reports. Quite serious haggling, wrangling and quite extraordinary manoeuvres had gone on in the Authority to make sure the first report never went forward.

It is now an historical matter: both reports are in the hands of the South Australian Attorney. One might argue that we are in the position we would have been in had the first report been accepted, because the South Australian Attorney knows full well its contents. But of course it is not the task of this Committee simply to check that the South Australian Attorney knows what he should know. One of the tasks of this Committee is to report on the operation of the Authority. The haggling within the Authority over those two reports was a disgraceful and deplorable event, surpassed only by the unwillingness of this Committee to report as soon as it should have on that matter.

In conclusion, this response is pretty limp-wristed; it certainly does not address the point. It highlights this Government's desire to have every government member do its bidding in parliamentary committees and its desire to reduce parliamentary committees to nothing more than the yea or nay of what the Executive says--and that is a problem. It reveals a desire to not be fully frank with this chamber and those who might read this report, because it does not outline clearly the procedural situation at the time this report was tabled and the qualifying statement was put in. Nor does it properly outline the changes since then. In that respect, it is a very deceitful response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: --I wish to comment briefly on the Government's response to the report of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority on Operation Ark. I do so as a member of that Committee. I express some disappointment, as Senator Vanstone did, with the content of the Government response. It hardly warrants any further comment.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I would like to comment briefly on some matters of substance. A brief history might be useful. It was not until December 1989 that the Committee became aware of a National Crime Authority operation in South Australia codenamed Operation Ark. We became aware of that due to some media reports. We subsequently became aware that there were indeed, as Senator Vanstone has said, two reports: one prepared and authorised by the outgoing Chairman of the NCA, Mr Justice Stewart, and one authorised and officially dispatched by Mr Faris, who took over as Chairman of the NCA.

The first comment to be made is that the internal dispute in the NCA about which of the two reports was the valid one points to the need to reform the handing over procedures whenever a chairman, or in fact the administration, of the NCA changes. That aspect has been noted during the evaluation by the Committee of the work of the NCA, and it will be addressed in that report. I express confidence that, with the present Chairman and administration of the NCA, we will avoid a recurrence of such an unsatisfactory procedure.

Seeing I have had the opportunity to look at both reports, it might be useful to comment briefly on the quality of the two reports. From a cursory reading and without being able to enter into a detailed investigation of the facts that were the subject of that report, certainly, the first report prepared by Mr Le Grand, went into some detail on the subject matter of Operation Ark.

We should note that Operation Ark arose from the conduct of members of the South Australian Police Force during Operation Noah in 1989 where telephoned information, at least in 13 cases, dealing with the alleged involvement of police officers, was not passed on to the head of the South Australian Police Force. This came to light only at a later stage.

The first report deals in some detail with these cases. It names police officers. I believe that Mr Faris considered that the charges made in that report could not be sustained by the information included in it. Be that as it may, one must admit that the second report was very slight, very bland. It did not give a lot of information. It would have been of concern to me had that been the only report provided.

Under its terms of reference the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority is not entitled to review the findings of the NCA. However, that does not prevent the Committee from examining the methods by which the NCA arrives at its conclusions. If that reflects upon its ultimate findings, so be it.

On a matter of substance, I had the opportunity to look at the first report as well as at the second report. The first seven cases were investigated by the NCA and by the South Australian police, and satisfactory answers were provided. Subsequently, there were six cases left which had not been dealt with in evidence before the NCA Committee, and written questions on notice were placed before the present head of the NCA, Mr Justice Phillips, at my request. The answers have since been received. They are not being released publicly, and I agree with that course of action. It remains to be noted that, in four cases out of the six, allegations were made that police officers had actually been involved in drug trafficking or in assisting drug traffickers. The reports found that in all four cases this was not proven and that no further action was considered necessary.

It is not a reflection upon these investigations by the NCA or upon the South Australian Police Force when I say that, following evidence by the South Australian police before the Committee, I formed the view that it is not satisfactory to have charges against police officers investigated by other police officers. We now have an internal investigating agency in the South Australian Police Force. But it seems to be an incontrovertible principle that, where charges are made against members of an organisation which affect members of the community outside, such charges should not be investigated by other members of the organisation but by an independent authority.

I would confirm the position of the Australian Democrats that every State police force should be answerable to, and if necessary members of such a force should be investigated by, an independent authority established by the Government in each State. I trust that we will ultimately reach that particular position.

I refer to that part of the Government's response which refers to the release of in camera evidence in the dissenting reports by members of the Opposition who are members of the Committee. It must be of some concern to us that our present rules allow in camera evidence to be disclosed in Parliament and, therefore, to the public. The principle is that if witnesses who appear before parliamentary committees choose to give evidence in camera, they should be protected. There is a case of natural justice that such a request should be honoured but it is also a matter of practical orientation. It seems that parliamentary committees cannot expect to get worthwhile, sensitive evidence if these witnesses cannot ultimately be assured of the protection of confidentiality.

I am aware of the set of guidelines that were agreed to as put forward by the Procedure Committee. I note that in most cases every possible precaution is being taken and all possible caution and sensitivity are being exercised before such evidence is disclosed. The nub of the matter is that ultimately, although we have gone through all of these steps, such evidence may still be disclosed.

It may well be a matter of public interest which should override the private concerns of witnesses and the practical considerations of getting witnesses to appear before parliamentary committees. This is something that we will have to test as time goes by. We may never know, of course, because some witnesses may simply not be prepared to appear and, if they do appear, may withhold evidence since they cannot be assured that it will remain confidential. But it is a time for testing and I have no doubt that that issue will be revisited in this chamber.

In adopting these guidelines and safeguards it is absolutely essential that witnesses appearing before committees to give evidence in camera are advised at the beginning of the hearing that, although they have been granted an in camera hearing, such evidence may be disclosed and that they may not be in a position to stop such disclosure. From my own observation, I believe that this procedure is not always followed in committees and I wish to place it on the record that in the circumstances it is absolutely essential that this be done.

I look forward to the completion of the report by the NCA Committee on the evaluation of the workings of the NCA, which I trust will throw some light on the direction in which the NCA will be travelling from now on and will provide some evidence of the work that the Committee is carrying out in discharging its duties to supervise the workings of the NCA on behalf of both the Parliament and the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I respond to the Government response to the report of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority on Operation Ark. The Government has trivialised the report, has been offensive in its response to the minority report and has been crudely partisan in its comments.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect to the majority report, it simply notes the content of the report. In respect to the minority report, it does not seek to refute any of the facts or debate the facts. All it does is criticise the minority report for disclosing in camera evidence which was done in strict accordance with Standing Orders of the Senate.

The Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) criticises that conduct on the false basis that the dissenting report contained in camera evidence without that being disclosed and without the approval of the majority of the Committee. I accept that under the hybrid Westminster system that we have in Australia the Parliament does not have any independence in its final determinations because, sad as that might be, the government of the day is the parliament of the day.

I find it thoroughly offensive for a government to assume that, if a member of a committee seeks to express a point of view, it requires the imprimatur of the majority. There is nothing new about this notion. It has been looked at on previous occasions, in previous parliaments, including in the House of Commons, I think. I find it fundamentally obnoxious for the chief law enforcement officer in this land to assert that the committee members in the minority are unable to report their findings, their deliberations and their determinations to the Parliament without the approval of those in the majority. To the extent that the Attorney-General attended the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority and made it clear that he wanted the matter of Operation Ark brushed aside, it was inevitable that the majority of the members on the Committee would do his bidding; that is, do less than was necessary to address a very important and fundamental matter relating to Operation Ark.

I should say that, as a result of the disclosure of certain administrative matters which were given in camera--not because there was anything special, unique or secretive about them, but simply because that has been the procedure used thus far by the Committee--this chamber has referred the evidence of two members of the National Crime Authority to the Committee of Privileges on the basis that, prima facie, it would appear that two members of the National Crime Authority misled the Committee.

Presumably, that is what the Attorney-General finds offensive. Had we not tabled in camera evidence, that revelation would not have been before the Parliament and this chamber would not have been in a position to move the motion that it did. The response to that was that the Attorney-General, the first law officer of Australia, complained that the evidence had come to the notice of the chamber. Had it been done with the approval of the Authority, that evidence would have not seen the light of day.

There is a very good reason for that evidence being made available. It showed, highlighted and contrasted the fundamental difference between the anaemic and inadequate report tabled by the majority of the members of the Committee and the substance which was disclosed in the minority report. As Senator Spindler has said, the majority report accepted the claim by the then head of the NCA, Mr Faris, that the first report on Operation Ark was not a complete report. It accepted that notion in spite of the fact that Justice Stewart, Mr Le Grand and Mr Robberds had claimed to the contrary.

We were not given an opportunity to pursue that matter because Justice Stewart was denied an opportunity to appear before the Committee, as were Mr Le Grand and Mr Robberds. The three of them had a view contrary to that presented in the majority report, but the majority of members on the Committee, notwithstanding the pleadings of myself and others, refused to take their evidence. The result was that when the majority and the minority reports were tabled Justice Stewart wrote to the Committee expressing some offence at the inadequacy of the findings and disputing matters of fact portrayed in the majority report. In a comprehensive letter, he dissected the majority report and exposed it for what it was.

As a result, the majority of members on the Committee felt sufficiently chastened, embarrassed and obliged to call Justice Stewart. For the time being I am not in a position to disclose what he had to say or the pleadings of those in the majority as to what they should do to correct the wrong. If my memory serves me correctly, Justice Stewart, when asked by me whether he would be unhappy about any of his evidence being made public, said, `Absolutely not'; he had nothing to hide. Thus far we have not heard from Mr Le Grand or Mr Robberds. It is my judgment that the majority of the members of the Committee have now sneakily come to the conclusion that there was a fundamental flaw in the majority report and that there was a fundamental failure on behalf of the Committee in not calling those witnesses.

Another reason for writing it is to help develop what I hope will become a tradition in Australia of enhancing the importance of constructive debate on competition policy and law for this country.
