The document read as follows--
A Revival for Trade Practices Law &Competition Policy
Observations of R Baxt
Introduction

The Annual Report for 1990-91 is the fourth Annual Report which I have been involved in with the Commission although I will not be a signatory to it as my term will have ended on 30 June 1991. I would like to thank my colleagues Brian Johns, Allan Asher, and Hank Spier, and the incoming Chairman Professor Allan Fels, for giving me the opportunity to have this chapter included in the Annual Report.

I have been influenced to write this partly because of the precedent set by the first Chairman of the Trade Practices Commission, Mr Ron Bannerman. Another reason for writing it is to help develop what I hope will become a tradition in Australia of enhancing the importance of constructive debate on competition policy and law for this country.

Ron Bannerman's 17 years as Chairman of the Trade Practices Commission, or Commissioner of Restrictive Trade Practices, were outstanding years in setting up the framework of administration of this important piece of legislation. His style of administration was very different to that of my predecessor, Bob McComas who brought considerable strength from his background as a leading commercial lawyer to the administration of the Act. Whilst my style has been quite different again from that of Bob McComas, I have benefited enormously from the framework which he and Ron Bannerman have developed and strengthened.

It has been a great privilege to serve as the Chairman of this important body. In leaving it in reasonably good shape (although inadequately resourced) I wish it and the Government well for its continued success as the champion and watchdog of Australian competition and consumer protection law. I just hope that some at least of the initiatives which have been developed during my term will be advanced further and strengthened wherever possible.
The Culture of Compliance

In this report I highlight some of the features of the three and a quarter years during which I chaired this Commission. I will also be pointing to the future in relation not only to the administration of this law but how Governments, Federal, State, and Territory might better ensure that the citizens of Australia are better protected (where that protection is necessary), from the excesses that may occur if anti competitive and unfair practices are allowed to go unchecked, especially in an environment of deregulation.

The business environment of the 1980s, especially the latter part of the 1980s, have been influenced by two very significant developments inter alia. In the first place we have seen the remarkable feature of a Labor Government taking up the mantle and becoming in fact the champion of micro economic reform and deregulation. Many within the Labor Government, as well as outside it, were surprised and perhaps disappointed that such a vigorous program of deregulation has been championed by a political party which may well have been seen in the past as being less inclined to allow the market to be the `regulator' of the business environment. Some of the implications of this development for competition policy and law are considered in this chapter.

The second major feature has been the evolvement of a political and business environment in which greed has been seen as a key feature. A cry of the late 1980s and early 1990s, both in the political and business environment, has been the need to make Australian businesses and those who run and advise Australian businesses more accountable for some of the excesses that have occurred in the marketplace during the 1980s. Whilst these cries have been directed primarily at excesses which are outside the area of Trade Practices Law (at least that would be the perception from the public's viewpoint), it is clear as a result of a number of cases that the Trade Practices Commission has run during this period, that many excesses have also occurred in the area of competition and consumer protection law. Indeed, our major court successes have been against some of the most reputable companies in the land rather than the entrepreneurial ones.

Because Trade Practices law relies on civil remedies and penalties (with some criminal type penalties in the area of Consumer Protection), there may have been a different emphasis placed by the business community on the need for businesses and persons involved in managing these businesses to comply with the legislation. The following passage from the judgment of French J. in the case of TPC v CSR Ltd (1991) ATPR 41-076 epitomises some of the frustrations that confront regulators such as the Trade Practices Commission in dealing with major companies in this country and their reaction to the need to comply with Trade Practices law.
Recognising some of the difficulties faced by the management of the company when it found itself facing competition in an area where previously non existed, the judge added these chilling comments:

"There was little convincing evidence of a corporate culture seriously committed to the need to comply with the requirements of the Act. The compliance program as indicated by the evidence appeared desultory and in need of reinforcement. No indication of any corrective measures or revitalisation of that program was offered. The corporate culture was, I think, reflected in CSR's dealings with the Commission and the conduct of this litigation. It is to its credit that it has withdrawn its defences and submitted to injunctions restraining further contravention. However that withdrawal and submission came nearly two years after proceedings were instituted and followed a period of protracted stonewalling in CSR's dealings with the Commission. I have no doubt that the preparation of the case by the Commission has consumed an enormous amount of time and financial resources. CSR's conduct in its dealings with the Commission and in relation to these proceedings, when viewed in the light of the admissions it now makes, is an aggravating factor." ((1991) ATPR at pp 52-155-52, 156)

I include these comments early in this overview chapter because it is my view that there has been a commonly held belief abroad in the business and general community that perhaps Trade Practices law is `second class' economic law that needs only a modicum of attention from sectors of the business community. Low penalties (which are discussed briefly below) play a significant part in this scenario. The resources that have been provided to the agency which administers the law, and the Government departments which are responsible for developing policy in relation to this area of the law have not received high priority--this is not seen as a vote winner. If we are to have a successful implementation of competition policy in this country, which is the matter I want to turn to shortly in this review, then that attitude must change and change very quickly.

Before turning to the question of the development of a competition policy and the need for resources to ensure that such a development occurs, let me say that during my term as Chairman the Commission has been generally impressed by the changing attitude of many corporations to their obligations under the law. The successes of the Commission in a number of cases in 1990, such as TPC v Sony (Australia) Pty Ltd (1990) ATPR 41-053 and TPC v Carlton United Breweries Ltd and Ors (1990) ATPR 41-037, the CSR case referred to earlier has led to the creation of many more compliance programs than has previously been the case. One such program which was developed during 1991 and which I feel particularly proud of is the Metal Trades Industry Association and the Commission joint program launched by the Attorney General Mr Michael Duffy on 18 March 1991. That program has been `sold' to a large number of companies and one suspects that it will be the forerunner of many other similar programs to be adopted by corporations throughout the land. Compliance is important and will be a very significant factor in persuading the courts to provide lower penalties.
Resources for the Commission and the development of competition policy

When I became Chairman of the Trade Practices Commission the thing that struck me most after two or three weeks was the fact that the Commission's budget had not been increased in line with the inflationary and other indexes against which one measured the Commission's performance. It had certainly not reflected the increase of its responsibilities. I and my colleagues on the Trade Practices Commission conducted a vigorous campaign to increase the budget of the Commission in 1988. This received considerable support not only from members of all political parties, but from the community at large. Interested commentators almost without exception strongly supported this push. The increase in our workloads during that year, together with new work that was being generated as a result of micro economic reform, led to the Government giving the Commission a useful increase in its resource base during 1989. Recognition was also given to the increased workload of the Commission in the area of mergers and other anti-competitive practices. But it has been disappointing to me that the Government has not appreciated in any constructive way that micro economic reform has and will impact on the work of the Commission. The call by the Prime Minister and other Ministers for competition to be at the core of our revitalised and deregulated services industries, means the Commission needs a greater resource base; for as Australian governments remove the protection previously provided by the regulatory agencies, the framework being dismantled, relying on competition to deliver the bene-fits of a market approach, the governments must recognise that it is the Commission which will have to ensure that the competitive process works.

The business and economic environment in which the Commission has to carry out its work as this policy is enhanced have been well encapsulated by the Prime Minister in his 12 March 1991 statement in delivering his speech "Building a competitive Australia". Let me repeat these words:

"We will press ahead with further reform, to increase competition and efficiency within Australia. For the consumer, competition means lower prices and a broader range of better quality goods and services; for producers it provides the spur to better performance--at home and abroad. We want to see the whole domestic economy opened up to this kind of positive structural change. . . . .

The Trade Practices Act is our principal legislative weapon to ensure that consumers get the best deal from competition. But there are many areas of the Australian economy today that are immune from that Act; some Commonwealth enterprises, State public sector businesses, and significant areas of the private sector, including the professions.
This patchwork coverage reflects historical and constitutional factors, not economic efficiency; it is another important instance of the way we operate as six economies rather than one.
The benefits for the consumer of expanding the scope of the Trade Practices Act could be immense: potentially lower professional fees, cheaper road and rail fares, cheaper electricity."

The scenario which the Prime Minister was describing as one that he would like to see further develop was already partly in place at that time. There had been significant micro economic reform and deregulation in the telecommunications area, banking and finance, the civil aviation area, the waterfront and in the rural sector. The Commission was given modest increases in its resource vote in relation to the waterfront and in general terms but not in the other areas. Indeed the increase was and remains insufficient if the Commission is to undertake the type of work that it adopted during my three and a quarter years and if it is to provide the kind of general overseeing role which the Prime Minister clearly identifies as essential in the quotation set out above.

The Commission can take one of two roles, it seems to me, in dealing with rapid change that is occurring in our economic environment. It can sit back and await the occurrence of breaches of the law and then react to those breaches as a policeman might. It can be a very strict enforcer of the law. Or it can take a proactive approach and seek to educate the community; it can seek to ensure that there is a better understanding of the competitive environment--this will not only reduce the overall litigation work of the Commission, in the short and long term, but it will also ensure that the Government's wishes in making Australia a more competitive economy come to fruition more quickly.

The concept of a competitive Australia as enunciated by Prime Minister Hawke on 12 March 1991 built on a series of earlier statements made by him and other Ministers about the importance of competition in Australian industry. Yet, regrettably, in my view, there had been little appreciation by Government Ministers about how competition can really be made to work in the absence of an effective policeman or regulator and in the absence of appropriate law. In the area of telecommunications the Government had chosen to give Austel very considerable regulatory powers to ensure that there was no misuse of market power and other unfair practices (inter alia). It chose not to subject the bulk of this industry to the operation of trade practices law. In other areas of micro economic reform (e.g. civil domestic aviation and the financial sectors for example) the Trade Practices Commission using the Trade Practices Act is expected to be the most appropriate way to ensure that the wishes of the Government are fulfilled. If the Commission is to undertake these tasks in an appropriate fashion it must be provided with a better resource base. When deregulation occurs the `protection' that has previously been afforded the consumer through a series of regulations and legislation administered by specific bodies, is generally left to the operation of the market. The Commission, as the body responsible for the administration of the Trade Practices Act, is the only body most consumers can turn to to ensure that they receive the appropriate protection in that environment if there are unfair practices or anti-competitive behaviour or if the market does not work. One can contrast the type of approach the Government has adopted towards the Trade Practices Commission with its very generous funding of both Austel and the Australian Securities Commission. In my view the Commission should be treated no differently to those bodies, although allowance would clearly have to be made for the fact that it had been in existence for some time.

But the question of resources is not simply one of the resources to be voted to the Trade Practices Commission. They are by all accounts inadequate if it is to fulfil its obligations of being the guardian of competition and the consumer.
Competition Policy and Micro Economic Reform--Some Problems

The question of resources also relates to the kind of resources the Government is prepared to provide generally to an examination of the importance of competition policy, and how that policy links in to the development of its micro-economic reform agenda. We have not seen, with respect, the Government tackle the issue of the effectiveness of competition policy and law (in the context of the Trade Practices Act) when it has generally dealt with micro economic reform. This was dealt with only partially and unsatisfactorily by the Government when it looked at the question of Telecommunications. It did not allow an open debate on this issue, the whole question being debated in the press through leaked Cabinet documents and submissions.

Issues of competition policy were poorly handled by the Government when it announced airline deregulation in 1987. The granting of 30 year leases to the two airlines in the hope that the Trade Practices Act would provide adequate protection to new players has been roundly criticised by all and sundry. Nor has the issue been dealt with except in very vague and general terms in relation to the waterfront--although the government is to be congratulated for ensuring that specific funds were voted to the Commission to undertake this work.

Another example of where competition policy has not been thought through is in the area of bank mergers and "alliances". Whilst the banks are subject to the merger provisions of the Trade Practices Act, they are also subject to the fiat of the Treasurer. In disallowing the ANZ/National Mutual merger the Treasurer of the day, Paul Keating, announced that the merger would not proceed because it was not in the national interest, and because it would lead to a substantial lessening of competition. The test under the Trade Practices Act is dominance, not a substantial lessening of competition. Recently the new Treasurer, Mr Kerin, recognised that this was an issue that needed to be addressed and addressed very quickly in giving his "blessing" to the Westpac-AMP alliance.

Perhaps the most graphic illustration of the lack of a coherent policy on competition law has been the rather strange attitude of the government towards the media. The government established cross media rules which have in my view no cohesion in the "regulation" of mergers or other anti competitive arrangements. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is responsible for television and radio with very restricted powers on dealing with acquisitions, the Trade Practices Act being the relevant legislation to deal with print mergers. The Trade Practices Act is the relevant legislation when other anti competitive arrangements involving all media are involved as was shown to be the case in September 1990 when there were concerns about plans to restructure the Channel 10 network. The announced need for retrospective legislation to deal with issues of control and influence in the media shows a lack of clear policy on the part of the government in its evaluation of this highly sensitive industry. The attitude of "lets fix it up" afterwards is both irresponsible and evidence of a lack of will to tackle this vital area responsibly. Of course the overriding power of the Treasurer to block foreign investment in this and other industry is another issue which is in need of urgent review.

The development of a policy on competition policy is vital as the exciting initiatives taken by the Prime Minister on our federal structure opens up the possibility of the Trade Practices Act becoming far more relevant than it has ever been. Will it be effective in being translated into these virgin areas or do we need a new Act to cope with new problems such as the "regulation" of natural monopolies"? These are but some of the questions which need to be addressed.

The assertion by the government that it was in command of competition policy and the legislation which embodies this policy has not been evidenced by its attention to the needs of the Trade Practices Commission. Despite the fact that I advised the then Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen in August 1988 that we would need a new Deputy Chairman from early 1989 (Bill Coad was seeking and did obtain another appointment in the Attorney-General's portfolio by December 1988), the current Deputy Chairman Brian Johns was not on deck until September 1989. For eight months, during which the work load of the Commission increased in intensity and importance, Allan Asher and I were left to run the Commission when Brian Johns was ready and waiting to join it. I had advised the Department that he was the man for the job, in February 1989. A government committed to this area would have answered this plea more urgently.

When my successor Allan Fels was appointed (and it was clear he would be my successor as early as the beginning of June 1991) there was apparently no urgency seen in ensuring that he would be able to become a full time chairman (as is required by the Act) as he was left as Chairperson of the Prices Surveillance Authority for the whole of July and early August (at least). Again it is important to impress the need for a full time commitment to the work of the Commission.

Despite the fact that I advised the Attorney-General and the Department as early as July 1990 about the need for lawyers to be appointed as Associate Commissioners, and gave him and the Department the names of a number of people who could be approached to fill this important role, as at the time of writing no lawyers have been appointed 14 months after. I can think of fewer better examples of a lack of commitment to this area than the failure on the part of the government to ensure that the Commission is able to call on a full complement of willing and able commissioners and associated commissioners. The Attorney-General and the Department must give more active and urgent attention to these needs.

At present competition law is administered by the Attorney-General's Department. Paul Keating, when Treasurer, had suggested (in late 1990) that a ministry of Competition Policy or similar portfolio might be created to oversee the various approaches that were being taken to the development of competition policy. I believe that the development of a specialist ministry or position is the right way to go. I am not sure whether I would agree with the establishment of a Competition Ministry as such, but I believe that by allowing trade practices and competition policies to be relegated to the position it previously occupies--a very minor part of the Attorney-General's portfolio, the Government is making a serious error of judgement. The very small number of people in Attorney-General's Department who are responsible for this area work extremely hard at trying to keep abreast of the important developments. But frankly, just as I think that our courts are inadequately resourced to deal with the handling of competition cases and issues, so I believe the Attorney-General's Department and the office of the Minister, (and indeed the Trade Practices Commission itself), are inadequately resourced to deal with this increasingly important area of government.

Australia needs to employ either in full time positions or on contract more people with appropriate economic and business training to deal with this area of work. More importantly there has to be a willingness and ability to look at competition policy in the context of its linkage to the other aspects of Government policy to ensure they will achieve appropriate results. The Attorney-General's Department has, in my respectful view, been far too reactive to Government initiatives; and often the reaction is too slow, and regrettably unimaginative. The Attorney-General, Michael Duffy, who has been a very progressive and active Minister in a number of other areas, needs the time to devote to developing his and the Government's thinking in this area--he should be allowed to take a leadership role in this vital area. Regrettably the work load that is imposed on him (and other Government Ministers) is too great to enable more than passing attention to be given to this important area. The splitting of competition policy and consumer protection policy also reflects poorly in my view, on the importance of these two areas to be seen as flip sides of the same coin.

Perhaps a better solution would be to move this area of economic law to a new economics based Ministry such as Business and Consumer Affairs (such a Ministry was very effectively administered with the help of people like Tony Hartnell in this late 1970s). Whatever solution is chosen, and this is of equal importance, the Government should involve the Trade Practices Commission at the policy development stages as well as actively canvassing community views early in developing policy.

The courts are also inadequately resourced--there are not enough Federal judges, they are grossly under-paid in my view, and they do not have the back up resources that are necessary to enable them to deal with these matters effectively. Trade practices and competition law issues throw up difficult economic questions that need to be addressed by courts which have the necessary economic and other background to handle them. Whilst there are exceptions to this general proposition I suspect that many of our judges believe themselves not to be adequately trained in economics to handle this area. The Griffiths Committee in its report "Inquiry into mergers, takeovers and monopolies" delivered in May 1989 recommended a greater use of the specialist Trade Practices Tribunal to deal with such issues. There is no reason why judges, politicians, regulators and professionals should not receive appropriate training in economics and law to make them more able to deal with this area. There is no shame in admitting that we need extra education, and resources, to enable us to handle these matters adequately and in a way that will achieve appropriate results. In the USA (and Canada) such training is a feature of their judicial and professional make-up for some years.

Furthermore even if Government voted the resources to the Commission, to the courts and to the bureaucracy, it needs to recognise the need for flexibility to allow the Government sector to compete effectively with the private sector and hiring specialists to deal with the problem areas. It is in litigation that the Commission suffered most. It was subject to out-dated rules which say that the TPC (and other regulatory agencies are in the same boat) cannot pay senior counsel or other experts more than $2,500 a day to act for us. This penalises the Commission (and thus the community) in competing against our opponents. Whilst there are many counsel and experts in our capital cities who are prepared to undertake work for the Commission at these very much below market value fees, the Commission had been finding it increasingly more difficult to persuade these persons to take on all our cases or to act as experts. This is especially so where the cases are long and they are asked to sacrifice quite significant sums of money (in many cases counsel are being paid less than half the market rate) in competing against the lawyers representing the largest corporations in the land. If the Commonwealth wants effective regulation of business practices whether they be in trade practices, corporate law, or other areas where they are fighting companies which are very large, very powerful and very rich, then it is going to have to think very differently about the resources that it makes available to the regulatory bodies to ensure they can have the lawyers and other experts of their choice in doing battle.

This general direction on policy and resources is most regrettable. It means competition policy and the law upon which it is built and which is so much part of the Prime Minister's policy in this area is being allowed to "sail" along without a rudder--indeed some have suggested that it suits the government to give it this low profile. Whilst I am not as cynical I regret that during my three and a quarter years I was often disappointed at the very low priority given to this area of government responsibility.
The Administration of the Law

There have been many significant developments and events which deserve some highlighting in an overview chapter of this kind. These successes and developments reflect not only on my ability to use the resources available to me to achieve a successful administration of the Act, but more importantly reflects on the achievement of the staff of the Commission and the trade practices cell of the Australian Government Solicitor's office attached to the Commission. Again I wish to thank all my colleagues at the Commission, the Department and the Ministry during the three and a quarter years.
Mergers

I was concerned at the apparent inability or unwillingness of the Commission to tackle some of the mergers which on the surface at least, seemed prime candidates for the authorisation route or court challenge. Bill Coad, Deputy Chairman of the Commission at the time, was concerned that the practice of the Commission in entering into private arrangements with companies which were engaged in takeover activity, may have gone too far. The May 1988 Objectives and Priorities paper announced a new approach to the consideration of mergers and as a direct result we have seen a number of successful court action and authorisation. Elsewhere in the pages of this report readers will find a discussion of the Full Federal Court's decision in Arnotts, and the decision of Burchett J. in ACI-Smorgons. Australia Meat Holdings and the Daily News cases have been discussed in earlier annual reports. The successful authorisation decisions in Fletcher Challenge joint venture (discussed in 1988-1989 report have now been complemented by the decision of the Commission in ACI-Smorgons which is discussed in Chapter . . . of this Report.

Whilst there remains a reluctance on the part of some members of the business community to use the authorisation process, I believe that the speed and flexibility of the process as illustrated by the ACI-Smorgons matter should encourage greater use of this process. If the suggestion by Douglas Williamson QC to allow authorisations to be dealt with directly by the Trade Practices Tribunal (with the Commission acting as amicus curiae) is taken on board this will encourage even greater use of this procedure. But time constraints will need to be imposed on the Tribunal if we are not to destroy the utility of the authorisation process.

I do not favour a return to the substantially lessening of competition test as I believe the dominance test is viable. But it is necessary in my view to reintroduce a limited form of pre-notification and sensitive industries deserve a different treatment. But before turning to this question I want to say a little more about the court processes.

The Commission has been reluctant to go to the courts because the cases take a long time, cost a great deal, and do not necessarily result in the success that the Commission believes should come its way. The Australia Meat Holdings case is a classic example of extraordinary delays in reaching a final result. I do not wish to comment on why these delays have occurred. Certainly Mr Justice Wilcox, the judge who heard the original application by the Commission to enjoin the merger, as well as being the judge deciding the final case, expressed some concern at the length of time for the divestiture to be effected. He suggested that he should perhaps have granted an injunction when it was sought initially, rather than allow the merger to take place and then let the matter proceed to divestiture had he known that the matter was going to take so long.

The resources of the courts are probably inadequate to deal with the type of economic legislation that we have to administer under the Trade Practices Act. The Commission has been critical of the fact that the courts have had some difficulty in coming to grips with the interpretation of the economically oriented provisions of the Trade Practices Act. Certainly the court cases that the Commission has run have been too slow. At times the Commission has been dissatisfied with the procedures that are in place to achieve a speedy result in the context of a practice or arrangement that needs to be evaluated. The Arnotts/Nabisco case took over nine months--surely this was too long for any merger matter to be evaluated in the courts. The Australia Meat Holdings case, although it took a relatively short period of time in the hearing phase--three months from the start of the case to the decision--then took a further two years to be finally resolved through the divestiture of the acquisition held to breach the Act.

With the Australia Meat Holdings case one can perhaps level blame for the delays on both the TPC's quite unreasonable patience, and what I would regard as delaying tactics by the defendants. In Arnotts, the tactics used by the defendant's counsel were not always vigorously opposed or adequately countered by the TPC's own counsel; certainly the trial court was not strict enough in conducting the case. The Full Court's criticism of the trial is quite appropriate in my view:

"We recognise the burden of presenting a complex case such as this. The parties were represented at the trial by experienced counsel. None the less, we regard the situation which we have described as unacceptable. Neither the Court nor the litigants should have to contend with the constraints imposed by unnecessarily wide confidentiality orders. Neither should they be burdened with the consequences of a mountain of seemingly unnecessary evidence. We have no doubt that, with even reasonable attention on both sides to the relevance and utility of the questions being asked and the documents being tendered, the trial could have been completed in much less time than it actually took and, consequentially, with much less cost to the parties.

There appears to be an assumption abroad today about commercial litigation: that, when big issues are at stake, there must inevitably be a long complicated hearing. This assumption must be discarded. No matter how much is at stake, in dollar terms, there is no justification of irrelevant or unuseful evidence. Moreover, it is in the interests of the parties to analyse properly the cases which they wish to make and to restrict themselves to helpful material; and not only because of savings in costs. The devotion of excessive attention to peripheral matters, rather than the main issues, causes the parties to lose sight of the real issues and to devote insufficient attention to them. The result may be to leave the Court with insufficient or unsatisfactory material upon principal factual issues. The essence of counsel's function is the identification of, and concentration upon, the critical issues in the case." (1990 ATPR at 51,782.)

The Nabisco business is now to be "divested". But the length of time which has passed since the "acquisition" by Arnotts means that Arnotts probably has achieved much of what it wanted to achieve by the acquisition. One wonders what is left of the Nabisco lines which can be usefully purchased and utilised by another firm as a competitive pressure to the efficient and dominant Arnotts machine.

The dominance test may well prove to be highly embarrassing for the Government in some of the deregulated industries where, by virtue of the granting of significant power to incumbent players, a merger or takeover involving a third entrant or player could not be stopped. I refer in particular to the airline industry where, because of the significant power held by both Ansett and Australian, any attempt by either of those companies to acquire Compass (the only true entrant in the deregulated environment to date) or if the reverse were to occur as has recently been signalled (namely the acquisition of Australian by Compass), could probably not be stopped under the terms of s50 of the Act. Neither company by acquiring Compass' small but growing share of the Australian market would be said to have achieved dominance; and similarly by virtue of the strength of the two major players, Compass' acquisition of Australian would also not breach the merger provisions.

A different issue would, of course, arise if we were dealing with the telecommunications industry; but had both Telecom and OTC been allowed to operate in the market, rather than creating the giant Megacom, then perhaps any takeover by either OTC or Telecom of a third player might not have resulted in dominance either.

There could be similar problems facing Government if deregulation occurs in the energy sectors, and where some of our State Governments operate monopolies, e.g, transport etc.: or where duopolies or oligopolies may exist and where a new player could be easily "knocked off" without breaching the dominance provisions of the Trade Practices Act.
Pre notification

There is a growing concern that the absence of a pre-notification system (no mergers have to be advised to the Commission as a matter of course in contrast to the position in the United States, Canada, Europe and until recently New Zealand) we need a tougher test. This has also been helped by the vigorous debate about the media and the banking and financial sector (inter alia).

Whilst I was Chairman the Commission had suggested to the Griffiths Committee, a suggestion it repeated elsewhere, that whilst the Commission would not formally welcome the return to the substantial lessening of competition test, it would support the reviewing of certain mergers in the sensitive industries through a formal process not dissimilar to the authorisation test. Under this proposal the Commission would have the onus (not the parties as is the current position in the authorisation area) to show that the merger should not proceed where a net public detriment would likely be produced by the merger--in other words despite some of the benefits that might be produced by the merger, the public would be worse off if the merger were allowed to go ahead. Clearly only large mergers would be pushed through this particular process--it would be an intolerable burden if the Commission had to deal with all of the mergers in the sensitive industries in that way.

The industries that I would nominate as sensitive include the media (where a similar approach is adopted in the United Kingdom), the banking and financial sector (where the Treasurer, Mr Kerin, has recently indicated that the Government needs to reassess competition policy in the light of developments in that industry), probably the petroleum area (where there is concern that competition is not as effective as it might be), and possibly in the area of food. Other industries could be added to the list if the Government felt that the area was so sensitive as to warrant such a classification. I would suggest that the deregulated industries would be strong candidates for nomination in the sensitive areas category--telecommunications, television if pay TV is introduced, and perhaps the rural sector.

Treasury already engages in some evaluation of mergers in the financial sector and in other areas where it has responsibility (in respect of foreign investment or otherwise). The problem with a Treasury evaluation is that it is not public. The authorisation process engaged in by the Trade Practices Commission is both public and subject to a tight time constraint (45 days) which requires the Commission to ensure a speedy resolution.
Misuse of Market Power

The less than satisfactory interpretation of s.46 by the Full Federal Court in Queensland Wire Pty Ltd v BHP Ltd ((1988) ATPR 40-841) led me to believe that it was essential for the Commission to seek the right to intervene in High Court appeal. Our "Claytons" intervention in that case is well recorded in the history of the law. The Background Paper produced by the Commission on the interpretation of s.46 has been a notable contribution to the business and legal communities. The Commission has also successfully litigated matters involving s.46. The landmark determinations on penalty in TPC v CUB &Others ((1990) ATPR 41-037) and TPC v CSR Ltd ((1991) ATPR 41-076) have paved the way for a stronger compliance culture in Australia but one which is perhaps still in need of enhancing. Our (as yet undetermined) intervention in the Matilda Oil Case (O'Keefe Nominees Pty Ltd v BP Pty Ltd ((1990) ATPR 41-057) may signal some important developments for the future I have been disappointed at the lack of action on the part of government to respond to the unsatisfactory position faced by the TPC under S.163A where it seeks the right to intervene.

As signalled in the Background Paper there are still major problems facing small business in relation to the operation of s.46. The matters cannot be addressed properly or appropriately by amending s.52A as had been suggested as an option by the Commission to the Small Business Inquiry (the Beddall Committee) a more fundamental problem faces that sector. Also there are issues which arise from de-regulation and the utility of s.46 to deal with these problems. Before I completed my term I forwarded to the Attorney-General and the Minister for Small Business a Commission Report on the possible extension of s.52A.

Mr Lionel Bowen the then Attorney-General in introducing amendments of s.46 in 1986 (when the threshold for the section was lowered considerably) indicated that he believed that individuals should be the recipients of some protection as a result of the changed language. He noted:

"The effective provision controlling misuse of market power is most important to ensure that small businesses are given a measure of protection from the predatory actions of powerful competitors. Unfortunately, s.46 as presently drafted has proved of quite limited effectiveness in achieving that result, principally because the section applies only to monopolists or those with overwhelming dominance. Even in those cases, it has been extremely difficult for a plaintiff to establish the requisite predatory purpose on the part of the defendant corporation." (Emphasis added)
The Second Reading Speech (paragraph 49) after describing the various ways in which the conduct covered by s.46 may be "caught" states:

"[The corporation's] market power gives it leverage which it is able to exploit and this power is deployed so as to `take advantage of' the relative weakness of other participants or potential participants in the market.

These words at least indicate that the section is aimed at behaviour that might impact on individuals. However, paragraph 48 of the same document indicates that the draftsman is mainly concerned about the way in which competition may be impaired in the market for those are the words directly used.

There is an inconsistency between providing protection for single competitors as against the competitive process. The latter phrase is at the heart of the High Court decision in the Queensland Wire case. This "tension" in the language needs to be addressed quickly by Parliament to ensure that the inconsistency that might be generated in interpreting the section is eradicated.

Purpose is a difficult matter to prove (as noted by Lionel Bowen); although s.46(7) was added to make the task for the Commission (and other persons) easier in establishing--purpose it will still be an extraordinarily difficult matter to establish. I return to this question later.
Remedies and s.46

It is in the context of the remedies that the section creates greatest problems in my view. There is an inadequate range of remedies available to the court in dealing with misuse of market power, especially if engaged in by monopolists. It is true that the section is not aimed at monopolists any longer (see the Second Reading Speech of Lionel Bowen in introducing the 1986 amendments). But what if the misuse of market power is by monopolists, or arises in a situation which can be described as a shared monopoly (where for example duopolists or oligopolists--and there are many of these in industries in Australia--choose to act together!)? Whilst an injunction issued by the court may deal with the particular matter that led to the particular breach, it does not go to the heart of the matter. As has been noted by the leading American commentators on antitrust law Professors Areeda and Turner in their classic work Antitrust Law:

"To the extent that society reprehends monopoly profit [and the misuse of monopoly power] it should attack the existence of the power rather than its exercise--as we have recommended for persistent monopoly." (Areeda and Turner, Antitrust Law, para 710.)

That particular approach is one that is consistent with the language of the US courts, commencing with the classic decision in the Standard Oil case (Standard Oil Co v US 221 US 1 (1911)), and recognised as being the appropriate remedy (if necessary) by Justice Wyzasnski in the case of US v United Shoe Machinery Corporation (110 F Supplementary 295, 342 (1953)).

The US court refused to order divestiture in the decision of Alcoa (US) v Aluminium Company 148 F 2d 416 (2d Cir 1945)). In that case Judge Hand made a finding against Alcoa but when the case went back to the court for the order to be made, Judge Knox refused to order a break up of Alcoa which had been sought by the Government although certain shareholdings by Alcoa in Canadian companies were ordered to be divested.

There are cases in which courts have ordered divestiture--for example the movie industry and in particular the ownership of movie houses has been the subject of some interesting decisions--see for example US v Griffiths (334 US 100 (1948)).
Divestiture for Australia

The power of divestiture which is present in the US law and which is regarded as central to the administration of their antitrust laws has rarely been used, as students of American antitrust law continue to remind us. Similarly, it has rarely been used in other jurisdictions where it is available--in Canada and Europe. But the fact that it is available and can be used by the court in the appropriate circumstances, and has not been withdrawn despite pleas that it is too draconian and remains a telling factor in evaluating the appropriateness of US antitrust law. Indeed judges will rarely ever want to impose such a drastic remedy as divestiture if one means by that the breaking up of a corporation.

But "divestiture" as I use the term can take a number of different forms--for example requiring a company to give up its shares in a related corporation (as Knox J ordered in the Alcoa case in relation to Alcoa and its holding in the Canadian companies); or to give up part of its distribution network (as was ordered in the cinema cases in the United States--e.g. Griffiths).

There are situations where unless the court is given power to rewrite the particular arrangements which are the basis of the power that is the "springboard" from which the misuse is "generated", we will be unable to bring about effective competition. Let me give you an example which is unlikely to go to the courts in this form but which could, in a different scenario, have led to a significant amount of embarrassment to our current Government. When the Government decided to deregulate civil aviation in 1987 it decided that Ansett and Australian, both of which had devoted considerable resources to this industry (and had been significantly protected from competition by the two airline policy) should be given long term leases (30 years in effect) over the major terminals in the capital cities. Recognising that new entrants would have to be given some opportunity to enter the market, the Government at the same time "required" the two airlines to provide two gates in each of the cities of Melbourne and Sydney and one gate in each of the other cities to any new approved entrants once deregulation occurred.

The immediate question asked was would this "concession" be enough to allow new entrants to effectively compete. Right from the start Compass Airlines, which is the only new entrant to have made any impact in the market (indeed its impact has been quite significant) has indicated that it is working under severe disadvantage by being unable to obtain use of more than two gates in Sydney and Melbourne. The terms under which Compass has been allowed the use of relevant gates has in my view been negotiated firmly but fairly by Australian Airlines. Recently Compass could not come to terms with Australian in relation to the start up of its Adelaide operations and had to make alternative arrangements for "gates". Brian Grey has indicated that he does not believe Compass will be able to gain a much bigger share of the market unless the infrastructure that currently exists in the airline industry is rewritten, i.e. the access question is reassessed.

If there were evidence of misuse of market power on the part of Australian Airlines (I take Australian Airlines simply because it is the airline through which Compass obtains its access to the airports) what remedy could the court impose? An injunction would probably be inadequate in the context of Compass' desire to gain a bigger share of the market which it might believe it was entitled to through its vigorous competitive behaviour. Taking away from Australian the right to use the terminals it has a 30 year lease over would be too drastic a remedy in the context of the misuse of market power that might arise in these particular situations. But what about the rewriting of the 30 year leases to require Australian to provide say three or four gates at Sydney and Melbourne and an increase elsewhere for fair compensation? This is not possible in my view under the current law.

Some of the operators in the industries that were tightly regulated (e.g. airlines, telecommunications, etc.) until recently are almost in a position of natural monopolies or natural duopolies. The potential remedies under the Trade Practices Act (which as I have indicated would not include the ability to rewrite those 30 year leases on my reading of s.87 of the Act) would mean that if there were serious breaches of the law the courts would be left with a limited range of remedies that they could provide to the parties--injunctions, small penalties and no real ability, as the US writers assert, to get at the heart of the problem.

Apart from airlines of course we have the telecommunications industry and there may be others (energy is about to be opened up to some form of competition) where the sheer size and protection of the existing monopolists and duopolists might be so significant as to create very significant barriers to new entrants.

The Government has signalled very recently that it will empower the Broadcasting Tribunal to order "divestiture" of the cross media rules (as amended) are breached; if such power is to be given to this Tribunal why is it so horrendous to arm the Federal Court with such a power if there is a serious misuse of power (and it will only be the most serious case in which the remedy will be sought!!)?
Purpose or Effect

Another change that might be considered to s46 so as to in effect bring it on par with the other provisions of the statute (other than the mergers provision) is to prevent the misuse of market power where the purpose or effect of the misuse is to create detriment to the competitive environment--ie to lead to a substantial lessening of competition. If an effects test was introduced (as has been suggested by the Trade Practices Commission especially in relation to the deregulated industries) other parts of the section would have to be changed, in my view, to make sure that it is the competitive process rather than competitors that will have to be shown to have been damaged to obtain the necessary relief. If we do not change the impact of the relevant conduct this may amount to swinging the pendulum too far the other way. Such an approach would create significant opportunities for new entrants to gain an advantage that they would be unable to obtain through normal market forces.
Other Restrictive Trade Practices

The Commission's continued success in Resale Price Maintenance cases for example, TPC v Commodore Business Machines Pty Ltd ((1989) ATPR 40-976) and TPC v General Corporation Japan Pty Ltd ((1989) ATPR 40-922) and in TPC v Sony (Australia) Pty Ltd &Ors ((1990) ATPR 41-053) (discussed elsewhere in this report) reflect the fact that this practice remains regrettably high on the work list of the Commission. Price fixing also occupies a good deal of the Commission's time--not naked price fixing but arrangements and practices which it has been alleged lead to price fixing. The existence of concentrated industry sectors, where oligopoly and duopoly is often the norm, has contributed to a public perception that collusion is at the heart of some industries. Even assuming that there are grounds for supporting these allegations, the proof which is necessary to establish the existence of an arrangement (or understanding) which amount to a breach of s45 of the Act, is so difficult to establish that there will be very few cases which the Commission will wish to run in this area.

Of course the penalties which may be handed down by the courts (see discussion of penalties) are not conducive to the Commission instituting court proceedings in this regard. This in turn has led to the Commission seeking to go down a different route in reaching agreement in various cases--e.g. Toshiba, Pacific Dunlop and Solomons Carpet--all of which are discussed elsewhere in this report.
Penalties
There is now a recognition of the inadequacy of the penalties which may be imposed by the courts. These two extracts from leading cases in 1990 are evidence of that.
The first case to note is TPC v Sony (Australia) Pty Ltd and others ((1990) ATPR 41-053) Pincus J made these comments about the inadequacies of current penalties (at pp. 51, 690-51,692):

`Were it not for the desirability of setting penalties conforming to the level found in the authorities (and in particular in the recent decision of the Full Court in Commodore Business Machines Pty Ltd v TPC ((1990) ATPR 41-019), I should have been inclined to assess penalties at higher sums than have in fact been fixed. When one finds deliberate breaches of the price maintenance provisions of the Trade Practices Act committee by a subsidiary of one of the greatest manufacturers of electronic consumer goods, after years of attempts to enforce compliance with these provisions, one can only suspect that the penalties have not been taken very seriously. Their deterrent effect has been insufficient, it appears, to counterbalance the profit apparently derived from protecting recommended prices against the effects of competition between their dealers.'
The second major statement is Mr Justice French's decision in TPC v CSR Limited ((1991) ATPR 41-076) where he noted as follows (at p 52, 154):

`. . . each case will fall to be decided according to its own circumstances. But the approach taken in the CUB case [TPC v Carlton and United Breweries Ltd (1990) ATPR 41-037] suggests, and I think it right, that large corporations contravening s46 of the Trade Practices Act can expect penalties in the upper reaches of the range for which the law presently provides. Indeed having regard to the size and strength of some of the corporations to which the section is addressed, it may be concluded that the present day value of the maximum penalty no longer reflects the seriousness with which Parliament intended contraventions of Pt IV to be treated when the Act was passed in 1974.'

Mr Duffy recently announced an intention to increase penalties to $5 million (although he did not dismiss the possibility of going as high as $10 million). What is even more important, however, is the development of a policy on penalties. What should we be trying to achieve with the penalty regime? Alternatives such as a disgorgement of profits should not be dismissed without some detailed consideration.
Consumer Protection

In addressing various issues I have not touched much on the area of consumer protection. This is in some respects more important than the competition issues because we are dealing by and large with problems which confront the `have nots'--the regrettably increasing number of Australians who find the cost of justice beyond their reach and who therefore come to rely more and more on regulatory agencies to act on their behalf.

The separation of the Ministerial responsibilities between the Attorney-General and a Minister of Consumer Protection, with establishment some years ago of a separate departmental structure (The Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs) has meant a higher profile for aspects of this area of responsibility, whilst also creating unnecessary competition within the Department and the TPC for resources and attention in dealing with the problem areas. Whilst the States and Territories have now each established separate legislation (Fair Trading Acts) to replicate (almost totally) the consumer protection provisions of the Trade Practices Act, and whilst the Commission during my term took a number of steps to bring about greater cooperation and coordination of the work of the relevant agencies (the setting up of CADMAC being the most recent innovation), I believe the Commission should do more for the consumer than it is able to do.

In particular I felt rather helpless to assist the many consumers who had been left in a fairly invidious position as a result of many instances of what appeared on the surface to be unfair and at times harsh behaviour by financial institutions including the banks, and by some of the high flying companies of the 1980s. But the most significant incidence of unfair behaviour was in the smaller businesses area; they (ie small business) in turn were often the victims of the type of behaviour. Because of the limited resources the Commission took the hard decision to limit our involvement in business scams, such as the get rich quick schemes, franchising rorts (especially in relation to such schemes) and areas such as land sales. No sooner would the Commission succeed in stopping one such activity (even with well publicised court cases) than others would crop up to frustrate and blunt the successes of the part.

The development of alternative strategies to deal with such practices was a primary activity of the Commission. Our colleagues at CADMAC (referred to below) and I felt that the introduction of cease and desist orders as part of the `arsenal' available to the Commission (and State and Territory agencies) was a matter deserving urgent attention and appropriate action. I recognise there may be some constitutional difficulties in developing a scheme which might replicate the US system which has been part and parcel of the Federal Trade Commission's `arsenal' for many years.

At the time of my retirement from the Commission I understood that some good work was being done in the Federal Bureau on this and related topics concerning remedies; the Commission itself was undertaking some preliminary work the results of which might be of very real use to the Bureau in its endeavours. As should be the case of other proposals for reforms one hopes that any discussions appear to consider these issues is made available for considered public comment at the earliest possible time.
Working with Governments and the Community

The establishment of the Consultative Committee and CADMAC during my term have been outstanding successes. The Consultative Committee has been invaluable in ensuring that the Commission receives the best possible advice from interested groups (from all sectors of the community) in developing guides, position papers and background information for the community and government. The Background Paper on s46 of the Act, the Report produced on the possible extension of s52A of the Act to small business; and the soon to be released paper on the interface between intellectual property rules and trade practices rules, all benefited enormously from input provided by representatives of the groups sitting on the Consultative Committee.

Elsewhere in this report there is a description of the work of CADMAC. This group was established at my initiative at the SCOCAM Meeting in Perth in July 1990 (Meeting of Consumer Affairs Ministers and Officials) and with Allan Asher and Bill Dee from the Commission providing guidance it has been able to ensure greater cooperation between the Commission and the Consumer Affairs Agencies.

Coordination between the Commission and the Australian Securities Commission which was formally set up in March 1991 has in the ensuing months produced significant cooperation between the two bodies; it will be important to see if this can be extended to the heart of the area of agreement--the provision of better results to disgruntled investors who have been the victims of misleading investment schemes, advertising or practices. The Commission, encouraged by its success in setting up these arrangements with the Australian Securities Commission, at the time of my retirement had been negotiating similar arrangements with the Insurance Commission to cover the overlap between Trade Practices law and the Insurance industry.

With the appointment of Associate Commissioners from the Prices Surveillance Authority and Austel it is not surprising that there has been considerable cooperation between these two bodies and the Commission. The Commission also enjoyed a close coordination of the Channel 10 restructuring with the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and I had discussions with Peter Westerway on the possible appointment of an Associate Commissioner from that body (or rather its `successor') in due course. Of course this is a matter of government policy but in the light of the continued interest in the media generally such a cross appointment seems desirable.

Our relationship with the New Zealand Commerce Commission has been very strong and I look forward to the day when the two Commissions can sit formally together, or some alternative mechanism is put into place to allow greater coordination of the work of these two bodies as the concept of one market involving Australia and New Zealand becomes more realistic.

Many other agencies and organisations agreed to cooperate with the Commission over the past years and it would be invidious for me to name each of them. But perhaps the most satisfying development in that regard has been the increasing recognition of the Australian Commission by our OECD partners and the OECD itself. Despite quite amazingly reactive opposition from the Attorney-General's Department but with the Attorney-General's approval (both Bowen and Duffy) I attended a number of meetings of the Competition Policy Committee in Paris (as an observer but on two occasions without the benefit of departmental representatives). These meetings were very productive and have led to the Commission's work becoming even better known than it had been for some years. The invitation for me to join the Bureau (which is the Executive Committee of the Committee) was an honour for Australia (I could not join for reasons of timing and protocol). There should be a complete rethink by the Department to ensure that the Commission representative is given formal standing at this Committee so that he or she can serve on the Bureau if invited.
The Profile of the Commission

When I joined the Commission it had a regrettably low profile--many mistook it for the National Companies and Securities Commission; others felt it had been too `soft' in dealing with mergers and consumer protection (due to a large extent to a misunderstanding of the resource constraints imposed on the Commission). Certainly our relationship with the press was a `tense' one.
It is obvious that this profile has changed. This has been due to a number of factors
(a) our politicking for better resources.

(b) our high profile court `cases' such as Queensland Wire, Arnotts, CUB, CSR, and our authorisation push such as Pasminco and ACI-Smorgon as well as our stand against applications which had insufficient assets (such as the Daily News authorisation).
(c) the overdue recognition of the role of competition law in our micro-economic reform push by the various Ministers culminating in the Prime Minister's statement of 12 March.
(d) our engagement in high profile studies and research such as the Professions and Small Business and s52A of the Act.
(e) various speeches delivered by me and my colleagues including two Press Club speeches by me which received significant press and other media coverage.
(f) the growing disenchantment with aspects of the law--e.g. penalties by the judges, the merger test as it applied to the media, etc.

There are no doubt other reasons for this profile having been changed. I make no apology for pushing the profile into the forefront as I firmly believe that if we are to have a successful campaign for the creation of a competitive Australia we must have relevant and practical trade practices law which has clear aims, together with properly resourced agencies and courts (and departments) to undertake the task of ensuring that the law is administered and interpreted in an appropriate way.

Without doubt my success on raising the profile of the Commission has been largely due to the work of the Information and Compliance Branch of the Commission led by John Adey, and the hard work the Commissioners, staff and lawyers within the Australian Government Solicitor's sub-office under the leadership of Bob Alexander.
Conclusions

I conclude as I began--to thank all who worked with me to make the work of the Commission more relevant to the community, and to acknowledge the opportunity I have been given to serve the community. I hope the results of my term will be lasting.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows--

The purpose of this Bill is to provide the SBS with a new Charter and the full range of corporate powers appropriate to an independent public authority. The decision to develop the Bill was announced in the Government's National Agenda for a Multicultural Australia, launched in July 1989. The agenda defines the Commonwealth Government's multicultural policies and the goals that underlie them.

The National Agenda for a Multicultural Australia emphasises that the nation's cultural institutions, including the media, have a critical role to play in both mirroring and shaping Australians' image of themselves. Our institutions need to be responsive to Australia's diverse community in which four out of 10 Australians are immigrants or the children of immigrants, half of them from non-English speaking backgrounds.

The Government regards the SBS as both a special service for Australians of non-English speaking background and as a genuinely multicultural broadcaster for the benefit of all Australians, regardless of background.
The establishment of separate legislation for the SBS will secure the future of the SBS and will express and guarantee the multilingual and multicultural character of the broadcaster.

The legislation defines the Charter of the SBS and sets out its structure, powers and responsibilities. It removes from the Broadcasting Act the provisions relating to the establishment and management of the SBS. The principal effect of the legislation will be to establish the SBS as a statutory authority with similar powers and operational structures to the ABC, taking account of statutory authority and Government business enterprise reforms where appropriate.

The Bill provides for the introduction of a new Act, the Special Broadcasting Service Act and consequential amendments of the Broadcasting Act 1942 and a range of other Acts. The new staffing provisions will commence on proclamation. All other provisions will commence 28 days after the legislation receives Royal Assent.
I now turn to the detail of the proposed legislation.

The new legislation for the SBS provides the Government, the SBS and the public with a clear statement of the SBS's intended role. It also establishes management, advisory, accountability and staffing structures appropriate to the functions of the new corporation.

An important underlying theme of the legislation is to provide the SBS with greater flexibility in the management of its operations. At the same time there is a need to put in place adequate measures to ensure that the SBS operates efficiently and is accountable through the responsible Minister and the Parliament to the Australian people who own and fund it.

The SBS Charter establishes the primary role of the SBS as being Australia's multicultural broadcaster. It provides a broad statement of the main objective of the SBS which will be to provide multilingual and multicultural broadcasting services which inform, educate and entertain all Australians, and in doing so, reflect Australia's multicultural society.

The specific charter objectives recognise the wide-ranging role of the SBS. The SBS will be expected to meet the needs of ethnic, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Communities for information and entertainment in languages other than English, and to contribute to the retention and development of language and other cultural skills now present in Australia. It will be expected to increase awareness of the contribution of a diversity of cultures to the continuing development of Australian society and to promote understanding and acceptance of that diversity. The SBS will also be expected to extend the range of Australian television and radio services, to make use of Australia's creative resources and to contribute greatly to the overall diversity in Australian broadcasting.

In practice, the SBS's approach to fulfilling its Charter will differ between television and radio, reflecting the inherent characteristics of these different broadcasting media. SBS radio will continue to mainly provide programs in languages other than English which cater for the needs of a wide range of communities. SBS television will provide programming in both English and community languages, reflecting the needs and interests of all Australians.

The SBS will continue to be primarily funded from the Budget. It will, however, as a subsidiary function to its charter obligations, also be able to conduct business or other activities to the fulfilment of the Charter, with a view to generating off-budget revenue. In addition, the SBS will have the opportunity of increasing its revenues through advertising and sponsorship.
To assist the SBS to undertake permitted business activities, the legislation will allow it to enter into partnerships or other business arrangements with the agreement of the Minister.

These business activities should not detract from the SBS's primary charter responsibilities. The SBS will be subject to a range of corporate planning and annual reporting requirements. The SBS will be required to identify, in advance, the corporate objectives, including forecasts of revenue and expenditure, and overall strategies and policies to be followed by the SBS, and its subsidiaries, for meeting those objectives.

Under the current legislation, the SBS is already able to accept money for the sponsorship of programs. Accordingly, it has, over the past 12 months, entered into a number of successful sponsorship agreements which have enabled it to purchase programs which have attracted high audience ratings such as the World Cup Soccer Series and `The Civil War'. The additional revenue it can expect to attract from advertising will enable it to further improve its services and, in particular, to produce more programs of its own.

I am sensitive to the concern that advertising and sponsorship revenue funding has the potential to alter the scheduling and content of SBS programs. The distinctive character of the SBS will, therefore, be preserved through a number of measures. Foremost there is the detailed Charter and the obligation on the Board to ensure the independence and integrity of the SBS, also, the SBS Board will be required to report annually to Parliament on how its programming activities have related to its Charter obligations. It will also be required to report on the detail of the advertising and sponsorship arrangements it has entered into.

In addition, the legislation limits the amount of advertising and sponsorship announcements the SBS can sell to five minutes per hour and requires that the announcements be broadcast only between programs or in natural program breaks. The five minute limitation will not apply to announcements for which the SBS receives no payment or other consideration--for example, community announcements or the promotion of the SBS's own programs and products. The SBS will be generally subject to the same statutory control on advertising as the commercial broadcasters.

Within these statutory limitations, the SBS Board will have discretion to determine a range of matters about the types of advertising and sponsorship announcements it will broadcast and when they will be broadcast. The Board will be required to develop and publish guidelines on these matters, and may refuse advertisements which do not comply with its guidelines.

The effect on the commercial broadcasting sector of the introduction of advertising and sponsorship is not expected to be significant. The SBS audience share is relatively smaller and its advertising revenue share is expected to reflect this. Furthermore, the SBS serves many distinct audiences and has the potential to appeal to companies which do not presently advertise on radio or television.

The legislation allows the SBS to borrow money from the Commonwealth or other sources with Ministerial approval and to offer its assets as security. It will permit the Commonwealth to guarantee the loans. The legislation also confers powers to enter into hedging contracts to reduce the risks of foreign exchange or interest rate fluctuations and to invest surplus funds in a manner approved by the Treasurer.
These powers are consistent with the greater independence and accountability of the SBS in financial matters.

The size of the SBS Board will be increased by two to reflect its increased statutory responsibilities. Although there are no formal qualification requirements for Board members, members will collectively be required to possess expertise in the areas needed to govern the SBS effectively. For this purpose, members will be required to have an understanding of multiculturalism and of the needs and interests of the SBS's culturally diverse audience. They will also be required to have between them a diversity of cultural perspectives. At least one member will be required to have an appropriate understanding of the interests of employees.
In making appointments to the SBS Board, the Government will actively seek equitable representation of women, young people and people of different ethnic backgrounds.

The Managing Director of the SBS will be the only full-time member of the Board. He or she will be appointed by the Board and be responsible to it for the conduct of the SBS's business. Other appointments to the Board will be made by the Governor-General.

The SBS requires a flexible staffing regime that can accommodate a range of employment arrangements. Accordingly the SBS will be empowered to engage staff in accordance with terms and conditions determined by the SBS. However, the Government expects the terms and conditions, including internal administrative arrangements, to be developed in full consultation with the unions. The new staffing provisions will not commence operation until the Government is satisfied that there has been full consultation.

In addition, the SBS will be expected to adhere to the Government's policies on industrial relations matters with possible flow-on or policy impact, including pay and conditions of service issues, and matters such as industrial democracy, occupational health and safety, and technological change.

The Board will be required to develop and publicise the SBS's programming policies and its policies on the handling of complaints. The Government is separately reviewing public accountability arrangements in relation to both the ABC and SBS. As part of that review, the Government will consider the adequacy of existing arrangements for program standard setting and complaints handling and the appropriate role of external bodies such as the Ombudsman and the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.

The SBS Board will be expected to ensure that SBS programming is responsive to the changing needs of SBS audiences, and to take account of community opinion in developing programming strategies and policies for fulfilling the Charter.

The consultative mechanisms for gauging community needs and opinions will be determined by the SBS Board. The Board will be required to describe these measures in the corporate plan. Due to the public interest in effective consultation, this element of the corporate plan will be subject to alteration by the Minister, if considered necessary. Through this process, the Minister will be empowered to require the SBS Board to establish an advisory council if the Minister is not satisfied with the consultative arrangements planned by the Board.

To assist the Board to develop appropriate community consultative mechanisms for inclusion in its first corporate plan, the Board will be required to establish an interim community advisory committee constituted by persons with an understanding of multiculturalism together with interests, skills and experience relevant to ethnic, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. This committee will be disbanded when the first corporate plan is provided to the Minister.

The independence of the SBS from Government influence is an important policy objective. The legislation aims to guarantee this independence in programming and editorial matters, but at the same time ensure that the SBS, as a Budget-funded organisation, is properly accountable to the Australian public for expenditure of its money.

The SBS will be expected to adopt relevant Government policies in the performance of its functions where these do not conflict with the exercise of its statutory responsibilities. Also, the Minister may formally direct the SBS Board on matters and circumstances which are prescribed in regulations but not on programming or scheduling matters.

The amendments in the Bill will not alter the costs or revenues of the Commonwealth. They do not require the application of additional resources by the SBS to meet its new charter obligations or to comply with its establishment and management responsibilities.

The Government sees the SBS as playing a vital role in the enjoyment of being Australian. The SBS also meets real communications needs for many Australians. The SBS has won acclaim for its successes in radio and television, which the Government recognises and applauds.

The Government's commitment to the SBS has been evidenced by the decision to continue indexed Budget funding for a further three years and to allow the full retention of non-Budget income including income from sponsorships and advertising. The Government has also authorised borrowing to allow the SBS to purchase its own headquarters building.

This Bill seeks to provide the foundations for a stable future for the SBS. We are confident that with solid legislative and financial underpinning, the SBS will continue to offer a fine and improving service to all Australians.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
