The figure of $12m has been appropriated to bring that date forward from 1 July 1992, according to the old Budget figures, `to be implemented as soon as possible'. The Caucus meeting decided that an appropriation of $12m should be made for that purpose. Another dot point in the document referred to cutting over-servicing and improving the efficiency and quality of service in pathology and diagnostic imaging. While two out of four items have remained unchanged, two have been altered.

Today we are debating these Appropriation Bills and obviously, if the alterations to which I have referred have taken place, the Bills must be amended. But the Government has not yet had the courtesy to make a statement in the Senate. This has all been done via the media--there has been no statement in the Senate at all.

What are the new figures that we are meant to be looking at? We know the old figures which are contained in the Budget Papers. In respect of outlays the old figure was $101.508 billion. But what are the new figures? We have been told by the media that an additional $70m will be needed. Where is the money coming from? We know that the original deficit was $4.732 billion. What will the new deficit be? We have no idea. How much further will this Government put the country into debt to please the Left so that the Prime Minister can survive a leadership challenge?

We have the highest unemployment in the history of this country, with a total of over one million people out of work. We also have the highest number of bankruptcies ever recorded in this country, and the highest overseas debt on record. Nearly one in four 15- to 19-year-olds are unemployed. But the Prime Minister is incapable of making the tough decisions because he is a captive of the Keating challenge. It is pathetic that this wonderful country is going down the drain because the Prime Minister is too scared to show a vestige of leadership.

For the first time in the history of the country, the Prime Minister decided--when the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) had already made his statement to the Parliament--to send the Budget to a backbench committee of lefties to come up with an alternative Budget decision. He gave strict instructions to that committee, and let us not underestimate those, that the decision could not compromise the Budget figures or outcome. What happened? The Budget has been amended because its integrity has been compromised. The figures no longer have any integrity. The whole thing is a shambles. Yet here we have the Government placing the Appropriation Bills on the agenda in this place for debate. These Bills are totally flawed.

We went through a couple of weeks of Estimates committee hearings. The figures for the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, in which I am particularly interested, are totally wrong. While all this has been going on, the Prime Minister and his Treasurer have ducked off overseas. Mr Hawke probably realises that it is the last trip he will have overseas as Prime Minister. When he comes back I do not doubt for a minute that Mr Keating will challenge him because no leadership has been shown on any of these issues.

Unions, backbenchers, Labor Party members and the Premiers of both Victoria and Tasmania are all screaming, `For heaven's sake, just do something for the unemployed. Let there be no tough decisions'. Instead, the Prime Minister has given way to a leftie committee and a scrambling for votes for leadership. The Prime Minister rings Joan Kirner and says, `Pull Mr White into line'. As Laurie Oakes says, what a cheek. I quote Laurie Oakes:

Hawke's cheek in demanding that Kirner discipline her industry minister, David White, was astonishing. This, after all, is the prime minister who was unable to phone his own employment minister, John Dawkins, about allegedly destabilising activities, and tried to rely on an intermediary to hose down Dawkins. The attempt to heavy Kirner was yet another serious lapse of political judgment by Hawke.
All I can say to that, as do the backbenchers of the Labor Party, is that it certainly was.

We have to have some leadership to get out of the mess that this Government has deliberately got us into. It deliberately created a depression with over one million unemployed people and deliberately forced record bankruptcies because Mr Keating, the then Treasurer, said, `We have to have a depression'. It is the only way he saw to deal with the economy in the country. Those in the Labor Party had better get out and tell those in the dole queues that their sacrifice is for the good of the country, because they do not know that Labor Party members consider their sacrifice as such.

Let us look at bankruptcies. In this last financial year, from June 1990 to June 1991, there were 12,991 bankruptcies--just on 13,000 bankruptcies. How many were there the previous financial year? There were 8,552. As if that were not bad enough, the Government brought it up this year to 13,000. In the last quarter to June 1991--in just three months--there were 4,030 bankruptcies. In the same quarter last year, it was about half that--that is, 2,605 bankruptcies. We were horrified at last year's figures; this year's figures are just about double them.

In Question Time yesterday, Senator Button said, `Oh, well, the Government got it wrong; we made a few mistakes'. In speaking in this debate on the Appropriation Bills, Senator Sherry said, `We are not perfect; we have made a few mistakes'. I suggest that Senator Button, Senator Sherry, Senator Cook, Senator Jones and the rest of the mob opposite get out, go down to the dole queues and apologise for the mistakes they have made because someone has to tell the unemployed that the Government is sorry for the plight they are in.
This Budget, as presently being debated before the Senate, has not done a solitary thing for the unemployed. The only thing the Government has done is appropriate $800m for a better cities program.

TALK.START.PARA: —-A marginal seats strategy.
—-As Senator Tambling has said, it is a marginal seats strategy. Our leader, Dr Hewson, says:

SPEECH.PARA: All the Government is going to give them as a result of that package is better quality pavements to queue up on, designer soup kitchens or better parks for the homeless to live in.

That is all the Government has done for the unemployed. Over one million people are unemployed in this country. I wonder how many Opposition and Government senators have children in the 15- to 19-year-old age group; one in four members of that group are unemployed.

Let us look more closely at unemployment. As I have just said, in my State nearly one person in four is unemployed. On the north-west coast of Tasmania, nearly one person in three is unemployed. What is the Government's response? It stopped the development of the Wesley Vale paper mill. That is what this Government did for unemployment on the north-west coast of Tasmania. As a result, one third of our 15- to 19-year-olds in that area are unemployed. I can assure Senator Cook that the better cities program will not help them. Let us look at the debacle of the health scheme that this Government set up. According to the Government, it does not really matter what happens to the health scheme or the health policy in this country; ideology is all important. Medicare is going broke, but we must retain ideology. Hospitals are closing beds, but we must retain our ideology. Queues are lengthening. Over 75,000 people have been queuing, some for years, but it does not matter because the Government says that we must retain our ideology. Pensioners cannot get into the hospitals, but the more wealthy in the community--for example, the friends of Mr Hawke--can get in whenever they want to. The hospitals have to take them because they need the money. But all that goes by the board because the ideology has to be retained.

I would not mind if ideology helped those in need, but all Bob's mates are the ones who will benefit. Bond, Packer, Skase, O'Connell all roll off the lips of those in the Labor mob over on the other side of the chamber, because ideology is what it is all about and it is ideology that says that people should be able to go to their doctor and not have to pay a thing.

It does not matter one bit if we income test and assets test family allowances. But, according to the Government, we must not test health care. If people go to their doctors, they can receive their services for nothing so long as he or she bulkbills. I warn the medical profession: at the moment, something like 74 per cent of GPs in New South Wales are bulkbilling. Once they are all paid by the Government for bulkbilling, they are socialised. Once the Government pays a doctor's full income, there is no way that he or she is not socialised. Irrespective of whether doctors like it, that is the situation.

The doctors have to realise how this Government works. I have watched the pharmacists slowly but surely succumb to the temptation of accepting direct government payment, instead of the patient getting the subsidy and being responsible for payment. The pharmacists accepted direct payment when they should have rejected it and said to the Government, `You subsidise the patient coming with a prescription and we will just deal with the patient'. Many of the doctors are still doing that but many are succumbing, as the pharmacists did, to direct payment by the Government.

What has happened to the pharmacists? They are now fully socialised. They are paid by the Government. They have to get permission to open up a pharmacy. If they want to open up a pharmacy in a country town or in a suburb, they cannot. They now have to go to the Government and plead their cause. I can assure honourable senators that the pharmacists are getting nowhere. They are fully socialised. The Government will not let them open a pharmacy without special permission. Indeed, the Government even pays them when they close a pharmacy. What further control could the Government have? It does not matter how essential the pharmacy is; the pharmacists cannot open one, but they get paid for closing one.

I will explain to the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), who is in the chamber, and to honourable senators present, what the Government has set up. I do not think Senator Cook understands it. He can tell me later if he thinks it is the best way to spend taxpayers' money. I will give an example. A pharmacist owns two pharmacies. The first is a very old, viable pharmacy which fills lots of prescriptions. Fifty metres around the corner in a shopping mall is his second pharmacy. It was a mistake. It is going broke. For some reason it has not taken off. But his old pharmacy is doing very well. He can close the old pharmacy, get $80,000 from the Government and transfer the new pharmacy, which under normal market forces would have gone broke, to the position of the old pharmacy, without ever closing its doors. So the Government has paid $80,000 of taxpayers' money for a pharmacy that was going broke; it was in dire trouble. What a rort.

Later on I would like the Minister to tell me whether he considers that to be a rort. If he does not, then I want it clearly understood that the taxpayers I speak to consider that this situation is a total rort. Yet, when I asked officers of the Department about this, they said, `No, it is all in the guidelines. That is quite permissible. A pharmacist can close a good pharmacy down. We will pay him $80,000 and he can move his no good pharmacy and put it in that position and never close his doors'. So a pharmacist is paid $80,000 for a pharmacy that would normally close through market forces. If the taxpayers in the gallery think that is the way their tax money should be spent, I would be most surprised. No taxpayers I talk to consider it anything but a rort. It is just socialist nonsense and a method by which the Government can have full control over the pharmacists.

I will come back to the integrity of the Budget. The integrity of the Budget is just non-existent. We do not have the figures. When I asked Senator Button for the figures at Question Time he was so sensitive and upset about this change in Medicare that he rattled the figures off at a rate of knots. I then told him that I could not pick them up and asked him whether he would mind tabling them so I could have a look at them. He said, `No. They will be in Hansard tomorrow'. I am well aware that the figures will be in Hansard tomorrow, but I wanted them for this speech today. He is so sensitive about them.

Senator Button is also very concerned about the integrity of the Budget. He knows that the figures we have in this document on health care are totally wrong. Supposedly, the saving in the original Budget was to be $940.7m in the year 1994-95. We know that those figures are no good now. Those figures are passe. We know that the Government has to find $70m from somewhere else. We know that it has now appropriated $4m of taxpayers' money just to go out and explain to the people the alteration in the Budget. The Government has appropriated $4m of taxpayers' money to tell the people that Bob Hawke had to give way to the Left. If he had not, he would have been rolled as a leader. So Bob Hawke had to set up a committee--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! Senator Walters, I believe you should refer to the Prime Minister by his correct title.

—-The Prime Minister had to go out and spend $4m to tell the people that he had to change his Budget because, if he had not, he would have been deserted in the Caucus. He is spending an additional $4m to do that. He is also spending another $12m, as I have just said, to tell the medical profession that the Government has alternative ways in which that profession ought to conduct itself. Once the medical profession sees what is in this Budget, it will be horrified. I am not sure how many millions of dollars we are going to spend to implement practice grants to complement fee for service reimbursements. A practice grant will provide some remuneration to those general practices which choose to reduce their reliance on fee for service. The Government is going to give a doctor a practice grant so that he will be able to bulkbill.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government wants to trial the use of practice budgets. Under this arrangement a budget is allocated to a general practice to cover the cost of diagnostic services and pharmaceuticals. So the Government will say to a practice, `There is your budget and don't overspend'.

The next item in the document is accreditation of general practices. The Government sees this as a natural development of the vocational registration arrangements, so it tells us. Those arrangements are a form of accreditation, but of individual practitioners. So individual practitioners will be accredited.

The next item is supply and distribution of medical practitioners. The Government will look at the medical immigration numbers, outputs from medical schools and the distribution of medical practitioners. Does that sound familiar? The distribution of medical practitioners sounds so similar to the distribution of pharmacies. Soon doctors will have to apply to the Government before they can set up practice.

If the medical profession does not take this warning and get out of bulkbilling, does not reassert the fact that there is a contract between it and its patients, and the Government subsidises the patient and not the doctor, it will find itself in exactly the same situation as the pharmacists are in today. Doctors will be crawling to the Government to say, `Please, can we open a medical practice?'. They will find that they are knocked back just as the pharmacists are being knocked back at the moment.

The Government is in dire trouble and it was very obvious to this side of the Senate at Question Time today just what sort of trouble it is in. When we saw Senator Cook today organise that pathetically weak and appalling dorothy dixer to take up as much of Question Time as possible to relieve the other Ministers of questioning by the Opposition, we knew what sort of trouble the Government was in. Its method of handling these changes to the Budget clearly reflects the stress that Ministers are under, and it is time the Government cleared up its leadership problems and started to govern the country for the sake of all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I rise to speak on the Appropriation Bills before the Senate and, in particular, to support the amendment moved by Senator Short. This amendment points out that Australia is suffering the worst recession in 60 years. Even Government spokesmen have started to concede the tragedy we are now facing as many families have to suffer the results of this Government's policies, which are causing unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: If the public wants to find a clear example of why Australia finds itself in this predicament, it could find it by reading Senator Sherry's speech on this debate. Senator Sherry seems to think that the Government can impose a further tax on employers, the superannuation levy in this case, and have no effect on employment. Indeed, according to Senator Sherry's logic, this tax will benefit employment. If this is the case, one wonders why the Government has not immediately imposed a 10 or 20 per cent levy.

According to Senator Sherry's logic and, indeed, that of Senator Cook, who is in the chamber now, this levy presumably would have no effect on employment levels in this nation. The reality is that this levy alone will cost up to 100,000 jobs. I suggest that Senator Sherry's shabby logic and his willingness to agree to trade union bosses' demands very succinctly explain what has happened to this Government and how it has derailed the Australian economy. Senator Sherry's arrogant demands that further imposts be placed on employers in the midst of a recession indicate that Labor, its Ministers and its back bench have learnt nothing from the results of the last eight years.

There is no doubt whatsoever about the cause of the recession. Mr Keating indicated it in his memorable words, `This is a recession engineered by the Government, a recession we had to have'. Senator Button has indicated on a number of occasions in this chamber that the Government misjudged its economic strategy. It kept interest rates too high for too long. What the Government has not told us and what we wait to hear day after day in this chamber when we pose questions to Senator Cook and to Senator Button is how this Government is going to engineer a recovery. The Government can engineer a recession--no-one is arguing that point--but we are still waiting to hear its plans to see how it can engineer a recovery.

The members of Caucus are in a high state of panic, knowing that they will lose their parliamentary jobs as punishment for allowing the Government to put one million people out of their jobs. All those Labor senators and MPs, the men and women who laughed and cheered behind Mr Keating as he boasted about his policies and the Government, are now in a state of blind panic.

When Mr Keating was Treasurer it was very interesting to go over to the other place to see how he boasted about his policies and what great policies they were. He heaped contempt on the Opposition when it pointed out that Australia was heading for a recession. The back bench of men and women of the Labor Party laughed with and cheered on this man. The reality is that those men and women who laughed and cheered will be laughing and cheering themselves out of a job--and deservedly so--because they defended this man. When they could have stood up and criticised the policies of Mr Keating and Mr Hawke, they laughed and jeered. They are going to pay, I suggest, a very heavy price.

What is the answer to the recession that we now have? Caucus, apparently, as I mentioned in a previous speech, has formed a subcommittee under Lloyd O'Neil to find out the reasons for unemployment in this nation today. One wonders why the Government needs a Caucus committee to explain the causes of unemployment. I would have thought it could be summed up in five simple words: Hawke, Keating, Button, Richardson and Cook. That is the answer Lloyd O'Neil has to find. It is quite simple and straightforward. These five guilty men, a Prime Minister and four senior Ministers, have a unique dishonour, I suggest, in the history of the Federation of Australia. In 100 years they are the only Government Ministers who have openly boasted about engineering a recession.

There is massive confusion amongst key Ministers about what strategy should be adopted to deal with unemployment. Indeed, as Senator Walters mentioned today, there is massive confusion in virtually all major policy areas of the Government: media, health, education and, as we learnt today, AIDEX--another split in Government ranks. It is no wonder that the Government is experiencing these splits and divisions because the nation is experiencing massive policy failure right across the broad range of government policies.

I want to deal with just one key issue on which I believe the Government is fundamentally split: what to do about unemployment. Senator Cook in his speech today in this debate drew our attention to some of the divisions in the Government in this area and I want to look at those divisions in some detail. I believe that a number of senior Ministers, particularly Senator Button, do not accept that this Government has a policy to deal with the economic crisis which is facing Australia. Perhaps Senator Button in the twilight of his career, mindful of the way his stewardship may well be viewed in our history books, is trying one final time to turn the Government away from its failed strategy.

Barely a day goes by--Senator Short can confirm this--without television, radio or press reports on the alleged differences Senator Button has with the Government. One day last week there was a leaked letter to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Front page headlines followed that for two days. Then came Senator Button's inevitable television appearance, where he dropped broad hints about new directions in tax strategy. Further headlines followed. Then questions in Parliament on Senator Button's speculations led to further stories. Then came reports about Senator Button's differences with a Caucus decision--yet more media stories. As they say, one leak may be a mistake; two may be carelessness; but three leaks add up to a concerted campaign. A concerted campaign is being waged by a senior Minister against his own Government. That is what we are now seeing.

That is why Senator Short was quite right to highlight in his amendment to the Bills the divisions in the Government. I ask Senator Button and all senior Ministers: how can the community hope to have any confidence whatsoever in this Government when one of its senior Ministers, Senator Button, differs so profoundly with the economic strategy the Government is pursuing?

We all know that Mr Keating is campaigning against the Government--we read about that every day--and against, it has to be said, with more than a touch of irony, the very policies he supported while he was Treasurer. But Senator Button is a bit different: Senator Button is campaigning against his Government while remaining inside Cabinet and as Leader of the Government in the Senate.

I wish to highlight the areas where Senator Button is campaigning against his Government and against his Prime Minister. Surely industry policy is a key area of government policy and one directly concerned with Senator Button's stewardship. There is no question that Senator Button wants a more interventionist policy. On the Sunday program on Channel 9 last week, in relation to encouraging new industries in order to deal with what Senator Button called `chronic structural unemployment', this senior Minister said:

I think we need to have some sort of compensation in terms of developing new industries and new processes and expanding the manufacturing and services sector to take up that sort of unemployment which we now have.

Senator Button has not explained what sort of compensation he was talking about. Maybe Senator Cook can explain what sort of compensation Senator Button had in mind. But what did Mr Hawke say just four days previously? According to the Australian, he said he would not consider employment generation through Government support for untested industries. So much for Senator Button's views as far as the Prime Minister is concerned.

Then Mr Crean weighed into the debate and said that the Government should help industries get over their initial hurdles. What sort of help is Mr Crean talking about? It is not spelt out. Finally, what does Mr Kerin say about Senator Button's more interventionist policies? He dismisses them by saying, `I have been looking at vision and it costs a lot of money'. What massive confusion we have in a key area of industry policy with the industry Minister campaigning against Mr Kerin, his Cabinet and his Prime Minister.

Let us look at taxation policy. This is the second major difference Senator Button has with the Government's direction. Taxation policy is surely a key area when one is thinking about incentives for the creation of jobs. Last Sunday on television, Senator Button said that taxation in Australia was possibly inhibiting investment. He suggested we look at taxation systems in other countries--principally our trading partners.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Like a GST?

—-Our colleagues in the Democrats and Opposition members asked Senator Button what features of the business tax systems of our major trading partners he found so attractive. Did he duck and weave! He refused to tell us what he had in mind. Nonetheless, he was happy to go on television and drop these very broad and unsubtle hints.

SPEECH.PARA: Did Senator Button have in mind the tax the name of which no-one in the Labor Party dares utter--a goods and services tax, as Senator Walters mentioned? If Senator Button looks through the Asia-Pacific region and looks at our major trading partners, he will find that one element of the tax system which makes it different from the tax system we have in Australia is a goods and services tax. The reality is that a number of our major trading partners in this region have a goods and services tax, which particularly encourages the export sector. Did Senator Button have that tax in mind? There have been press reports that Senator Button has said in private meetings with people in business that a goods and services tax is not such a bad idea. But still he cannot come out and say that. He wants to remain in the Government while he campaigns against the Government.

This working party, which has been set up to look at the different tax regimes in our region, will undoubtedly point to the goods and services tax. We on this side appreciate Senator Button attempting to draw the attention of the Government towards an important taxation reform that would encourage the export industry, which he has highlighted as needing further help.

What does the Treasurer, Mr Kerin, say about Senator Button's suggestion that we need to look closely at reforming our business taxation system? The newspapers report Mr Kerin as saying that he doubts that the tax regime is hampering much-needed investment. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce wants a change in the tax structure for business; the Treasurer immediately hits it over the head. All of these views by Senator Button and Mr Kerin have been made before the interdepartmental working party to study the matter has even met--incredible confusion!

Let us look at the resources policy. This is the third area where Senator Button profoundly differs with Government policy. Senator Button clearly believes that the Government policy on environmental and heritage concerns has held up major projects. Senator Button has no argument on this issue from the mining industry and, indeed, most observers. However, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Kelly, leaks departmental advice immediately, claiming to rebut Senator Button's contention that environmental and heritage claims are blocking investment and development.

Senator Button has listed a whole host of major projects which have been held up as a result of his Government's policies: magnesium development at Gladstone; iron ore at Marandoo; the Yabulu nickel refinery at Greenvale; and the list goes on and on. None of this convinces Mrs Kelly, and the press has been given detailed departmental submissions to reject or counter the arguments that Senator Button is putting forward.

In this debate on a resources tax, the Prime Minister adds to his reputation as possibly the greatest jellyback in Australian history. Mr Hawke says what he wants to fast track is the debate on fast tracking. He does not want fast tracking of resources development; he wants fast tracking of the debate on fast tracking resources development. This is the man who is currently appointed to lead this country out of its worst recession in 60 years!

It is about time that Senator Button made up his mind. If he believes that his Government's policies are a disaster for Australia--and there is overwhelming evidence to suggest that is the case--he has two choices: either he forces a change in Government policy to come more into line with his own views or he stands on principle and resigns. If he stays in this failed Government--a disastrous Government which will be condemned in Australian history, a Government which has wrought more damage on our economy and institutions than did the Whitlam Government and a Government whose policies he clearly rejects--he will rightly be condemned as a hypocrite and a wrecker; a man without the courage of his convictions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: --The Budget brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) on 20 August recognises the problems facing rural communities. In this Budget there are a number of initiatives which assist farmers in rural communities. I wish to refer to projects in the electorate of Maranoa, an area in which I have taken a particular interest for a number of years. Farming communities in rural towns suffer from floods and the disruption and damage caused by them. Major floods in Queensland and New South Wales have been the focus of national attention in recent times. Charleville, an important centre for south-east Queensland, suffered severe damage from flooding in April 1990. Flooding ruined the entire commercial centre of the town and affected 82 per cent of the homes. If it were not for the determination of the people of Charleville, that town would have been abandoned. The Federal Government has funded, and will continue to fund, flood management projects in Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget includes $140,000 under the Federal water resources assistance program for a flood investigation for Charleville and Augathella. Funding also includes a further $100,000 in 1991-92 for an ongoing flood maintenance strategy for Dalby. Dalby has had 14 floods since 1908 with damage averaging $2.9m per year. In 1981 Dalby suffered $18m in flood damage, with 2,600 homes and 270 businesses being affected. All of us have been affected by floods in one way or another, but nothing compared with the loss of homes and belongings. In Dalby the Government is supporting a three-stage strategy which includes channel improvements, an automated flood warning system and a major bypass flood lane levee. These initiatives are part of a number of proposals by the Federal Government to help rural people.

Farmers and graziers are suffering because of the difficult international economic times that we face. The beef industry in Australia has had to confront restrictions on its exports to the United States. The Chairman of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation, Mr Dick Austin, has described the US export limits as appalling in the current trade and political environment. Unfortunately, beef producers are already facing extreme hardship owing to the drought.

This Government is working hard to support farmers and their families. Initiatives include an improved family allowance supplement, increased funding for the rural counselling program, a business advisory scheme, a rural industry business extension service, increased funding for the rural adjustment scheme and a rural access program. Also included is assistance to the wool, citrus and dairy industries, and the list goes on. What does this package of initiatives mean for the rural industry? Very clearly, it means that this Government is prepared to help the rural sector in a variety of ways. The increased demand in the rural counselling program is evidence that the rural community welcomes this type of assistance.

What would the policies of the Liberal Party and the National Party do to assist farming and other rural communities? It would be a relief to hear that the Opposition would do nothing but unfortunately that is not the case. The threat of a consumption tax and a plan to cut off dole payments do not sit well with the rural families, nor with the National Party rank and file. The Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) assures us that the plan to cut off the dole after nine months is not intended to affect those genuinely in need. With a consumption tax riding on our backs and on the back of the rural sector, there will be very few without genuine need. We cannot be sure because we do not know what the so-called consumption tax will be. It is a little like the coalition's infamous health policy a couple of years ago. It kept coming and coming but never quite arrived. The rural sector and the rest of Australia can only hope that the Opposition is as efficient now as it was then.

About 10,000 families will benefit from the Government's increased family allowance and family allowance supplement payments. That is what rural families need, not some misguided free market anti-welfare strategy. These initiatives also show that this Government recognises that the rural economy has changed. By far the majority of jobs in the rural sector are now outside agriculture and mining. Farmers need to be assisted in establishing new industries and job opportunities and obviously they should include value added industries which will bring more wealth to the community and to this country. We need to regenerate economic activity in country areas and this includes an intelligent combination of primary, secondary and tertiary sectors.

Another important policy of this Government relates to labour market and union reform. I am sure that, if Senator Kemp were here, he would agree about the union reform. The question is whether what he has in mind would be quite different from the sort of union reform that the Labor Government has in mind. Labour market reform is a high priority for this Government, as I said. This Government's efforts towards greater productivity and efficiency depend on constructive reform in the workplace. Obviously, that means both management and labour.

The workplace reform program was introduced in 1988-89 and $20m has been allocated to this program in the past two years on top of the $25m already invested. In 1990-91 the following projects were supported: the completion of a network of workplace resource centres which operates on a fee for service basis; the placement of work change advisers in industries playing a leading role in workplace reform; the `It's Your Move' project with the Confederation of Australian Industry which provided training in industrial relations to nearly 8,000 supervisors; and a number of publications including Practical Guides to Workplace Reform. The workplace reform program will continue to offer support to specific reform projects. Those projects that I have mentioned are specific; they are real tools to bring about change. We are not talking in just general broad brush terms.

The program will also provide a comprehensive service of advice and assistance on industrial matters, industrial strategic planning, new technologies, work organisation, career structures and human resource management. It will assist industry to provide managers and workers with the skills necessary to implement reform at the enterprise level and it will provide a range of practical materials and information on key industries and issues.

Workplace reform is an important part of the Government's economic and industry restructuring program. If we are to get greater efficiency and productivity in industry, we need to be constructive in our approach to the workplace. In 1991-92 priority will be given to industry sectors with large employment bases that are of major economic importance. These include the tourism and hospitality, food processing, banking, finance, insurance, rail and meat industries.

Work will also continue in the major sectors of metals, engineering, building and construction, and vehicle manufacturing. This Government is active in all areas of economic management and planning. This comprehensive approach to the economy also includes union reform. The Government is continuing to support union amalgamation as part of this program of award and general industry restructuring. I do assert that, without that union amalgamation, that restructuring will not take place in a satisfactory way.

The Government will provide a further $2m in 1991-92 to assist the amalgamation process. Eighteen successful amalgamations occurred in 1990-91 and a further 18 amalgamation ballots currently are scheduled for 1991-92. I must point out that, without the benefit of government advice and financial support, the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union came into existence, through intelligent amalgamations, and showed the way to the rest of the trade union movement. It continues to do so.

Recent amendments to the Industrial Relations Act 1988 will smooth the process of amalgamation. So we should see an escalation of the union rationalisation process as unions take advantage of these new provisions and the financial assistance that the Government continues to provide. It is pleasing to see the continued involvement of the union movement and the ACTU in this program. It highlights the unions' commitment to a more effective industrial relations system and to a more efficient and productive economy. It is very important for people to realise that both this Government and the union movement are committed to that approach because it will benefit all people in this country.

These are only three aspects of this Government's commitment to the future economic development of Australia's domestic and export industry. I am pleased to support this Government's continuing efforts to help Australian industries and to develop and continue to compete successfully at home and abroad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —-In speaking on Appropriation Bills (No. 1) and (No. 2) and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1991-92, I want to look at the economic climate, the performance of the now Treasurer, Mr Kerin, and indeed the way in which the Government as a whole is deteriorating to the detriment of Australia as a whole. Fairly recently I was caused to give a speech entitled, `Watch not: waste plenty'. In the preface to that speech I took a look at the history of this Government in the last 12 to 18 months. In specifically addressing the subject of waste I said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Budget represents the largest fiscal deterioration since the 1950's. The overall Public Sector Borrowing Requirement has moved from a surplus of 1.6% in 1988-89 into a prospective deficit of 4.3% in 1991-92.
It failed to address the fundamental problem of a disastrously low level of national savings. The collapse in savings and investment has resulted in the 308,000 fall in employment over the last year.
Of course, those figures are now out of date because we have now gone over 10 per cent for unemployment. My speech continued:

The 1.3 million underemployed and unemployed are no closer to getting a job under this budget and the Treasurer's admission in recent days that unemployment will remain in double digits for at least two years is the final indictment of his own budget strategy.

Further, the fiscal deficit of $4.7 billion is an accounting fiddle. Subtract asset sales, the transfer of maturing debts to the States, net payments from GBE's and additional profit transfers from the Reserve and Commonwealth Banks and you get an actual deficit of about $7.7 billion in 1991-92. The Budget deficit represents the largest turnaround in Federal budget numbers since the Second World War (a turnaround of $8.5 billion for the last year alone and a staggering $14.6 billion in two years).
The necessary bond sales of $11 billion this year will ensure that real interest rates remain amongst the highest in the OECD.
The 5% superannuation levy is a de facto payroll tax and will clearly add to inflation, not to mention a rise in unemployment by about 100,000. One man's super is another man's job.

Despite the Treasurer's and the Prime Minister's protestations this budget is a return to good old fashioned Keynesianism, a pump priming budget. In real terms this financial year, after a massive increase of 6.3% in 1990-91, the Commonwealth's own account spending will be back above the 1982-83 levels as a percentage of GDP.

In the light of those comments I made about a month or so ago, it was interesting to read a speech by Mr Kerin dated 10 October which he gave during a motion of censure which was being moved in the other place. As I read this collection of words which passes for a speech, I suppose, several things struck me about it: firstly, its paucity of content; and secondly, when he attempted to attack the Opposition rather than defend the indefensible--that is the Government--he used figures in such a misleading way which can only lead me to believe that he really does not understand them. That is really a great concern, when I am talking about the Treasurer.
Mr Kerin was dealing with the situation of New Zealand and making the comparison with the introduction of a goods and services tax. He was saying that we were using New Zealand as a model. He said:
New Zealand failed because it did not have a wages policy in its essential restructuring.

He said that the Opposition was to be criticised because it had a policy position that aimed to have inflation down to between 0 and 2 per cent. He went on to say, when he was trying to attack the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Reith, that the introduction of the goods and services tax had resulted in interest rates leaping to 25 per cent and inflation to 19 per cent and that this was the record of the GST. To say that those figures are misleading is to understate the situation to an enormous degree.

I said that they are so misleading as to cause me to believe that he really does not understand how the taxation reforms in New Zealand have impacted on the economy of New Zealand. I would suggest that he read today's international news AAP Bulletin. In it there is a report from Wellington which says:

A better than expected inflation result for the September quarter giving New Zealand an annual rate of 2.2 per cent--the lowest in 28 years--has elated the . . . National Government and animated the financial markets.
New Zealand now had the second lowest inflation rate for OECD countries, just above Denmark at 2.1 per cent, and wholesale interest rates were among the lowest.
They were the words of Finance Minister Ruth Richardson. The article continues:
The Acting Prime Minister Don McKinnon said it was "convincing proof" the Government's economic policies were working.
That is, with 2.2 per cent inflation and the lowest wholesale interest rates. The report goes on to state:

The 2.2 per cent annual rate gave New Zealand a competitive edge on its major trading partners such as Australia . . . , Japan . . . , the United States . . . and Britain . . . Financial markets reacted immediately today to the Statistics Department's release of the September quarter consumer price index showing a rise of 0.4 per cent on the June quarter. It followed CPI rises for the 1991 June quarter of 0.1 per cent (annual 2.8 per cent) and 0.6 in the 1991 March quarter (annual 4.5 per cent).

Reflecting annual inflation of 2.2 per cent--the lowest since 1.9 per cent was recorded in the year to September 1963--it had fallen well below the Reserve Bank's indicative range of 2.5-4.5 per cent set for the end of this year.
In other words, the policy of tax reform is working.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Will all the Kiwis now go back home?

—-And the Irish? The figures as they are set out and provided by the OECD relating to the time both before the GST was introduced in New Zealand and subsequently prove the point which has been made time and again by the Opposition that indeed any inflationary effect incurred by the introduction of a goods and services tax is washed out in four quarters. In other words, the effect was that interest rates were high prior to the introduction of the goods and services tax, that there was a one-off shock and at the end of four quarters it was washed out to less than the inflation rate that was being experienced prior to the introduction of the taxation reform.

SPEECH.PARA: In the December quarter of 1987--and the GST was introduced in New Zealand on 1 October 1986--inflation fell to 9.7 per cent, having been 11.1 per cent immediately prior to the introduction of GST. It has fallen every quarter since then, until now it is down to 2.2 per cent. The experience is the same in Canada, although it has been introduced in a lesser time. Again, it was a one-off shock that was washed out in four quarters.

The evidence is there for the Treasurer to see. But the way he dealt with the material in his speech leads me to believe that he does not understand the way those figures ought to be read. Further in his speech he says that our policy approach is unfair, narrow and regressive. In another part of his speech he goes on to say that we do not have a policy. Then he contradicts himself further by saying that we are recycling policies. Clearly, he does seem to be the three wise monkeys all rolled into one and attempts to neither see, speak nor hear evil. The fact of the matter is that he is totally confused. He thinks that we have no policy, that we are recycling policy or that we have an unfair policy.

The fact of the matter is that our reform policies in the taxation area are designed to bring about a logical and equitable tax system, to bring down the dependency that we have on direct taxation and to ensure that the wholesale sales tax--the Government's GST, the Government's secret tax--is abolished in all its unfairness, illogical requirements and the way it falls as a burden upon exports. It is designed, along with industrial relations reform and true micro-economic reform--not just talking about it, but actually doing--to see a change in the direction that Australia will take. In his speech, Mr Kerin says:
There is talk of the recession.

The next paragraph says that we have to understand that it was not really all our fault. But Mr Keating, when he was Treasurer, told us that this was the recession that we had to have and that it was tailor-made by this Government. Mr Kerin might want to be Pontius Pilate and wash his hands of it, but I am afraid that is not possible. He says:
In hindsight, the world's reaction to the 1987 stock market crash was too much.

It was not the Government's fault; it was the world that did it. Our response, of course, was the Labor Government's response. The Labor Government's response put us into recession ahead of the rest of the world. He says of the Labor Party Government:
We swapped a tight fiscal policy for what could be seen, with hindsight, as a too soft monetary policy.

The then Treasurer, Mr Keating, kept telling us that we were going to have a soft landing. He kept telling us not to worry, and many people did not. That was quite in line with the practice that he had indulged in before when the then Premier of New South Wales was going to an election. To accommodate that election, the Treasurer brought down interest rates for a short time whereby he thought he would be assisting the Premier to get re-elected. He failed, and Australia paid the price. Mr Kerin says:
State governments now come to us for funds for redundancy programs as they straighten out their public infrastructure.

That is certainly true of Victoria, and the Labor States are the ones that are in a mess. It is the Labor States where the economy is in the worst recession. Mr Kerin should not try to cover it up by saying that policies which are out of the Liberal stable are tainted with the same infamy as those out of the Labor Party. Then he goes on to say of the Labor Party:
We are the ones who have taken the hard decisions in welfare reform.

Yet earlier in his speech, Mr Kerin was at great pains to criticise Dr Hewson for his plain speaking about the attitude that we have to welfare, which is to target it, so that the people who really have the need receive it and that it is not spread out amongst those who do not require it, but find it a nice comfortable cushion as well. Targeting of welfare is an important policy. In the same speech, Mr Kerin wants to have it both ways. He wants to say that we are the hard-hearted ones, but he wants to claim the credit for having made the hard decisions.
On the question of investment, Mr Kerin says very confidently:
We know that we will get continuing investment in the mining sector.

Do we? There are many projects which are held up because of the deals that the Labor Party did with the Greens. There are many deals that would go ahead that Australia would prosper from, but they are impeded by the political will of the incumbent Government.
Then, of course, we come to the question of tax again. Mr Kerin says:
The Deputy Leader of the Opposition says that there is a tax on investment.

He says that he does not quite know what it means; I believe him. I believe him when he says that he does not quite know what it means because his entire speech shows that he does not quite understand what the portfolio is all about. The fact of the matter is that Senator Button understands more. He wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and said that our tax system was an impediment. After questions here from people on this side of the House, Senator Button went all coy and would not tell us what he meant. But we get a clue from a speech that was made by Dr Bell, who is a Deputy Secretary in the Minister's Department. Being an honest, toiling public servant, Dr Bell gave an address to a particular conference. This was reported in the press, and I directed some questions about this address to Dr Bell and Senator Button during the Estimates hearings. I asked whether I could have a copy of the speech. In the speech, Dr Bell actually said that we needed a consumption tax; he said that we needed tax reform. Although this is not the full text of the speech given, because I am told in the accompanying note that this is an outline of the speech that Dr Bell gave, I would like to quote what I think are two very important paragraphs. I am sure it is in agreement with the letter that Senator Button has written to the Prime Minister. He says:
Many elements of the micro-economic reform program are relevant
. . . need to consider a technology policy from this viewpoint.
Time permits me to address only one of these issues today.
That is, micro-economic reform. He said:

Australian exporters are significantly disadvantaged by our indirect taxes. GATT countries with value-added taxes are able to rebate these to exporters. In these countries, value-added tax is usually the major indirect tax. In Australia, recent federal fiscal restraint has forced our States to levy a variety of indirect taxes.
He then goes on to say:

DITAC calculations suggest that our current tax regime puts Australian exporters at a 5% (average) disadvantage vis-a-vis their international competitors. Five per cent may not sound much, but when transport costs on the costs of capital are taken into account the balance is often tipped against major new technology-based projects going ahead in Australia. Micro-economic factors can play a significant role in inhibiting economic growth.
Indeed, Dr Bell is quite right. He frequently says in this outline of the speech that he gave that we require changes in our taxation system; it requires a competitive tax regime.
Going back to Mr Kerin, he says:
The Opposition does not have one skerrick of alternative policy. We have not seen one detail of its policies and nothing has been said about the future of Australia.

I said he wanted to be the three wise monkeys rolled into one, and obviously his favourite is to hear nothing. Quite clearly, the Opposition has spelt out its aim and vision for Australia: to restore the standard of living that this Government has seen go into decline; to see that we have the important tax reform; to see that we have a lowering of marginal rates of tax so that we lessen the dependency that we have on direct taxation which comes out of the taxpayers' pocket at source, so the taxpayer will have some discretion about the way in which he contributes to the taxation system via an indirect goods and services tax which would replace that hidden government tax--the wholesales sales tax; and to see that we put in place and announce a compensation package for those people who cannot benefit from the reformed tax system.

I say to Mr Kerin and to all members of the Government that not only have we spelt out in great detail very many of our policies, such as industrial relations reform, but also in the area of dealing with the question of taxation reform there are three important elements to come. But as I have explained, we needed to find the data that was necessary in order to get the sums right. We could not possibly have relied on the Government's 1990-91 Budget because, very simply, our figures would have been out to the same degree that the Government's were. So we had to wait until we got the actual figures for 1990-91 before we had any reliable raw data with which to deal. Soon, in the period ahead, we will have three additional pieces of information--the rate of tax, the size of the tax cuts and the shape of the compensation package--which will fit neatly with the outline and express detail of the way in which tax reform will work under a coalition government.

I want to raise one more matter--a matter that was raised in this House today. During the adjournment debate last night, Senator Colston gave a ruling that I was not able to use the word `misled' in connection with my statement that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) had misled the Senate. I have to take issue with Senator Colston's explanation. Senator Colston said:
. . . it is important that any example of unparliamentary language be considered in its context.
I agree with that and that is exactly what this statement does not do. He went on to say:
While I accept Senator Hill's point that the word `misled' is not itself unparliamentary, I draw attention to the context in which Senator Bishop used the word.
He continued:

She had indicated that the Minister had "quite deliberately set up a question from Senator Crowley with the direct objective of maligning Robe River Mining". She then went on to say that she had taken a point of order at the time Senator Cook rose to answer the question, as to whether the Minister was speaking as a Minister of the Crown or as a paid up union employee. In that context, therefore, I considered that Senator Bishop's use of the word "misled" implied deliberate misleading.

That is where I must take issue with the statement. I refer to pages 1964 and 1965 of last night's Hansard. I set out very clearly in the first part of my speech the fact that Senator Cook had indeed set up a question to be asked by Senator Crowley for the specific purpose of putting material on the record that would malign Robe River Mining. He did not answer the question off the top of his head; he did it with a briefing note and with his notes clearly in front of him--it was planned and quite deliberate. That is where I will use the word `deliberate'.
However, I then went on to talk about the attempts that the Government had made to get rid of the legislation concerning secondary boycotts. I went on to say:
It was interesting that, in asking questions, Senator Crane--
whose question I had also referred to at the beginning of the speech--
gave Senator Cook the opportunity to correct his record. Senator Crane spoke in the Thursday lunchtime debate and outlined where Senator Cook had misled the Senate.

In other words, my statement relating to the misleading of the Senate related to the speech which Senator Crane had given in the Senate and was simply a recital of the facts. The Deputy President, in his quaint terms, said he `counselled' me. The Hansard shows that he said:
Order! It is not proper to impute an improper motive of misleading the Senate, Senator Bishop. You might be able to say it slightly differently.

I went on to say that I was proceeding to show, as a matter of fact, that the Minister had misled the Senate. Senator Bolkus then intervened and asked that the ruling be upheld. The Deputy President again said:

It is not proper to accuse a Minister of misleading the Senate. Senator Bishop, you may wish to say that he may have misled the Senate or inadvertently misled the Senate, but I will not permit you to say that a Minister misled the Senate.

Quite frankly, I would not have any idea whether it was inadvertent or otherwise. I could not possibly say that. I went on to explain the difficulty that such a ruling would make working in this Parliament impossible. In his statement, Senator Colston dismissed what took place with the following:
After some cross-chamber discussion, I suggested that Senator Bishop continue her speech.
I said:

I heard your ruling, Mr Deputy President, but I heard you rule that I may not say that the motives of the Minister were improper. The motives and the statement I made about the misleading stand apart. One can mislead the Senate without improper motives or with improper motives. As I understand your ruling, you said I may not say he misled the Senate with improper motives. Perhaps I can deal with the misleading on the basis of not commenting on whether or not his motives were proper or improper.

In other words, at no stage did my statement that Senator Cook had misled the Parliament relate to his motives. It was simply retailing a statement of fact. I then went on to say where he had made the error.

The reason I have chosen to raise this matter at this stage is that if I let Senator Colston's statement remain unchallenged, I would be acquiescing in a conclusion that I had somehow insinuated or implied `deliberate misleading'--to quote the statement--and I am afraid, on the facts, that that is not borne out. Therefore, I must correct the record.

Finally, I must say that since the Budget was brought down, the Government has indulged in antics in response to very adverse criticism. We have seen nothing which shows that the Government is, in any way, shape or form, in command of the direction of the economy. It is in no way in command of setting policy initiatives which will allow this country to survive with its standard of living intact.

Very simply, the reforms that the coalition has outlined in much detail--industrial relations reform, taxation reform and micro-economic reform--mean that people, when they go to the polls, will have something to vote upon which will give them hope that we can indeed turn this economy around. It can no longer be left in the hands of those opposite--particularly in the hands of a Treasurer who clearly does not understand the direction that the economy is taking or the part that he could play which might lead to a better path.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have sat here and listened to a fairly remarkable contribution from Senator Bishop. I did not set out to say this, but it was a bit wayward--indeed, if I were to leap to understand the state of Senator Bishop's mind, and I am not sure that I would want to, I might suggest that it was very dubious--for her to come into this place last night and accuse me of being a pawn, which I presume is spelt `pawn' and not `porn'. Why would Senator Bishop want to call me a pawn?
—-Were we supposed to clap?

—-No, Senator Bishop was not supposed to clap, but she had the opportunity to tell me why she would want to lag off anybody who came within cooee of her eye. Why would Senator Bishop want to say that I am a pawn of Senator Cook's, without my concluding that she was at least of a negative mode?

SPEECH.PARA: To say this is not a kindness; it is actually to impute motive and intent to people. Indeed, it goes immediately to the heart of what the Deputy President ruled that Senator Bishop was guilty of. Senator Bishop stood up in here and said, `I wish to dispute that ruling because I never at any stage wanted to impute motive to people' and then clearly said that I am a pawn of Senator Cook's. I suggest it is not drawing a long bow at all to say that she was deliberately trying to impute bad motives to people, and generously included all sorts of folk in her imputation of motives.

I refer Senator Bishop to the standing order--I cannot be sure of its number because we have had an updating of the Standing Orders and new numbering--which says that whether you say `misleading' or not, you may not impute motive to people. Senator Bishop is beginning to polish this imputation of motive to an art form. She is very good at suggesting that everybody else is doing things, and she can even tell them why they are doing them. She has just done an extraordinary hatchet job of imputation of motive to the Treasurer (Mr Kerin). She knows, apparently, what he thinks. I have to say that it does not do Senator Bishop any good at all.

If I were to get back into the chess mode with respect to Senator Bishop referring to me as Senator Cook's pawn, I would remember that the bishop on the chess board, by and large, does her killing on the diagonal, and that is a pretty devious way to approach things. It is not honourable of Senator Bishop to lag off me en passant last night--with no mention or reference notifying me. For the record, I wonder whether Senator Bishop actually informed Senator Colston that she was going to stand up and say those things or should he, inadvertently, have to find them out? That is not graceful.

Senator Bishop asks me to believe that the Opposition has the tax package which will change the face of Australia. I refer again to the Budget documents and some other comments of Senator Bishop's. The comments were along the lines of, `I know what is best', which is probably an even wilder claim than imputing motive to people. She told us that the Opposition's tax policy--which we all know about, except the details of it--will be the salvation of this country. That is best refuted by a little poem which has the line, `Oh let us never doubt what nobody is sure about'. Senator Bishop seems to be absolutely sure about something of which we have no detail, and she is not going to give us any detail either.

Senator Bishop has said some fairly fierce things about the wholesale sales tax, suggesting that it is tax by stealth and other comments of that ilk. She has not told us that one of the facts about the wholesale sales tax is that it is a very administratively efficient tax and that it would be collected at a much lower cost than the goods and services tax. That is not put on the board. If we are telling the truth, let us tell the whole truth, otherwise let us say, `You are not going to tell us yet what you are going to do with the goods and services tax, so it is really very peculiar that we should be debating it'.

It is also interesting that Senator Bishop mentioned New Zealand and the fact that the inflation rate is down there. Senator Bishop should tell us about employment; tell us about how much people are getting if they are on welfare; tell us about how much trouble pensioners are now in because their payments are so much less; and tell us, too, what the Opposition is planning to cut in terms of government expenditure under its policy proposals. It is dangerous of Senator Bishop to urge us to take note of how the Opposition's policies will save this country when, by and large, they are still unknown, not detailed or finalised, and certainly not available to the Australian community to have a long, hard look at. There is much that could be said about Senator Bishop's contribution and probably it is best that we bypass it.

I want to comment on the changes in the Budget that go to the needs of families, and low income families, particularly the increase in the family allowance supplement. I believe that my colleague Senator Burns mentioned this and perhaps others did too. It is a payment of such importance that I have to comment on it now. It is very important for people in the community, particularly low income families, to know what assistance the Government will provide for them, not only during tough times but also at any other time.

I have been interested to see the effort with which this Government has tried to make those rights, services and facilities available to people, together with information about them, so that people will be able to exercise their options to take up those facilities and provisions.

I know that the Opposition in this place has, on occasion, accused the Government of the wilful wasting of dollars when, for example, it has spent money on advertising social security benefits. The Opposition has wanted to pour scorn on the Government for informing people of the provisions that are available to assist them. I would have thought that if members of the Opposition had actually talked to the recipients of the family allowance supplement they would know just what help it has been to low income families and pensioners. It is a wonderful payment which covers people moving from a pension into the work force--it is designed to counter the poverty trap that people are caught in as they move off pensions into the work force.

It is a payment that has been well taken up, and it is important that people notice the changes. The income test for those in receipt of maximum benefits under the family allowance supplement will be increased from $18,000 to $19,300. This will raise the income threshold for the maximum benefit to align it with the indexed Austudy threshold. This means that a family with two children, earning $20,000 a year, will be eligible for family assistance payments up to $97 a week free of tax--an increase of up to $12.50 per week. For people in that income range, that increase will be of great assistance. Most importantly, I hope that families who will be eligible will know that they are eligible, and will not forget to inquire about their access to that assistance from the Government.

The other changes in terms of payments for families will be administered differently. It is proposed that they will all be paid as one payment to the carer of children--usually the mother. We also know--the facts have not changed at all but are continually confirmed--that the mother, when getting that money for her children, in large part spends it on the children compared to what has occurred in the past when payments to the family or to the father were, invariably, not spent on the children. The targeting of the payment to the mother ensures that the benefits for the children will get through to the children. It is important to stress that in relation to this Budget because of the increased payments which will be made to families on low incomes which will provide very important assistance.

The Budget also provides increased opportunities for training and education. I have heard my Opposition colleagues in this place seek to make mincemeat of the Government for providing education and training opportunities. Opposition members have tried to suggest that such action is in lieu of unemployment benefits. Even if that criticism were true, I believe that it is an acceptable comment. If this Government has focused people's minds on training and education rather than on their being unemployed, surely that in itself is a huge benefit. In particular, it is important that we stress the benefits of training and education, and not just look at short term actions in terms of unemployment benefits. Certainly, we should look at the longer term. We know from all the studies that people who are better trained and who have any kind of tertiary training, skill or education have better opportunities for employment, and once in employment access to better paid jobs.

The importance of these factors cannot be overlooked. Since assuming office this Government has increased higher education places by around 100,000--from 250,000 in 1983 to 350,000 in 1991. There will be further increases in 1992, particularly to address the number of youngsters who are now leaving school and wanting to go on to tertiary education. In some ways we are now facing the further demand on outlays that comes from the success of this Government's encouragement for young people to stay in school through to year 12. The figure of 30 per cent relating to such people when we came into office has now risen to 60 per cent for all States, except in the Australian Capital Territory where I think the figure is in the region of 80 per cent. In other words, there has been a dramatic increase in the number of young people staying to year 12. Consequently, there will be a significant increase in the demand on tertiary training places, whether in terms of universities, colleges or TAFE courses around the country. The Government has allocated extra money in this Budget to deal with that increased demand. I think that it is a matter of real celebration that so many Australians want to proceed to further education. We should be encouraging that education, its range, diversity and quality rather than carping about whether it is in lieu of unemployment.

I wish to say a few words about the increasing impetus of the science and technology part of the Budget. A number of cooperative research centres have now been established; indeed, a total of 45 or so will be established over a three-year period. I understand that 15 or so were established last year and are beginning to become fully functional. Cooperation between the educational institutions, research institutions and industry is beginning to happen. I think that in the short term we will see a considerable return to Australia on this investment in science and technology and the industrialisation of research and development.

We must not underestimate how wonderful this country's research achievements have been. We should be extremely proud of Australia's history in research. Our capacity to turn our research skills and talents into export dollars for this country falls short of the record of research itself. However, I am delighted to see the continued impetus and dollar commitment to the promotion of that kind of return through investment in our research, as well as university investment in the intelligence and capacities of our researchers.

Some of the programs are aimed particularly at encouraging young people, girls as well as boys, into the study of science and technology at school so that they can develop those areas in their university lives. These areas are still underdeveloped, and I look forward to the prospects brought about by those changes in the next five to 10 years. I shall also be interested to keep a close eye on the outcome of the new investment in science and technology. I would hate to think that our research was confined only to the industrial development of science and technology. I strongly support this Government's initiatives in insisting on research as much into arts and cultural matters as into the scientific disciplines. There is much that is interesting and exciting in this Budget. It is a great pity to have to listen to negative comments such as those made by Senator Bishop. Therefore, I am pleased to put my comments on the record.
