SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I rise to speak tonight in the debate on the Appropriation Bills as shadow Minister responsible for three separate portfolio areas, namely, defence, science and personnel, veterans' affairs and the status of women. In the brief time that is available tonight, I want to raise issues of importance in each of those three portfolio areas and especially matters of great concern to me.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, I turn to the budget for the Department of Defence. This year the Defence budget has been dominated by the results of the force structure review which were announced by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) in May. As a result of that statement, we are now facing the replacement of regular units by the Ready Reserve. This is probably the most momentous decision that this Government has made in terms of Australia's long term future. That statement will have a lasting effect on the defence of Australia. We now see the results in this Budget.

I say that it is a momentous decision because I fear that we are now on the first step of a route that will take us down the track that Australia took leading into the middle and late 1930s. By the time we were facing a second world war, we had a cadre force which was barely professional, severely depleted, had a very low morale and was having great difficulty in trying to raise and train a defence force to fight for Australia. I say that very advisedly and carefully because, when the Minister announced that there would be an abolition of regular units to be replaced by ready reserve units, he foreshadowed that there would be a review of that decision in a couple of years. That review would be with a view to seeing what other regular units could be translated into ready reserve units. I very much fear that this is just the first step in a long term plan to reduce us once again to a cadre defence force.

If the Government believes that we are now in a time of peace and that this is all leading up to some marvellous peace dividend, the Government is living in cloud-cuckoo-land. With the retreat, if you like, of the super powers from our region, small powers see opportunities for their own aggrandisement, for their own future empires and for power.

Countries in our region are believed to have nuclear capabilities, some countries are spending considerable money on arming their defence forces, while others are narrowing the technological gap between themselves and us. I do not want to be considered to be a warmonger, but it is in Australia's interests that that technological edge is maintained. It is in Australia's interests not only that we maintain a technological edge but also that we maintain a highly qualified defence force which is able to defend Australia with the new technology.

If anything was learnt from the Gulf war, it is that technology is wonderful if a country wants to win a war but, in order to make that technology work, it must have highly trained, very experienced, professional people. I fear that one outcome of the force structure review will be diminished experience levels, morale and numbers in our defence force. Numbers are not the be-all and end-all. We no longer need hundreds of thousands of people to fight with hundreds of thousands of people. But a rule of thumb that does not seem to be out of fashion is that 3 : 1 is a good ratio for ensuring that a country has the numbers to defend itself. However, I am not looking at questions of numbers but at the quality of the force that is needed to defend this country.

On Sunday, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mr Bilney, told the Australian Defence Association in Melbourne in my presence that the outcome of the force structure review will be a better defence effort. If ever there was a fatuous statement and one destined and designed, one presumes, to mislead, it was that. Certainly the Minister's statement would have misled any other audience, but those present were people who are extremely concerned and interested in defence, and they were not misled by it.

What is the real position? Let us just ask ourselves five questions to test the Minister's statement and the enormity of the decisions that are taken. I do not want to go into the details of the force structure review tonight; that is not my purpose. I did that when the Minister made his statement in May and I have been doing it around the country since. The Minister said that the outcome of the force structure review will be a better defence effort.

A question we have to ask ourselves is: has the force structure review improved our readiness and our ability to quickly get away to defend our country or our interests? Clearly, the answer to that question has to be no. When two out of the only six regular battalions which this country possesses are removed, the ability of a professional, highly trained force to get away quickly to defend our national interests is diminished by one-third. There is no doubt that we are trying to replace those two regular battalions with manpower that has had one year's professional training--I acknowledge that it will be professional training--and then part time soldiering 50 days a year for four years thereafter, which is useful and valuable but in no way can be equated to somebody training for the entire year. After the four years, the value of that training quickly diminishes. So their readiness must be compromised.

When we look at putting a force in the field, we look to see how long we can keep it there, how quickly we have to replace it and how soon it gets tired and needs reinforcing. We usually work on the basis that, for every battalion that is given a job to do, an army needs three battalions--one coming into the front to fight, one retiring from the front and one resting and getting ready to go in again. When we had six battalions, that was possible. It meant that we could deploy two battalions. By removing two of the six, we are now in a position where we could really only deploy one battalion in a sustainable fashion. There is just no getting away from that basic military rule. We have reduced the sustainability of our fight.

The next question one asks is: has the force structure review improved our technology? One might be tempted to say yes. After all, these cuts in the Defence budget and the changes being made are being made because the capital equipment procurement program has so blown out the budget that personnel, training and operating costs have had to be squeezed. So, in one sense, we could say yes, this will be to the benefit of the technology; of course that is important.

However, in another sense, it is not to the benefit of technology because we will have this enormous bulge caused by the Collins class submarines and the Anzac frigates all going through the Defence budget during the same decade and pushing out of the way other projects that are of great importance to Australia's defence. By other projects, I am thinking of the airborne and early warning aircraft, mine countermeasures and perhaps a helicopter support ship in order for us to deploy forces where airfields, et cetera, are perhaps occupied around our coastline. It may be a question of saving the Cocos (Keeling) Islands or Christmas Island; it may be the need some day to deploy off the coast of Papua New Guinea to help our neighbour; or it may be to save some of our nationals in islands in the Pacific. Whatever it is, those and other items of technology are denied to us because of the mishandling, until now, of the Defence budget.

We ask ourselves: has the force structure review improved leadership in the Defence Force? I say sadly that in the long term it will not. I also believe it will have a deleterious effect on leadership. There is an increasing emphasis on the need for Defence Force officers to be good managers, and that is right and proper. Particularly in peace time, there is a need for management of great budgets and management of great resources. But defending a country is not all about management; it is also about leadership. In war time, the leadership role takes prominence.

If we expect ever to need to commit forces to defend this county or our national interests, we need leaders of people. I fear that, by cutting out a substantial proportion of the officers and senior NCOs, particularly in our Army, down the track those people will no longer be around. They will not have had the experience at middle ranking or more junior levels. They will not be around when government may need very experienced and highly trained personnel. They will not be around to give the sort of advice that governments need in a time of emergency. They will not be around to lead a force. We could all be the poorer in every respect for that.

The final question we should ask is: has the force structure review improved morale in our Force? The answer, sadly, whether we are talking about the Regular Force or the existing Reserve Force, is no. The existing Reserve Force will feel very much the Cinderella of the defence forces of Australia. It is already underequipped. Last year, there were insufficient man days for the jobs, the roles, it had been given, yet we find in this year's Budget that cuts of 5.8 per cent have been made in man days for training the existing Reserve. Clearly, that money has been put aside to contribute towards the enormous cost to the budget of the Ready Reserve. It will be very clear to existing reservists who may even be working in civilian employment, side by side with a ready reservist, that the Ready Reserve has come into being at the expense of the existing reserves who have served this country long and loyally--those who already have a full time job and give up some of the time that they would otherwise spend with their family or on their personal interests to make sure that this country has a better chance to survive in times of war. The existing reserves can see very well what is happening to the limited resources that are available--and they are not going to get them.

The regulars are concerned about the future of their careers in a full time regular professional force. At the moment, they are economic conscripts because, with high unemployment, they do not see a great deal of future in getting out of the Defence Force to go to `civvy street'. Even now, it is interesting to see how many are still leaving the Defence Force, notwithstanding that we are facing times of high unemployment. There is a great correlation between the unemployment rates and the wastage rates from the forces. In good and bad times, we can see pretty clear correlations. Nevertheless, the resignations from the forces are still too high--surprisingly so when one considers the employment situation outside. On all these tests, the Government's changes to the defence of Australia will have a serious and long term effect, about which we should be very concerned.

In the limited time I have tonight I wish to speak about the two other portfolio areas for which I have responsibility. I want to deal quickly with two issues of importance in the veterans' portfolio. First, the Government talks very carefully about the integration of repatriation hospitals. It all sounds nice and clean and clinical and as though it could not hurt anybody. What we should be talking about is the hand over of the hospitals, the welshing on the veterans and the failure to keep bargains with the veterans.

Both in this place and outside, over many months, I have been quoting the promises made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) over three years that veterans will not be disadvantaged by the handing over of their repatriation hospital system to the State systems. The veterans know what is happening week by week in States around Australia: hospital systems are crumbling and are in chaos. Veterans are being forced out, shunted out, of their repatriation hospitals to join the queues in the public hospital systems of the States of Australia. I remind the Parliament of what the Minister for Veterans' Affairs said in Parliament in November 1988:
The integration of the repatriation hospital systems will not take place until all of the concerns of the veterans' community are dealt with. That is an unequivocal guarantee. . .

We cannot have it much clearer than that. The Prime Minister has made that promise in similar terms. Yet the Government is continuing to rush like a bulldozer down the track to hand over these hospitals while the veterans' organisations still have unsatisfied questions waiting to be answered. They are still not convinced that they will have any sort of priority of access in the hospital system that is being offered to them. They have no confidence that the quality of care to which they have been accustomed--and which has been theirs as of right as compensation for their war service--will remain after this Government hands over their hospitals.

In the Estimates Committee we heard that the Government has spent $358,906.81 on trying to persuade the veterans that the hand over is in their interests. If it really were in their interests, one would think that it would be very easy to tell the veterans and that they would start queuing for a new and better system. But this Government has had to spend money on mailing house costs, direct mail to veterans, and direct mail to local medical officers and specialists. The Government has sent out all sorts of propaganda leaflets from the States to the veterans organisations. The Government has distributed a brochure full of cartoons which has offended so many veterans and war widows. They have complained to me that they are being treated as stupid children who have had to be convinced of something by the value of cartoons. If ever there were a tasteless, expensive and unacceptable exercise, it is this $358,906.81 spent on trying to convince the veterans that getting rid of their hospitals will be good for them. The Government has failed on that, and unless it is prepared to take careful notice of the veterans' very justifiable concerns it will not get to first base with them. The Government will be shown up for making promises that it had no intention of keeping. Sadly, this Government has developed a tremendous reputation for making promises that it never intended to meet.

I also want to speak briefly about the failure of the claims system. After all these decades of a repatriation system, we still have a system which is not adequately meeting the needs of veterans. Just recently in the Parliament, the annual report of the Veterans Review Board was presented. The report contained pretty clear evidence of the tremendous waste of taxpayers' funds; of decisions, taken in the first instance by the delegate of the Repatriation Commission, being overturned in alarming numbers when they go on appeal to the Veterans Review Board. One thinks of the great waste of time and money and the stress and strain on older men and women who have fought for their country and the war widows who have lost their husbands through the husband's service to the country. It is long overdue that we develop a claims system which is humane, speedy, caring, non-adversarial and non-legalistic--whatever one would like to say. There are better ways of doing it and it is incredible that all this way down the track we are being so uncaring towards to our veterans and so prepared to waste taxpayers' money.

Only today in the Canberra Times there is a report about Mrs Whetton, who has finally achieved war widow status, five years after she was widowed. Her husband was severely injured in the Second World War and he died in 1986. She fought all the way to have her eligibility decided. She finally got a decision by a single judge of the Federal Court. Then, would you believe it, Mr Deputy President, the Repatriation Commission--all heart--appealed against the decision of the Federal Court judge and took her to the Full Court. I am glad to say that Mrs Whetton had the guts and the determination to persevere and she won in the Full Court.

This is not the sort of repatriation system that Australians should be proud of. The benefits are not bad by comparison with world standards, but the system is wretched. Too many people are put through this test. What worries me more than anything is the number of veterans who, unfortunately, have not claimed for their entitlements to compensation for their war service in all the years since the Second World War. Now they are perhaps in their seventies and are saying that they need some help. So they ask for a determination and are knocked back. Many of those people refuse to appeal.

We know from the Veterans' Review Board report that veterans have at least a 50 per cent chance of winning an appeal. Veterans in Western Australia have about a 70 per cent chance and those in Queensland a 60 per cent chance. Clearly, they have a very good chance of winning if they go on to appeal, but they are so disgusted and so hurt by the rejection that they do not appeal. I feel very sad that this country can preside over such a system. It is time that something was urgently done to help our veterans and war widows.

I want to speak in the minutes remaining on a couple of issues relating to the status of women. First, I want to raise the question of access to mammography for all Australian women, including those in the country. We have too many deaths in this country of women who have not had breast cancer detected early. Many hundreds of cases each year, something like 370, could be prevented with early detection.

For three years before the last election, the Government had in place a pilot mammography screening program in most, but not all, States--there was no program in Tasmania, for example. When it came to the election, the Opposition said that it would have a national screening program. In came big mouth, the Prime Minister, promising that he would spend $64m over the first three years of a five-year program to introduce a national screening program for breast cancer.

In last year's Women's Budget Statement for 1990-91, the Government allocated a sum of $20m for expenditure in the first year. What do we find now? We find in this year's Women's Budget Statement that the Government actually spent $1m. It is now 18 months since the Prime Minister made his promise and $1m has actually been spent. This coming year, $18.7m has been allocated in the Women's Budget Statement. One wonders just how much is going to be spent this year to save women's lives in this country. Are women's lives expendable? If the Prime Minister's wife had breast cancer, I wonder how much more urgent he might have considered a program which seemed so desirable to him at election time, but which was so quickly put on the back-burner.

I am intrigued also by the wording in the Women's Budget Statement this year when referring to the national program for the early detection of breast cancer. It is really rather coy. It says that some $1m was provided for the program in 1990-91 and that $18.7m has been allocated for 1991-92. Of course, it is not true to say that $1m was provided for the program in 1990-91. In fact, $20m was provided for the program, of which only $1m was spent. So much for the honesty of the Women's Budget Statement which I notice blew out from an already overblown document last year of 240 pages to a 414-page document this year. I think that must take the cake as one of the most overblown pufferies that the Government has been able to produce at Budget time.

It is not by the number of pages in the Women's Budget Statement that women in Australia will judge this Government. They will judge this Government by the services it provides, the care it gives to its citizens, the promises that it keeps or it breaks and the economy that it heals. It is judged already for the economy that it has left in such a mess. What will it do to try to right that wrong done to all the people in Australia?

The final issue I raise tonight that is of concern to women is the question of the Telecom 0055 telephone numbers. This Government has made much of its concern about the portrayal of women in advertising and the media. Many women in Australia find a lot of the advertising sexist and offensive. In many respects, I sympathise with the view. But if I were to set a priority for giving governmental attention to the portrayal of women in this country, it would be the portrayal of women in pornography and the growing, burgeoning industry which is degrading women of Australia, affecting the innocence of our children, changing the culture of our society, silencing, if you like, the good families of Australia who are being made to feel that there is something not very smart about complaining about pornography wherever they find it. They are being cowed into silence.

There is developing an acceptance of pornography, yet many people find it abhorrent. Parents worry about the long term desensitising effect pornography will have on their children, yet this Government lifts not a finger. Indeed, it takes money from it. This Government is indirectly achieving many millions of dollars in revenue from Telecom 0055 numbers.

As you will know, Mr Deputy President, this is an issue I have been pursuing for well over a year now. Today I received an answer from Senator Collins representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley. I asked questions about Telecom's new contractual agreement with service providers of the recorded telephone messages. That new agreement was supposed to have been effective for two weeks from 1 October.

I asked whether the Minister would confirm that adult messages previously available under the 0055 prefix had been moved to 0051 with limited access using a personal identification number. I also asked, if the answer was yes, how many of those messages had been moved to 0051 and if the answer was no, why was there a delay. I also asked a number of other questions. The Minister's answer was not at all specific. Part of his answer said:

I am advised by Telecom that, as the new arrangements are still in the process of being implemented fully, it is still unclear how many of the services currently on 0055 will need to be transferred to the new 0051 service.

I asked how many had been transferred. He did not address himself to that. Clearly, they have not been moved across. That is the information that was made available to me. I want to know why not. For the last several months we were told that on 1 October they would be transferred. What we find is that these adult messages to go to 0051 are not going to be transferred across by Telecom but only by the service providers and also that Telecom is not going to monitor the content and advertising of any messages until a complaint is raised by a member of the public.

The Minister ends his answer by saying that he is currently awaiting advice from Telecom concerning implementation of the procedures. I say that he and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, Ms Fatin, should have been out on the hustings insisting that a lead be shown by this Government, that Telecom remove these offensive services from the telephone lines of Australia. But this is the Government which has no policies, no morals, no standards, no ability to manage the economy, and cares not a jot or a whit for the people of this country. It deserves condemnation on every score and it will get that at the next election. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I want to reflect upon the stage we have reached after eight years of this Government. It is not unreasonable to ask: does this Government have a proud record of achievement? Can this Government stand on its record? Can this Government be satisfied with the rewards and results of its endeavours? Can the Government tell the average Australian, `You are better off than you were when we were elected in 1983'? Of course, the answer is no.

SPEECH.PARA: After eight years as Treasurer of this country, Mr Paul Keating has the audacity to say that this Government ought to refocus its policies to take account of unemployment. Of course, we know that it was eight years of hard Labor--eight years of his endeavour--that gave us one million unemployed.

It was not as if Australia was afflicted with an unfair fate. It was not as if a circumstance was visited upon us by the rest of the world. It was not as if some aberration has caused us to have one million unemployed. It is the direct and absolute manifestation of this Government's policies that we now have approximately 1.3 million people unemployed.

The great tragedy of this recession, which is going to be ever so difficult to escape from, is that it has touched parts of the work force that to some degree have previously been insulated. I refer, for instance, to the middle management white collar workers whose only skill, whose only qualification, is the experience that they are able to offer. If they are retrenched, they do not have the appropriate qualifications that are needed to obtain another job. Their skills are the years of service that they have given to the company for which they worked and which has had to take down its shingle. The 55-year-olds with two or three children at school, who are paying off their mortgage and who probably will not in their working lifetime be able to get another job, are the sorts of people who have been cast onto the unemployment scrap heap by this Government.

The level of unemployment is the result of deliberate decisions taken by the Government. A decision was made to induce the recession because of the failure of manifest policies. Decisions have been made from day one--the first in 1983-84 to blow out the Budget deficit to allow government sector borrowings to rise by 5.7 per cent. What was Mr Keating's comment? All we got was, `Prepare to hoist full sails for strong growth and recovery'. Of course, that is what we got--but strong growth at any price, without any structural reform in place to be able to absorb the growth that was taking place.

Between 1983 and 1988 private sector credit increased by over 20 per cent. In due course, the Government woke up to the fact that the level of growth could not in any way be sustained; that it was causing enormous imbalances in our current account; that it was piling up foreign debt; that it was driving up inflation; and that there would be cyclical unemployment. Those signals finally were seen by the Government.

But what did the Government do? Immediately prior to the 1987 Federal election, when it looked like being ignominiously dumped from office, the Government jammed down interest rates 6 percentage points. It took this action simply to save itself. That was at a time of already strong demand, which was not even interrupted by the share market crash of 1987. Australia paid a terrible price for rescuing the Government from almost certain defeat.

Then the money supply was let out again. Interest rates were allowed to come down as a result of the forlorn hope of this Government of saving its mates in the New South Wales Government. But nothing could save Mr Unsworth. It was only in late May or early June of 1988, notwithstanding the previous advice from Treasury and the Reserve Bank at the beginning of 1988 to do so, that the Government began to tighten monetary policy.

But the truth of the matter is that the Government had no other policies. No other structural change had been put in place to counter the difficulties that we had as a result of such strong growth. Although we could control the price of funds, because of deregulation there was no longer a capacity to use that instrument to control the quantity of funds. And because of galloping, unattended inflation, we had an assets boom.

Enormous amounts of foreign investment and funds poured into Australia. This money found its way into central business district properties simply because of high inflation and the tax structure. The cost of interest could be written off against profits. Profits were not taxed until they reached a certain level. There was record inflation. We saw an asset purchase binge. Finally, sustained interest rate increases over a long period ensured that the economy ultimately fell over.

The Government did absolutely nothing about the problems. We all know the perverse effects that the high interest rates had. They drove the exchange rate up. At a time when local manufacturers were crippled by high interest rates, this increase in the exchange rate made their capacity to export much more difficult and made imports much cheaper. So at a time when the Government was trying to drive down demand, to choke off imports, it was in a perverse way stimulating these activities.

While 1.4 million jobs were created between 1983 and 1990, Maximilian Walsh made the obvious observation that the jobs were being created where the economy artificially bubbled. We found a significant increase in employment in the consumption areas, wholesale and retail, the service industries and also in property services and construction--all the non-productive areas. When we look at employment growth in those sectors that create wealth for us, pay for our imports and assist with our foreign debt, we find that employment in the mining sector came down and there was only a very marginal increase in the level of employment in the manufacturing sector.

During all this time, while the nominal wage increased by about 6 per cent or 7 per cent because the accords had put a floor under inflation and guaranteed that inflation was unlikely to go below 6 per cent or 7 per cent, the truth of the matter was that the ordinary, average worker suffered a decline in real wages--or had certainly gone through a period of flat wages--all because of the level of inflation. Of course, it is no surprise that Australia's productivity had lagged behind that of the rest of the world, and by 1990 the level of GDP per hour was less than that of 1984 or 1985. The increase in nominal labour costs in Australia was double that of the OECD countries.

It is argued that there had been a slowdown in growth. The truth of the matter is that if we are not comparable with the rest of the world, the level of slowdown is totally irrelevant. Our nominal wage costs increased by 45 per cent between 1984 and 1989 while those for the rest of the OECD countries increased by 20 per cent. In part, that was as a result of the cosy deal between the Government and the ACTU whose prime objective, as best as I can tell, was not the interest of the workers but ensuring that it managed to control labour in Australia.

We have this bizarre uniform rigidity of wage determination spreading across the industries, where management is unable to make any determinations in respect of its capacity to pay the price of labour, or quality of that labour. Everything is subject to determinations in courts a long way from the workplace. Need we ask why Australia's annual productivity growth averaged but 1.1 per cent over the 10 years to 1990--hardly figures likely to create an environment to ensure that Australia could be competitive with the rest of the world.

In respect of matters such as micro-economic reform I will give the ex-Treasurer credit for one confession: between 1987 and 1990 the Government missed its opportunity for micro-economic reform. We see very little improvement now, except for Senator Collins puffing and panting about the very marginalised improvements on the waterfront. Of course, we still see two drivers required to drive a crane with one seat and three levers. That sort of mentality still prevails in Australia but, because there have been some percentage increases in productivity, we are supposed to get excited about them. Until such time as our micro-economic reform provides transport, communications and shipping, to name but three, at world best standards, we will not be competitive.

All this endeavour led ultimately to the levels of bankruptcy that we see in Australia; the 12,991 bankruptcies last year--an increase on the 8,500 the previous year--aggregating to just over 50,000 bankruptcies that have occurred in the life of this Government. We can expect that they will increase. That figure does not include the voluntary liquidations and those businesses that, while surviving, have little more than a nameplate over their businesses.

Is it any surprise that a recent survey by the Confederation of Australian Industry revealed that 90 per cent of respondents viewed current business opportunities as poor, very poor or depressed? Perhaps they meant `depressing', but they said `depressed'. Is it any wonder that the same survey found that 90 per cent of respondents saw investment prospects as poor, very poor or very depressed? In my view, we can expect employment to remain very subdued. For whatever reason not immediately apparent to me, the Government seems optimistic that we will see some growth in employment next year, but given the OECD's prediction for growth in Australia, I would have thought that unemployment will stay very much where it is.

As I say, the results that this Government has achieved have been all its own work. I find it interesting that we now have Senator Button, Mr Kerin, Mr Griffiths and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) talking about fast-tracking projects. It begs the question: what is the intrinsic worth of these projects that requires them to be fast-tracked now, whereas 12 months ago they could not get on the drawing board? Is there something different about the environment? Is there something different about world markets?

TALK.START.PARA: —-The political environment.

—-Senator Alston is absolutely right; it is all about the political environment. Mainstream Australia has had enough of the black, red and green votes--the minority radical groups who have held this Government hostage for so long. Even were those projects to be approved tomorrow, it would be months and months before they would get going. I observe that the figure for mining and minerals projects combined with pulp and paper projects amounts to $8.2 billion. That is a net loss of foreign earnings of $2.92 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: As I say, with Australia's growth likely to be 1.8 per cent at the most next year alongside the 0.2 per cent this year, one cannot be optimistic for the future. The truth of the matter is that nothing has changed. This Government has done nothing except tighten money supply. The only thing this Government could do to bring the economy under control in the short term was destroy jobs, destroy lives, destroy businesses and destroy life's endeavours. The object of that was simply to throttle import demand. What a cruel price the average Australian has paid because this Government has not been prepared to deal with micro-economic reform. It has not been prepared to deal with deregulating the labour market. It has not been prepared to come to grips with the necessity for privatisation. It has not been prepared to come to grips with creating an environment which makes Australia competitive with the rest of the world. At present, diabolical circumstances are prevailing simply because of an incompetent, failed Government which, in my view, has lost its right to govern.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I support the amendment which has been put forward by the Opposition in this debate. I shall not go over the arguments that have been put in favour of it--I support them. I wish briefly to take the time of the Senate tonight to refer to another matter which I hope the Parliamentary Secretary Assisting the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) will respond to when he concludes the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: It arises from the situation of the Buddhists in Vietnam. I want to refer in part to the answer given by the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Dr Blewett) in another place yesterday when he was asked this question:
Can the Minister advise the House of recent significant developments in Australia's aid program to Indo-China?
The Minister dealt with the other matters that the honourable member had raised in his question and then went on to say:

Turning to Vietnam, the Government's decision to resume direct aid restores a very important element in the relationship between Australia and Vietnam. Vietnam is, of course, one of the poorest countries in the world and there is a clear need for aid on both developmental and humanitarian grounds.

The Minister referred to the fact that an Australian programming mission will visit Vietnam looking at possible development projects. He also indicated that he himself would visit Vietnam in November to talk to the Government on questions of aid and of trade. He refers to enabling Vietnam to resume normal membership of the International Monetary Fund and says:
I have been asked what Australia will get in return from Vietnam--
then for some reason which escapes me he says--
a typical question from members of the Opposition.
It is not apparent why he threw that in. He then went on to say:
Firstly, we believe that we have a responsibility to this region.
Secondly, he said that the economic potential of Vietnam and the interest for Australian business are quite significant.

What I want to ask the Minister to do when he goes to Vietnam is to extract from the Vietnamese Government an undertaking that it will refrain from continuing to persecute the Buddhists in that country. There is very good reason to believe that that is still continuing. I am not opposing the resumption of aid to Vietnam but I believe that we ought not to resume that aid without requiring that Government to have some regard for human rights.

There were about 20,000 Buddhist monks and nuns in Vietnam in 1975. By the end of 1988 there were about 5,000 or perhaps a few more if one counts those held in gaol without trial. I wish to mention a few cases: Thich Thien Minh who was killed in 1978 and Thich Tri Thu in 1984 for being critical of the Government; and the Deputy Chairman of the United Vietnamese Buddhist Church National Council, the Most Venerable Thich Huyen Quang and Most Venerable Thich Quang Do, the General Secretary, who were held without charge from 1982 and one of whom at least was very ill for a period.

The United Vietnamese Buddhist Church was formed in 1964 and destroyed by the Communist Government of Vietnam in 1981. I refer also to Thich Duc Nhuan who was imprisoned in 1985 for 15 years; and Thich Tue Sy, a philosopher and writer, together with Thich Tri Sieu, an historian, who were sentenced to death on 30 September 1988. At the time I asked that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, and his Department take the matter up. Eventually, as a result of a great deal of activity, those last two sentences were commuted to a period of 20 years imprisonment. There is clear evidence that those people had been deprived of food and medicine and were not well treated while in custody. Tran Van Luong, a layman, was also sentenced to death in September 1988.

They were all arrested with other Buddhist scholars in April 1984 and then tortured, tried and, as I said, condemned to death. Many other Buddhists were sent to re-education camps and since 1975 they have either been killed or otherwise confined. Clearly, the communist-led government of Vietnam has tried to stamp out religion. It will not succeed, of course, but at the time a great deal of suffering has been imposed.

There are monks, nuns, lay leaders, writers and poets in prison, in labour camps, in re-education camps and held without trial with no regard for human rights. These people are religious leaders who have been held as political prisoners and punished because of their desire for democracy and for freedom of religion in their country. The Australian Government should require the Vietnamese Government to implement a policy of tolerance for religious organisations to enable the United Vietnamese Buddhist Church to resume not only its religious activities but also its educational and charity activities; to return to the church its property; and to allow members of overseas Buddhist organisations to visit their colleagues in Vietnam.

There is no doubt that the aid from Australia will be greatly appreciated. The people of Vietnam have been suffering under communist rule for a very long time and they need to be relieved of that. When the Minister says that he is going to Vietnam and is sending a programming mission to Vietnam, top of the list should be our requirement that this sort of torture and repression of the Buddhists must cease, that the people held in prison must be released and that the practice of the religion must be able to continue. That, as far as I am concerned, is a typical question from a member of the Opposition.

I hope that the Government, while acknowledging, as the Minister said, responsibility to the region and while recognising that there is economic potential for Australian business in Vietnam, will not merely pursue the matter on that basis but use the opportunity to achieve something in this area as well. As I said, I hope that when the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer responds to this debate tonight he will mention this matter. I hope that my remarks will be conveyed to the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development as he pursues the matters that he is taking up in Vietnam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I support all the speakers from this side of the chamber in this debate on Appropriation Bills (No. 1) and (No. 2) and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1991-92. I believe I am the last to speak in this debate on behalf of the Opposition. This Budget debate is an absolute indictment of the entire Hawke Government, which includes every member of the Government because they have all played a part in presiding over the worst economic recession that this country has seen since the Great Depression. But what is worse is that it is a deep recession that has been engineered by both the Hawke-Keating Labor Government and the Hawke-Kerin Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: We have got an economic situation that has been completely paralysed by a lack of direction, incentive and capacity. This Budget, which has just been delivered, is equally lacking in direction, incentive and capacity. In fact, it is just like the Government itself. Once again it has been announced one day and amended the next by the ACTU or some other faction of the Australian Labor Party. Once again we have a Budget that tinkers at the edges but leaves the hard decisions for another time, another day and another government.

It has been called the do nothing, be patient or hang on and hope Budget, although I do not know how long a lot of people will be able to hang on. For the nearly one million Australians on the unemployed scrap heap, there is nothing to hang on to and nothing to hope for. For the young unskilled school leaver, there is no encouragement, no incentive for employers to take on apprentices and, in fact, no jobs and no joy. For the students, more financial obstacles are put in their way, and the higher education contribution scheme is testimony to the inability of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, to tackle structural problems in higher education.

For the 60,000 businesses made bankrupt during the life of the Hawke Government there is also no incentive. For those still in business, the impost of the 5 per cent superannuation tax will result in more unemployment and more small business bankruptcy, and is unlikely to improve retirement income security to any degree. For Australian farmers there is less than nothing and not even the weather is giving them a hand.

We should listen to what ABARE says about the fact that the Australian farming and mining industries are in great strife. The Federal Labor Government is doing absolutely nothing to try to address the problem. ABARE forecasts released back in September basically reconfirmed what the Bureau had been saying continuously for the past 12 months. In short, ABARE said that our earnings from agricultural and mineral exports would fall for the first time in 10 years and the incomes of the hard-pressed farmers would decline even more. Farmers are facing a 24 per cent fall in net farm cash income, on top of a decline of 35 per cent in 1990 and 1991. That is a collapse of nearly 60 per cent in average net farm income over two years. We can all ask ourselves: would any PAYE worker accept a cut in his or her wages of 60 per cent over two years? I think that we can all give the answer to that: we would definitely not expect them to, nor would we want them to. But that is what has happened to the farmers. That is what has happened to the people out there in the broader community and the country communities who earn a lot of the export income for Australia.

We really have to ask ourselves: why is it that the Federal Government is doing absolutely nothing at the moment to help alleviate the situation? It either does not understand or just does not care. I would think that people on the other side of the chamber--the people in the Government--must care; so I would say that they just do not understand or they do not have the ability to understand. Maybe they have not actually been out to see the hardship and the problems in the rural communities at the moment.

Ten years ago, there were 267,000 persons employed in agriculture; last year, there were some 251,000 employed in agriculture. It is predicted that six in every hundred farmers, people employed in agriculture, will not be there next year. I believe it is time for this Government to really take stock of what is happening out there. It may say, `We do not care about it. We do not care at all because there are not a lot of votes in it for the Labor Party out there in the rural and regional areas'. But I am saying that if it lets those people go to the wall, if it lets those people out in the broader country areas go to the economic grave, then Australia will be the loser in the future.

I return to the Budget. In the Age, I think it was Ken Davidson who said that `the Budget is a damning indictment of a decade under Labor'. He talked of the elegant glossing over of the abject policy failures of the past half decade. He suggested that the recession is the direct consequence of gross excesses and that Australia's long term economic problem has been screamingly obvious for at least the past half decade. Basically, the Budget was a document without hope but, even more seriously, it was a document without economic strategy.
Let us look to see what the Morgan gallup poll found when it surveyed people out in the broader community. I quote from the Bulletin:

Few Australians believe the recent federal budget was a good one and most think it will increase unemployment, a special Morgan Gallup Poll has found. Only 4% of voters interviewed in the poll described Treasurer John Kerin's first budget as "good".
It went on to say:

Australians do not see the budget as a solution to the unemployment problem with only 4% (down eight) saying it will reduce unemployment while most (54% up six) believe it will increase unemployment levels. Some 32% (up two) think it will have little effect and 10% can't say, the poll finds.

I would say that the results of that poll of the Australian public were pretty right, because unemployment has gone up. Unfortunately, I believe that it is going to go up further. Out in the wider community there is no real glimmer of hope for people who are investing money. There is no real reason for them to actually put it into something that is going to produce jobs and that is going to produce income. That is a sad thing for Australia. Surely, this Government, the Hawke-Kerin Labor Government, could have thought a bit more about it and put a bit of hope out there in the community.

We have an economy that is in absolute crisis. We have a business community which remains deeply pessimistic about the state of the economy and is reluctant to increase its level of investment expenditure. Yet we have had the Government slapping on a compulsory 5 per cent superannuation levy. The capacity of business to pay that levy is doubtful, but that does not appear to have been included in the calculations. I believe this is going to cause the higher unemployment that I talk about. We have a Treasurer who told us that it was essential to levy a $3.50 Medicare patient fee, but less than a month later that strategy is out the window. Where that leaves the expected shortfall of some $13 billion is anyone's guess.

For the rural sector, there is nothing, despite the teasers put forth by the new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, that there would be some good news. In fact, he talks a lot about value-adding. I am all in favour of value-adding. I saw an industry at Casino the other day. Jerky beef is actually value-adding beef, which I am quite sure you, Mr Acting Deputy President, would have chewed around some of the camp fires in the outback of Queensland when you were on mustering camps. It is a value-adding product which is now being sold to tourists. The Japanese, especially, seem to like it, and it is very nice. It is a source of value-adding. It is producing some jobs. But that was there before any of this talk of value-adding at the moment.

There are not going to be a lot of other people wanting to value-add unless they have the incentive to do it. There is no incentive in the economy at the moment. There was nothing in the Budget that addressed the problem of falling asset prices, higher debt levels and high interest rates. The Budget gave the farming communities and the rural industries in general no incentive at all to invest.

I have been saying in this place for quite some time that the high interest rates that we have had for the last couple of years have really put into the cost structure a level of input costs that is not going to go away tomorrow even if interest rates came down dramatically. That is going to go on for quite some time.

Getting back to the rural communities again, we have the drought on top of this high interest rates structure that is now affecting the input cost; we have a catastrophe about to happen out in the rural areas. It is all right for Senator Loosely to laugh. He lives in a city. He should come out to the bush and see what is happening out there. That will take the smirk off his face, I am quite sure. He will not be laughing about it as much as he is in this chamber at the moment.

Look what happened to a small airline, Hazelton Airlines, because of the rural recession and the lack of incentive to build that third runway. I think Senator Loosley is actually in favour of the third runway, so I will have to give him a bit of praise for that. After eight years, we are sort of getting closer to a decision. But a lot of his colleagues are trying to stop the building of that third runway. That is not going to help Australia. That is not going to help New South Wales--the State that Senator Loosley and I represent. So I hope that Senator Loosley jumps on and gives a bit of kneecapping to some of his parliamentary colleagues who represent electorates around that airport so that that runway definitely gets built.

Where is there anything in this Budget that will repay the moneys raised either in the Loan Bill that we have already debated or in any other way? There is no incentive for the primary producers, the manufacturers or, indeed, for any of the income generating sectors of this country. Before the Budget there was no incentive and there is still no incentive. How long can we last as an Australian community without direction and some indication that not only is there a tunnel, but also there will be a little light at the end of that tunnel? If we do not have that direction and incentive there will be no jobs and we will face an absolute catastrophe as far as unemployment is concerned. People will walk off farms and out of businesses. They will say, `Stuff it. Why should we risk investing money until things get right?'. If people think things will improve they may invest money, but they have been given such a kick in the backside over the last eight years that I doubt whether they would want to do it under this Government.

Only last month, the Australian Wheat Board announced revised projections for the coming season's harvest. I have been talking to people in Queensland and people in the north-west of New South Wales whose crops have failed and the harvest will be down dramatically. The other day I visited coastal New South Wales. The cane harvest is down dramatically because of seasonal problems and some of the other problems associated with the importation of cheap sugar. It is of no surprise to those of us who are involved in the primary industries that the projections in the wheat area are the lowest for a decade, and they have been made before the full extent of the drought has been actually realised. Tonight I have been talking to people from the Liverpool plains in the near north-west of New South Wales. The crops there are absolutely screaming out for a drink of water. If rain does not come and those crops deteriorate even more, we will face a horrific problem.

The wheat industry has provided export income of around $3 billion, yet not a lot is being done, either by the weather or by this Government, to save it at the moment. At risk are not only our export markets but also some thousands of farmers who, if they are forced off their farms, will join the very long and growing line of people in the unemployment queue. At the moment some people in Queensland are talking about importing wheat for feedlots. If that happens there will be a bit of blood in the streets, especially if wheat is imported from any of the highly subsidised markets around the world so that even the little bit of wheat that people have here does not sell at the free market price in Australia.

What jobs can people find in rural areas where country towns are shrinking and dying? Where will the money come from to pay for the unemployment cheques when people finally give up all notion of keeping the farm? The blow-out so far in the social security budget will be nothing compared with what will happen if this present recession continues for another 12 months. Yet there is no prospect of getting out of this present dilemma for at least that long.

The Budget had to provide incentive, opportunity and hope. It has done none of those things. We needed economic reform measures. We got political meddling by the Reserve Bank of Australia to make the economy look better artificially. We needed structural reform which could lead to job security. We got a Budget designed to secure one job and that was the job of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), and I am not convinced that it will do even that. The Government needed to provide leadership and direction. Already we have seen the Medicare arrangements thrown out of the window because the unelected government of this country, the ACTU, did not like them. The ACTU has been directing this Government from the wings for some time and forcing its own members onto the unemployment scrap heap in the meantime.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank all honourable senators who have participated in this lengthy but, by comparison, relatively curtailed Appropriations debate, both for their contributions and for their procedural cooperation in allowing us to get to this point at this stage. In such a wide-ranging debate by so many honourable senators, it is obviously impossible to deal with the issues raised by all of them, or to even attempt to deal with issues raised by any of them. In the normal course I would not but for the coincidence of having been in the chamber for the last hour or so during which time Senator Reid raised a very specific point to which she requested a response. I will refer to that briefly before I refer to the Australian Democrats' amendment in concluding the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Reid raised a very detailed issue about the situation of Buddhists in Vietnam, which she has raised in this chamber before during Question Time and perhaps on other occasions. I have to say that I support very strongly the Government's decision to resume aid to Vietnam. I think it was a timely and appropriate decision. I am not persuaded that the issue which Senator Reid raised should be a precondition for that resumption. She did not necessarily say it should; I accept that. But I want to put my broad position on the table.

All Australians, certainly all honourable senators, would share the concern for freedom of religion and tolerance of dissenting views which are a necessary part of a decent society. I share her hope that in Vietnam and in other countries in our region--notably in view of recent events in Burma--we will see a resumption of that level of tolerance and respect for human values and dissenting views. I cannot go to the detail of the points raised by Senator Reid tonight, but I will certainly refer the matter to the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, Dr Blewett, for his consideration.

I now turn to the amendment which was moved by Senator Short, on behalf of the Opposition. I indicate that, of course, we will be opposing the amendment. Given that the Australian Democrats' amendment opposes one of the things that we also oppose, we will be voting for their amendment. But should that be successful, we will still vote against the Opposition's amendment.

I want to make only two points about this amendment. It would be unduly repetitious to deal with all of the amendment because it relates to matters that we have dealt with before in this chamber. In fact, I think almost exactly the same amendment was moved previously to the Supply Bills. My first point is that this amendment shows, once again, that the Opposition is absolutely full of apprehension that the economy might improve and that it will have to start relying upon the substance of its own policies to win support. Those opposite are now starting to try to redefine full employment. I noticed that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) came up with a definition of full employment as being 6 per cent. I have to say that is not my view, and it is not the view of anybody other than those who take an extraordinarily narrow, technical and somewhat desiccated economic view of a very profound and serious social concern.

There are many references to which one could turn to indicate the underlying reasons for the profound concern the Opposition has about the clearly impending economic recovery, the signs for which are clear and unequivocal. Today I received market insights from Westpac for October 1991. Westpac makes it absolutely clear, in the opening paragraph of the summary by the chief economist, that recent results confirm its view that there will be a modest economic recovery in the first half of 1992. The report states:
. . . output may have bottomed and that manufacturers are more confident than at any time since 1989.
The report goes on:
The good news is on the inflation front, where there are finally signs of significant gains.
We are not just getting a flash in the pan inflation result, but a significant change in inflation expectations. The report continues:
. . . for the first time since the survey began in the 1960s, on balance, manufacturers are expecting prices to fall.
Westpac expressed the view that there remains further scope for interest rates to fall. Page 3 of the report states:
Leading indicators suggest the economy is on course for an upturn in the first half of 1992 . . . further declines in inflation are likely before it picks up in 1992.

In 1992 Westpac is expecting real GDP growth of 2.3 per cent and inflation still at 3.5 per cent, with continuing reductions in the current account deficit. Nobody is predicting that we will go back quickly to the roaring heady days of boom leading to inevitable bust. Westpac is saying that it expects a modest and sustainable recovery, for two reasons: first, inflation is contained--one of the great inhibitors of sustained recovery--and, secondly, the balance of payments constraint is also somewhat under control.
Opposition senators interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-For those who believe that they have made a contribution to a debate provided they open their mouths and something falls out, such as Senator Alston, these matters ought to be considered and digested somewhat more soberly. There are, in the interests of the Australian people and to everybody else's great delight, signs that the economy is about to recover. For example, the CAI-Westpac survey of industrial trends states:

SPEECH.PARA: New orders and output look set to turn up in the next six months.

Inflation is expected to be below 4.5 per cent right through until 1993, which is what is expected after two years of steady growth. We will still have inflation lower than or, at least, comparable with that of our OECD partners. The survey talks about the industries that will be at the vanguard of recovery. The survey states:
For the first time in nearly four years, a sizeable net balance of respondents expect production to increase in the next six months . . .

There are many more pages and many other references. With this sort of amendment, the Opposition is desperately clinging to the hope that it will perhaps be able to use the significant economic problems of the last 12 months to hide and disguise its own economic failings and to sneak into office.
Opposition senators interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have heard the comments; and I have heard their comments about Senator Short.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! Interjections are fair enough if they are instructive or amusing. Continuous interjections deny other people the right to hear the speaker. I suggest that those on the Opposition benches restrain themselves.

—-Mr Acting Deputy President, I appreciate your comments and guidance. The fact of the matter is that this happens every time the problem of impending improvement in the economy is raised because it is very uncomfortable for some people.

SPEECH.PARA: There are seven subclauses to the amendment. I could happily talk about all of them, but I will not because other speakers have exercised proper restraint in this debate and I intend to do the same. I refer to the first subclause, which makes clear the nature of the alternative response to the economy we could expect from the Opposition. At the same time, we have the Opposition feigning concern for the people who are unemployed. Everybody wishes that unemployment was much lower. The Opposition simultaneously says, `You must slash government spending' and `You must deal with fiscal irresponsibility'--as it now calls it. The great recipe for inequity in our society is trying to balance the Budget during a recession. To cut $4.7 billion from outlays to try to balance the Budget, on the most cautious of assessments, would cost another 46,000 jobs. It also indicates that the benefits and services available to people in the greatest need in our society would be further impaired.

I say to people that when we eventually see this much vaunted alternative economic package we should not just look at this question of consumption tax--whether it is 8 per cent, 10 per cent or 15 per cent, I do not care--which has an inequity element of its own, or at the redistribution of income tax, which also has inequity elements. The key thing to look at is the expenditure cuts where the Opposition intends to slash the spending on providing services to people in need in Australia; at the Opposition's attitude towards the people in greatest need; and at the inequitable and redistributive elements of the economic policy that will emerge when this alternative package is released.

The shadow Minister for finance, the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow Treasurer have all been saying that there should be expenditure cuts of $4 billion. In the course of a recession, that would cost 46,000 jobs. The Opposition would like to pretend that we would not have that sort of problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —-You have got 10.2 per cent unemployment.

—-And the Opposition is advocating a socially reprehensible policy in that circumstance. That is a cause for absolute concern. This amendment only reinforces that morally reprehensible approach. To be advocating those sorts of cuts and that sort of slashing of jobs in this environment is a clear indication of the nature of the alternative that the Australian people can look forward to.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that the Australian Democrats will vote for that element of the amendment is a surprise to me, but that is for them to express their concern about. It is one of those many indications, one of the straws in the wind, of the inequitable nature of programs which we can expect to see from the Opposition when, if ever, it releases its policy package. That is one of the several good reasons for rejecting the amendment. Apart from the gratuitous nature of the amendment, I thank honourable senators for their otherwise interesting contributions to the debate. I commend the Bills to the Senate.

That the amendment (Senator Coulter's) to Senator Short's amendment be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I seek leave to table the sixth edition of J.R. Odgers' Australian Senate Practice and to move a motion to take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

Mr President, as you know, last Thursday there was a function in the Mural Hall of this building to mark the publication of the sixth edition of Australian Senate Practice by the late J.R. Odgers. I was pleased that you attended on that occasion and spoke in support of the launching of that important work.

Jim Odgers served the Senate for nearly 40 years. He was Clerk from 1965 to 1979. This sixth edition is the last to be prepared under Jim Odgers' authorship and contains his reflections on developing Senate practices as they stood at the time of his death in 1985.

Odgers' Australian Senate Practice, the first edition of which appeared in 1953, is the first treatise on parliamentary procedure in an Australian parliament. Its uniqueness derives from the fact that it deals with an upper House. The book contains much wisdom on the role and value of an upper House in a system of responsible parliamentary government.

As honourable senators will be aware, a measure of controversy attaches to this book. It is true to say that few of us would agree with everything in the book which, after all, runs to more than 1,000 pages. I note that one of the major issues tackled afresh in this sixth edition concerns the right of the Senate to press requests for amendments to Bills which it is unable to amend under the Constitution.

Odgers clearly favours views put to the Senate in 1981 by Senator Gareth Evans, the present Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and then shadow Attorney-General, supporting the pressing of questions. He clearly does not sympathise with the contrary views which I, as Attorney-General, put forward on behalf of the then Government. I must say that that is one instance in which I have some disagreement with the views of Mr Odgers. I understand that other senators may have disagreements about other matters.

This is a book of character and substance, not blandness and ambiguity. The volume has been published by the Australian Capital Territory division of the Royal Australian Institute of Public Administration. That body undertook the task as a service in the public interest. The volume has not been commercially produced. Any surplus funds from the sales of the book will be used to sponsor a prize for writings on parliamentary issues.

Having discharged its trust, the Institute has sought my assistance in formally returning the book to the Senate, to whom it belongs and was seen by its eminent author--as the book's dedication makes plain--to belong. The Institute is keen that the book should be tabled. It views its role as having been one of temporary trust only.

There are good reasons why the book should be tabled in the Senate. It is the work of one of the most eminent of Senate Clerks, commenced while he was Usher of the Black Rod. As a member of the staff, he carried it through five editions. It is not just another book about parliament: it is the most authoritative exposition of parliamentary procedure in Australia.
