TALK.START.PARA: —-In mid-September I had the privilege of leading, under the auspices of the National Republican Institute for International Affairs, the official observer mission for the inaugural direct election for the Hong Kong Legislative Council, which was held on Sunday, 15 September 1991. Although this election gave Hong Kong residents for the first time the opportunity to directly elect representatives to the Legislative Council, it by no means signalled the arrival of full-blown democracy in this British colony.

SPEECH.PARA: The election was for 18 out of a total of 60 legislative councillors. Of the remaining 42, 21 were elected from the so-called functional constituencies on 12 September; 18 were appointed by the Governor subsequent to the election; while three are ex officio members of the Council. This reflects the fact that Hong Kong is not gaining its independence, as other former colonies have, but reverting from British to Chinese sovereignty under guidelines set forth in the 1984 Sino-British Joint Declaration on Hong Kong.

This agreement outlines the process of Hong Kong's formal change of sovereignty and provides for the drafting of what is described as a Basic Law, which will serve as Hong Kong's constitution after 1 July 1997. Under the formula established in the Joint Declaration and the subsequent Basic Law, Hong Kong's administrative development should follow a path of what is described as convergence from the British colonial order towards the laws and structures of the Basic Law. Thus, by establishing the end points of the process, relatively distinct parameters have been placed on Hong Kong's political development prior to 1997 which leave only a narrow role for representative governance. After 1997, the Basic Law becomes substantially more vague about Hong Kong's democratic development, giving no guarantees of democratic self-rule and few assurances to the people of Hong Kong.

The background to this development is, of course, the expiration of Britain's lease of the New Territories from China which is due in 1997. With that time rapidly approaching, in December 1984--after some two years of negotiations--Great Britain and the People's Republic of China signed the Sino-British Joint Declaration, which states in sum that China will regain sovereignty not only over the New Territories but also over Hong Kong and Kowloon in 1997.

So China resumes the exercise of sovereignty over Hong Kong in 1997 but, under the Joint Declaration, it was agreed that it would establish a Hong Kong Special Administrative Region. Under this Special Administrative Region, the intention was to uphold national unity and territorial integrity for Hong Kong, taking into account its history and its lifestyle; so the Central People's Government in Beijing would have direct authority over the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, but Hong Kong would experience a high degree of autonomy, with the exception of foreign affairs and defence matters which would be the responsibility of the Central People's Government.

Hong Kong's laws currently in force were to remain basically unchanged under the administration of the Special Administrative Region. The Special Administrative Region was to be responsible for the executive, legislative and independent judicial administration, including that of final adjudication. Under the agreement, the chief executive of the Special Administrative Region was to be nominated by the Central People's Republic of China and he, in turn, was to nominate principal officials to be appointed by the Chinese People's Government.

It was agreed that China would not change Hong Kong's current lifestyle, including primarily the social and economic systems. The Special Administrative Region was to ensure by law the rights and freedoms of persons, speech, the press, assembly, association, travel, movement, correspondence, strike, choice, occupation, academic research and religious beliefs. China was also to allow the Special Administrative Region to remain a free port of trade and a separate customs territory. China was to allow the full flow of capital and the continuation of foreign exchange, gold, securities and futures markets, which would contribute to the continuation of Hong Kong as an international financial centre. The Chinese Government was not to levy taxes and would allow the Special Administrative Region to exercise independent finances. China was to allow the Special Administrative Region to establish mutually beneficial economic relations with foreign countries, even if the People's Republic of China did not do the same.

Also, the Special Administrative Region of Hong Kong was to be allowed, independent of China, to maintain and develop economic and cultural relations and conclude relevant agreements with states, regions and independent organisations. Finally, the Government of the Special Administrative Region was to be responsible for the maintenance of public law within the region. All of these issues, which were set forth in the Joint Declaration between Britain and China, were then to be stipulated in what I mentioned earlier was described as the Basic Law of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, which would remain unchanged for 50 years and was, in effect, to be the constitution for Hong Kong.

In 1990, the Basic Law was promulgated. Perhaps, as a result of that law being promulgated not so long after the events of Tiananmen Square, it was not as liberal in its provisions for Hong Kong as had been anticipated. Mr Martin Lee, QC, a legislative councillor in Hong Kong, among others, has led the challenge to the Basic Law, both within Hong Kong and in the international community at large. Many agree with him that the new document does not accurately reflect the Sino-British Joint Declaration which, it is claimed, promised a fully elected legislature, an executive which is accountable to that legislature and an independent judiciary with the final power of interpretation of law.

Mr Lee and others have outlined what they argue are breaches of the Sino-British Joint Declaration with regard to its application on the Basic Law. Generally, the pro-democracy movement, which was a major player in the elections in mid-September, objected to allowing only one-third of the legislature to be directly elected by 1997. Under the Basic Law, the rest of the legislature will continue to be elected through what are described as functional constituencies, representing various occupational groups such as the legal profession, the medical profession, teachers, trade unions, chambers of commerce and so on, and an election committee--in effect an electoral college--which would be under the control of the Beijing Government by 1997.

The Basic Law provides that, even by the year 2007, only half of the Hong Kong legislature will be democratically elected. It makes no promise of a majority--let alone all--of the legislature for Hong Kong to be directly elected in the future. The Basic Law also appears to contravene the Sino-British Joint Declaration since that declaration provided that the executive authorities would be accountable to the legislature. However, in the Basic Law, it appears as though the legislature will not have that degree of power.

The legislature will be denied the power to pass a vote of no confidence against the chief executive, who will not be democratically elected but selected by an election committee--again an electoral college appointed by the Beijing Government and in fact removable only by the Beijing Government. The chief executive, in contrast, will have the power to unilaterally dissolve the legislature. In other words, while that legislature does not have the power to sack or pass a vote of no confidence in the chief executive, the chief executive himself can unilaterally dissolve and dismiss the Legislative Council.

Article 159 of the Basic Law gives the People's Republic of China the power to amend it unilaterally without the consent of the Hong Kong Legislative Council. Under the Basic Law, it is Beijing which has the final power of adjudication on interpreting the Basic Law. That final power of interpretation of adjudication rests not with the courts in Hong Kong, as it was expected would be the case under the Joint Declaration but, in fact, with the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress. That is very important background to the issues that were at stake in the Hong Kong election.

The current executive and legislative functions in Hong Kong are embodied in the Executive Council and the Legislative Council respectively. But final authority for legislation and administration lies with the Governor under the colonial status of Hong Kong. The Executive Council remains entirely appointed by the Governor at this time, and it is his principal policy adviser. It acts under sworn confidentiality and joint responsibility for decisions.

After the September election, the Legislative Council consists of three ex officio members, 18 members appointed by the Governor, 21 members elected from the functional constituencies which I described a few moments ago and 18 directly elected members. This is a total of 60 members of the Legislative Council.

In addition to the Executive Council and the Legislative Council, Hong Kong does have partly elected, partly appointed urban councils. In the New Territories, there is a similarly partly elected, partly appointed regional council as well as, under a district administration scheme, district management committees and district boards which have some elected officials. Those urban and regional councils have had elected members for several years. So there has been a measure of democracy developing in Hong Kong for some time now.

Until 1984, the Legislative Council was fully appointed by the Government, but it was at that time that functional constituencies were introduced whereby a certain number of members of that Council were elected from various occupational groups. Each occupational group had one member elected. As the proportions that I spoke about a few moments ago indicate, at most, by 1997 directly elected members of the Legislative Council will make up only one-third of its total. Of course, that is a very important point with regard to the recent election and also with the next direct election due in four years time, in 1995.

Because the system is a derivation of the British colonial administration, there is no clear separation of legislative and executive functions. This has the immediate effect of leaving the Legislative Council in a tenuous position with regard to its authority and responsibilities. It is clear that the Executive Council is by far the most powerful of the two bodies in policy making and in governing Hong Kong in general. All legislation considered and passed by the Legislative Council must receive the approval of the Governor-in-Council before it becomes law.

Of course, Hong Kong enjoys a strong common law tradition and a well-established framework of modern corporate and procedural laws, but these laws are virtually silent on political matters. The legal consideration of electoral politics is confined to the Legislative Council (Electoral Provisions) Ordinance and (Procedural) Regulations.

The citizens of Hong Kong expect the electoral legal framework to grow and change as Hong Kong's political experience grows. It is very hard to predict what form future electoral laws and practice will take. On the occasion of the first ever direct election for the Legislative Council last month, it was important for the Hong Kong people to express their hopes and concerns about Hong Kong's path into the future.

Since the creation of the Sino-British Joint Declaration, Hong Kong's political environment has been of a precarious nature. Having been a British colony for more than a century, Hong Kong has experienced little independent political activity. Political participation by the residents has been limited. In the recent history of Hong Kong, since 1982 there have been just five elections in the colony. They were for those urban councils and district boards that I referred to a few moments ago. In each case, the voter turnout has been relatively limited, ranging from a low of 22 per cent in 1983 to a 57.6 per cent turnout in 1985.

Of course, when we consider that turnout, while it may seem low in comparison with our own situation, we need to remember that we have compulsory voting whereas in Hong Kong, as in many other countries, voluntary voting is in vogue. But it is also important to remember that British colonial rule makes no provision for the formation of local parties. Indeed, it does not encourage the organisation of interest groups, and this may well explain to some extent the lack of participation to this date in Hong Kong politics.

Despite the low participation rates that Hong Kong has experienced thus far, there is an increased awareness of political affairs amongst the residents of Hong Kong. Certainly, political participation in Hong Kong has increased significantly over the past few years. In Hong Kong it is fair to say that the political climate oscillates between pessimism and optimism. There are those who believe that they can make a difference in determining Hong Kong's political future.

As far as politics is concerned, group activity in Hong Kong is organised around one issue: how to deal with the People's Republic of China when 1997 rolls around. Although there are a few small pro Taiwanese groups, a few Chinese mainland infiltrated groups and one newly developing group called the Hong Kong Democratic Foundation, in practice there are only two major groups with an effective political presence in Hong Kong. They are the Liberal Democratic Federation of Hong Kong and the United Democrats of Hong Kong. These two parties have both similarities and differences. They are similar in their views on the issue of Hong Kong's economic future. Both groups advocate and are committed to working towards maintaining Hong Kong's economic status within the international community. Both groups are adamant about preserving Hong Kong's free enterprise, free market economy. There are certainly no qualms about this issue. When it comes to economics, all of Hong Kong has agreed that the primary goal is to make a profit.

There are, in fact, two issues that determine group activity in Hong Kong: namely, economics, about which these two major groups agree; and the People's Republic of China, about which the two groups disagree. The United Democrats of Hong Kong aim to challenge the People's Republic of China for democratic reform up to and beyond 1997, while the Liberal Democratic Federation of Hong Kong does not. The United Democrats propose changing the newly determined Basic Law and advocate democratisation in Hong Kong at a much more rapid pace. The Liberal Democratic Federation does not want to aggravate the People's Republic, fearing that, if it does, it will see no freedom whatsoever in post-1997 Hong Kong. The Liberal Democratic Federation has taken a more conservative and slow-paced approach to democratisation.

The United Democrats are led by Martin Lee, QC, who visited Australia in April of this year and presented his arguments to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. He and his Party have certainly received more exposure on the international scene than the Liberal Democratic Federation. Mr Lee testified before the United States Senate Foreign Relations Committee in June 1990 on the issue of the denial of democracy and human rights before and after 1997 in Hong Kong. His Party has also submitted to the United Nations Human Rights Committee in March 1991 a protest regarding the Sino-British Joint Declaration and British obligations under the International Covenant for Civil and Political Rights. As I mentioned, on 11 April, Martin Lee himself appeared before our own Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, reinforcing the arguments that he had put to those other bodies.

Given the similarity of the manifestos and agendas of these two parties, Hong Kong politics is clearly one-issue oriented, that is, the issue of the People's Republic. The Liberal Democratic Federation would like to educate enough people, gather enough support and have enough democratisation to be able to co-exist peacefully and in a mutually beneficial relationship with the Chinese.

Martin Lee and the United Democrats do not trust the People's Republic and want to have as little to do with it as possible in the near and distant future. Martin Lee is quite willing to rock the boat and do what is necessary to establish democratic roots in Hong Kong and to gain political autonomy for the region after 1997. He and others contest that the Basic Law does not adhere to the promises agreed upon within the Sino-British Joint Declaration.

It is worth recalling that Mr Lee actually served from 1985 to 1989 as a member of the People's Republic of China-appointed Basic Law drafting committee--the mainland dominated group entrusted with the drafting of Hong Kong's post-1997 constitution. He gained widespread support in Hong Kong for his position as the drafting committee's leading proponent of democracy and human rights. It was on that basis that he was removed from the drafting committee by the People's Republic Government after his criticism of the 4 June 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre.

In contrast, the Liberal Democratic Federation accepts the Basic Law as it is and advocates an attempt to work within the system. That party is more interested in local level issues, as opposed to focusing on political development or the promotion of democracy for its own sake. The Liberal Democratic Federation has, therefore, been accused of being too accommodating to the Chinese and too conservative in its approach to democratic political development.

Despite the activities of these two parties, it is worth noting that in the recent elections some 70 per cent of candidates--not only for the recent Legislative Council elections but also for the earlier regional and urban council elections--chose not to affiliate with either of the two major parties. That, in part, reflects the fact that Hong Kong currently lacks a significant political environment within which to organise and participate. Apart from those two major parties, there are some smaller groups, such as Meeting Point and the Association for Democracy and People's Livelihood. As I said, there were a number of independent candidates, particularly in the Legislative Council elections.

It was not the purpose of the observer mission to in any way interfere with the electoral process in these elections but rather to conduct ourselves in an unbiased and non-partisan manner at all times. The threefold purpose of the mission in observing the Hong Kong elections was: firstly, to bring international attention to the status of Hong Kong's democratic development; secondly, to report on what degree of the internationally accepted standards of accessibility, transparency, fairness, openness and electoral due process existed in the Hong Kong electoral system; and, thirdly, to offer any insights which we, as individuals experienced in international affairs and practical politics, may have gained through our observations of various types of political systems.

In pursuit of these objectives, the observer mission spent several days prior to election day obtaining briefings from a range of people with information and expertise relevant to our task. These included diplomats, business representatives, academics, representatives of political parties and government electoral officials. We also informally observed the latter stages of the campaign, including media coverage.

Under my leadership, the mission also consisted of a representative from the Philippines, Mr Mariano Quesada, the vice-chairman for Mobilisation of the National Citizens Movement for Free Elections; from Britain, Mr John Whittingdale, OBE, former political secretary to former Prime Minister Thatcher and a Conservative Party candidate for the next elections; and three people from the United States: Mr Steven Saunders, an international public policy consultant, and Susan Gerrick and Shelly Stewart, both senior Congressional advisers. We were ably assisted in fulfilling our responsibilities by Institute staff Meg Thompson, Ed Stewart, Jeff Crouse and Jennifer Prah.

On election day we split into five groups of two and, with an interpreter and driver to assist, visited as many polling booths as possible between the polling hours within the electoral divisions allocated to us. It should be noted that the polling hours were between 7.30 a.m. and 10.30 p.m. As there were nine constituencies, this involved four of the teams covering two constituencies each and the remaining team covering the largest constituency.

At each polling booth we interviewed voters leaving after casting their vote, party workers handing out how-to-vote cards, pollsters conducting exit polls and, occasionally, polling booth officials who ventured outside. As will be explained later, we were precluded from observing the electoral process inside the booths.

The 18 seats--two from each of the nine constituencies--attracted a total of 54 candidates from a wide range of backgrounds. A number represented the several parties, but many were independent candidates. Most of the candidates were well supported by polling booth workers canvassing for votes with how-to-vote cards on election day. Often we saw eight, 10 or more workers for each candidate at the polling booths--an enthusiastic, but congested demonstration of democracy in action. At the end of the day and the next morning we met to pool our experiences and conclusions regarding the electoral process and prepared a final statement which was the subject of a press conference on Monday afternoon, 16 September. I seek leave to incorporate that statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows--
National Republican Institute for International Affairs
FINAL STATEMENT
International Delegation
Hong Kong
September 16, 1991

We are an international delegation sponsored by the National Republican Institute for International Affairs and are here to observe the first direct elections for the Legislative Council. Comprised of 10 delegates representing four nations, we bring to this delegation our individual and institutional experience in international affairs, election administration and practical politics. Having observed elections in twenty-three countries, the Republican Institute has developed significant and expertise in transitional political environments.

The Republican Institute has sent four study missions over the course of the past seven months in order to conduct an ongoing analysis of the democratic process in Hong Kong. The delegation has had discussions with political party leaders, election administrators, government representatives, members of the academic community, and foreign diplomats. On election day, our delegation divided into five teams which were deployed to all nine constituencies to interview voters, candidates, polling agents and election officials. Throughout the day, our teams visited over seventy polling stations. Unlike all previous Republican Institute observer missions, we were not allowed to enter polling stations actually to witness the voting and counting process. Our primary purpose was to assess the overall electoral process, to demonstrate international recognition of emerging democratic institutions in Hong Kong, and to offer suggestions to the Hong Kong Government for its forthcoming electoral review.

The development and implementation of representative government in Hong Kong is the affair and responsibility of the citizens of this territory. However, Hong Kong is an international city with international importance. As a demonstration of international support for the future of Hong Kong, we believe the international community has a duty to assess and to comment on Hong Kong's political situation.

The delegation commends the residents of Hong Kong, who as voters, candidates, and government officials, participated in these historic elections. Their commitment to the democratic process is encouraging for Hong Kong's future stability, prosperity, and democracy. Furthermore, we were particularly impressed with the level of voluntary participation by supporters working on behalf of candidates and parties, and by the professionalism with which the technical aspects of the elections were conducted.

We have reached several conclusions. The following comments and suggestions for consideration are made in order to assist Hong Kong as it refines and further develops its democratic system. These observations are made based on the experience of this international group and in comparison to international democratic practices. A more thorough assessment of the electoral process will be published in the near future.
With regard to election day procedures:
- In order to allow further development of and identification with political parties, party names and symbols should be included next to the names of candidates on the ballot.
- The number of polling stations should be increased in order to avoid overcrowding in the event of a large voter turnout.
- The "buffer zone" surrounding each polling station should be more clearly defined in order to maintain order at polling stations.

- Obtaining signatures of voters next to their names on electoral rolls as they collect their ballot at the polling table could assure greater control over access to ballots and a more transparent process.

- The delegation heard complaints of and witnessed voters being inconvenienced by canvassers and campaigners outside the polling stations. Placing stricter limits on the areas in which canvassers are allowed could alleviate this problem.
- Provisions could be considered to allow the vote to absentee registered voters.
- Given the fact that 18 is the age of majority in Hong Kong, extending the franchise to persons who have reached that age might be considered.

- The vote counting and tabulation procedures could be moved from the counting centre to the polling station level so as to ensure greater transparency and more timely announcement of results at the polling station level.
With regard to the registration process:
- The registration system should be clarified and publicised and the timing of registration more flexible so as to allow more eligible voters the necessary time to register.
- The voter registration process could be reviewed and reformed in such a way as to reduce the chance of legal voters from being dropped from the voter rolls incorrectly.
With regard to the campaign process:
- Political association and activity should be given greater legal guarantees and protection.

- We received widespread complaints that candidates exceeded the established spending limit. Campaign spending limits should be increased in order for political parties and candidates to carry out their activities.
- Clearer guidelines should be established concerning what constitutes campaign expenditures and contributions.
- As the political system develops and matures, the electronic media should make itself more available for candidate and political party use.

Finally, the delegation suggests that an independent electoral commission be considered to be comprised of persons drawn from all concerned sectors. Such a body could be responsible for geographical boundaries, voter registration, election disputes and protests, poll and tabulation security, appointment and training of election officials, registration of political parties, public disclosure of candidate funding and spending, and the administration of the election day procedures.

In the view of this delegation, yesterday's Legislative Council elections were peaceful and orderly. Despite the limitations of our observation, we believe that the polling and tabulation were conducted in a fair manner. We have seen no evidence of centralised or systematic fraud in the conduct of election day activities.
The delegation thanks the citizens of the territory for their assistance and hospitality during our work here. We congratulate the people of Hong Kong on this democratic and historic achievement.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank the Senate and the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson). This statement summarises and makes recommendations regarding a number of issues concerning the electoral process in Hong Kong upon which I will seek to enlarge.

SPEECH.PARA: It needs to be understood that political parties in Hong Kong are not legally recognised as specific politically motivated organisations which are distinct from business corporations or other private voluntary associations. As such, they are governed by laws designed to regulate societies or business corporations. As can be expected, this has given rise to problems in adapting the structures and operations of political parties to the established regulations.

One example of this is the function of political fundraising. Fundraising activities are governed by social welfare and police laws. Public soliciting of funds has always been directly and solely associated with charitable social welfare organisations and thus they are regulated through government agencies appropriate to these activities. These same agencies have explicitly and implicitly disallowed any political content to the charitable activities within their purview. Since this extends to public fundraising, political parties have been unable to collect funds and hold membership drives in public places. Permits are granted for activities in certain easily regulated and controlled areas, such as sports stadiums, but this has proved relatively ineffective when compared to open public solicitation.

Another example of this has been the application of police regulations to public rallies or meetings. In Hong Kong, any loudspeaker to be used in public must be registered with the police. Several political leaders have been arrested for using unregistered loudspeakers during political rallies in the election campaign. This type of regulation, in addition to a general hesitancy about political activities, has hindered political organisations in organising events and publicly disseminating their platforms.

An explicit law requiring registration of political parties could lend itself to greater and more explicit regulation of parties which would serve as an even greater barrier to political activity. However, it is apparent that there needs to be some legal consideration of political parties' rights to organise and conduct political activities freely. The current laws applicable to political parties, at best, hinder political party activity and, at worst, have acted as a principal obstacle to political party formation and the conduct of organised political activity.

With regard to political expenditures, individual candidates for the geographical constituencies were limited to an expenditure of $HK200,000 or about $A33,000. In a relatively expensive Hong Kong, this amount is far too low to enable candidates to conduct a viable electoral campaign honestly. While the Government provides postage for two mailings for each candidate free of charge, the printing of these mailings can nearly wipe out the candidate's allotted expenditure. This situation forces virtually all candidates to evade the expenditure restrictions quietly, thus rendering one of the few campaign regulations inoperative. We found plenty of anecdotal evidence during our investigations that this overspending with regard to the regulation had indeed occurred.

On the other hand, political parties, as corporations, have no general limit on expenditures. This fact could promote the formation of political parties, but the very ambiguous line between party and individual expenditure makes the activities of a party suspect when they come close to operating in the interest of individuals. A party's expenditures must be limited to promoting ideas of the party, some of which may be held in common with individuals. The grey areas between party and individual expenditure leave a lot of room for intentional or unintentional violation of the laws. The embryonic nature of the legal framework and the permissive attitude of the Hong Kong authorities have allowed such legal questions to go unchallenged. It is clear that this is an area of unanticipated problems which must be dealt with as the legal framework matures.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 12 September 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the Minister's answer to a question without notice from Senator Devereux on 4 September 1991 (Senate Hansard, p.1152-1153)

(1) Was the quotation cited by the Minister from the Policymakers Summary of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change which does not necessarily reflect the views of the 170 scientists involved and did the 700 scientists at the Second World Climate Conference in Geneva in 1990 necessarily endorse the statements.

(2) Have many scientists, including Professor Richard Lindzen from MIT, arguably the world's most eminent atmospheric physicist, expressed deep scepticism about the likelihood of significant human caused global warming.
(3) Did the Industry Commission in its draft report (p.134) observe that the Tasman loss `is broadly comparable with the Commission's estimates of loss of GDP'.

(4) Did the Industry Commission forecast Australian coal output under the Toronto target would fall by 70 per cent by the year 2005, a level comparable with the Tasman estimates, and did the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics forecast an even faster phase out of coal, envisaging its total phase out for domestic power generation by the year 2005.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following response to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The quotation cited was from the Policymakers Summary of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) report `Climate Change--The Scientific Assessment'.
To quote the chairman of the IPCC Working Group in the foreword to this IPCC report:

`Although, as in any developing scientific topic, there is a minority of opinions which we have not been able to accommodate, the peer review has helped to ensure a high degree of consensus amongst authors and reviewers regarding the results presented. Thus the assessment is an authoritative statement of the views of the international scientific community at this time.'
With respect to the Second World Climate Conference's endorsement of the IPCC report, the Conference Statement says:
`The conference agreed that [the] scientific conclusions set out by the IPCC reflect the international consensus of scientific understanding of climate change'.

There are a small minority of scientists who have raised dissenting voices in regard to the IPCC findings on the enhanced greenhouse effect. Some scientists have suggested that the greenhouse effect is less likely to occur than currently accepted by the mainstream scientific community. Others have raised concerns suggesting that there is the possibility of a climate 'surprise' that may lead to much greater impacts.
(3) The Industry Commission did make that observation in relation to one of the many scenarios they studied.

The quotation should be read in the context that although the results were `broadly comparable', the assumptions and methodology used in arriving at these results were vastly different. The Commission comments on the assumptions the Tasman Institute used to calculate the loss figure on page G26 where they said `the Tasman Institute ... used a tax rate which was about three times higher than the Commission's estimate of the tax required ... [the Tasman] estimate was calculated for the US ... The required rate should be lower in Australia'.

It should also be pointed out that the Industry Commission was comparing two different sorts of figures--`welfare loss' in the case of the Tasman Institute, and `GDP loss' in the case of the Industry Commission. As explained by the Tasman Institute in their paper `Global Warming--Its Economics and Politics', these two measures do not necessarily correspond.
The Industry Commission recognised the shortcomings of all the estimations of costs and benefits that have been attempted so far when they said:

`What the Commission's work has shown, however, is that while there is a better basis for estimation of cost effects than climate effects, the complexity of economic interactions, especially when considered over time, are such that it is difficult to be confident about the ability of existing economic models to get it right.' (Page 89)

These were scenarios, not forecasts. The scenarios studied by the Industry Commission and the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics are based on economic models with all the limitations and qualifications of such tools the Industry Commission gave recognition to. The output of such models is a reflection of the methods, assumptions and constraints of such models. The scenarios examined by such models tell us something about the possible results of pursuing a particular policy path, such as the narrow possibility of reductions in greenhouse gas emissions being achieved solely through imposition of a carbon tax as in the Tasman Institute study.
This is very unlikely to be the policy path followed. Thus work done to date with these models does not inform us as to what is likely to happen in the future.

In this context the Industry Commission's comments should be noted--`it is difficult to be confident about the ability of existing economic models to get it right' (page 89) and `these results should not be taken to be forecasts' (page 26).

It should also be pointed out that the ABARE model referred to is now producing very different results with respect to the coal industry, using a different set of assumptions. This reflects the considerable state of flux and uncertainty in economic modelling, even that performed by ABARE, a body with considerable experience in the field.
